HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "THE AMERICAN EFFECT: GLOBAL PERSPECTIVES ON THE UNITED STATES, 1990-2003," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676, through Oct. 12. Exploring ways that artists throughout the world react to the United States as a superpower, this show of documentary films, videos, installations, photographs, paintings and objects by 47 artists and filmmakers and 3 collaborative groups runs from sunny side up to deep despair. There are reflections on America's military and industrial might, its treatment of minorities, its consumerism, its justice system, its marketing strategies, its religious evangelism, its celebrity worship and its interference with other governments. There are also expressions of admiration for the freedoms, the opportunities and the material achievements of a country unfettered by ancient traditions. A wacky installation by a French artist, Gilles Barbier, in the form of life-size figures offers a wry take on the United States through its aging comic book heroes, viewed in the setting of a nursing home and in the last stages of decrepitude. The show has its weak spots but is provocative and visually compelling over all. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 62+, $9.50 (Grace Glueck).

* "THE DAWN OF PHOTOGRAPHY: FRENCH DAGUERREOTYPES, 1839-1855," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Jan. 4. Silvered sheets of copper, sensitized with iodine and developed in heated fumes of mercury, daguerreotypes are alchemical objects of ethereal physicality. The show, although a little too large and repetitive, lucidly tracks the brief evolution of daguerreotypy in France, where the medium lasted barely two decades after its invention in 1839. The best daguerreotypes remain weirdly unlike any other photographs, with their own mysterious sense of space. From this, photography got the seeds of its talismanic aura: most people wouldn't casually rip up photographs of their loved ones, because it is still commonplace to believe, if only unconsciously, that photographs somehow contain tidbits of the souls of their subjects. That is completely irrational and superstitious, of course. But you can see where it comes from when you look at daguerreotypes. They are perfectly true to life and somehow not of this world. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 65+, $7 (Michael Kimmelman).

* "FRENCH ARTISTS IN ROME: INGRES TO DEGAS, 1803-1873," Dahesh Museum of Art, 580 Madison Avenue, at 56th Street, (212) 759-0606, through Nov. 2. The show auspiciously inaugurates the Dahesh's new Manhattan home in the former I.B.M. gallery, which is just about the only below-ground space in town that is not too bad for looking at art. It charts the evolution of 19th-century French academic art in Rome, although at heart it's about young friends finding themselves as artists in a great city with an intimidating past, a prototypical story that could be told about New York or Paris. The academic stars here are Ingres and David d'Angers. Adolphe William Bouguereau's "Battle Between the Centaurs and the Lapiths," an academic machine of a painting, is a remarkable picture if you can stand it. But the best works in the show tend to be informal portraits and sketches of the Roman landscape, fresh and bathed in light. The exhibition ends on an ethereal note, with paintings by Moreau, Puvis de Chavannes and Degas, who challenged academia and for whom Rome became, when they were older, a kind of enchanted memory. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $9; students and 62+, $4 (Kimmelman).

"FRIDA KAHLO'S INTIMATE FAMILY PICTURE," Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200, through Jan. 4. The message of this small painting-cum-photography show seems to be that one of the starriest idols in the feminist pantheon was half Jewish, on her father's side. It is based on her elaborate 1936 painting "My Grandparents, My Parents and I," which depicts her as a child with ancestral portraits, embellished by such clinical details as herself as a fetus in her mother's womb and an egg being fertilized by a sperm. The painting is accompanied by vivid photographs of the artist as a child and a young woman, taken by her photographer father; reproductions of other paintings, including some of her own and a portrait by Henri Rousseau and his wife that apparently inspired her; pertinent books; and other material. It all seems a rather slight basis for an exhibition but proves again that the personal, obsessive thrust of Kahlo's work makes you feel the pain of her life. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m.; Fridays, to 3 p.m. Admission: $10; students and 65+, $7.50 (Glueck).

* ELLSWORTH KELLY, "Red Green Blue," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676, through Nov. 2. Mr. Kelly was the Chet Baker of the new, cool painters of the post-Abstract Expressionist generation. From the late 50's to the mid-60's he produced a series of paintings using the colors red, blue and green. On view in this show, they still sing. With their optically dazzling, high-keyed colors, their catchy, simplified designs and their satiny, brush-free surfaces, the paintings communicate the excitement of a new hedonistic optimism that did much to make the 60's what they were. Hours and admission: See above (Ken Johnson).

* "PASSION FOR THE MOUNTAINS: 17TH-CENTURY LANDSCAPE PAINTINGS FROM THE NANJING MUSEUM," China Institute Gallery, 125 East 65th Street, (212) 744-8181, through Dec. 20. The focus of this exquisite show is on the southern city of Nanjing between the defeat of the Ming dynasty in 1644 and the subsequent consolidation of the Qing dynasty. The scrolls, album paintings and fan paintings on loan from the Nanjing Museum distill both the verve of that cosmopolitan city and the mood of fatalistic nostalgia that has long defined classical Chinese art and was particularly acute in periods of political transition. A hand scroll titled "A Thousand Cliffs and Myriad Valleys" by Gong Xian, one of the great Nanjing artists, is a standout. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays and Thursdays, until 8 p.m. Admission: $5; for students and 62+, $3 (Holland Cotter).

* "STRANGERS: THE FIRST I.C.P. TRIENNIAL OF PHOTOGRAPHY AND VIDEO," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0090, through Nov. 30. Not that anyone except the curators felt there was a pressing need for yet another art survey, but the first I.C.P. triennial is that rare case: an instructive, topical show. The theme, "strangers," is nebulous enough to be a catchall for different brands of photography and video (works by Luc Delahaye, Rineke Dijkstra, Collier Schorr, Susan Meiselas, among others); not many of these are discoveries, but the range is wide enough to accommodate the dissimilartastes of the four curators and the diversity of photographic work being made today. The title is also specific enough to mean something. After 9/11 the subject of strangers has gained traction, and most of what's here expresses a cautionary view that the world is full of people who are strangers to one another. You might say that after years of navel-gazing, the climate of photo-based art, as this show presents it, has gradually shifted from me to them. Hours and admission: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; students and 62+, $7 (Kimmelman).

Galleries: Uptown

KATY GRANNAN, Salon 94, 12 East 94th Street, (646) 672-9212, hrough Oct. 29, and Artemis Greenberg Van Doren Gallery, 730 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 445-0444, through tomorrow. Echoes of August Sander, Diane Arbus, William Eggleston and high-fashion shots inform these too-derivative photographs, whose youngish, anonymous subjects seem carefully unposed in unremarkable settings. In the black-and-white series "The Morning Call" the sitters responded to Ms. Grannan's newspaper advertisements for models; dressed or naked, most appear in their own homes, nudged by the camera into roles they seem to seek. In "Sugar Camp Road" at Artemis Greenberg Van Doren, Ms. Grannan ventures into larger color formats and outdoor settings. Light plays a formative role, and the approaches are more venturesome, some suggestive, some prim. Though highly acclaimed, Ms. Grannan does not seem to have arrived yet at a truly distinctive style (Glueck).

LOTHAR OSTERBURG, "At the Edge of the Real," Achim Moeller, 167 East 73rd Street, (212) 988-4500, through Oct. 17. Conjuring monumental phenomena with minimal means, Mr. Osterburg presents picturesque photogravures of events like a Zeppelin over Timbuktu or a landing craft's approach to a celestial body. But the settings and props are all contrived in his studio, using mundane materials like twigs, toothpicks, peanut butter and wee electrical parts. Photographed through a magnifying glass or a macro lens, his pictures are given a romantic, retro look through photogravure. Blowing up small objects and settings to make large-scale photographs is nothing new, but Mr. Osterburg's skill in constructing his scenes and suffusing them with nostalgia is quite special (Glueck).

Galleries: 57th Street

"AMERICAN EXPRESSIONISM: ART AND SOCIAL CHANGE, 1920'S-1950'S," Kennedy, 730 Fifth Avenue, (212) 541-9600, through Nov. 1. A group show of artists pegged by the show's curator, the art and cultural historian Bram Djikstra, as dealing with the hopes, desires and economic troubles of the working classes around the era of the Depression. The problem is that the show's concept has been stretched to a one-size-fits-all cover for an improbable mix of artists whose styles run from the in-your-face injustice imagery of Charles White and Harry Sternberg to the poetic modernism of Marsden Hartley and John Marin. Topflight artists have been lumped with those who at best were mere illustrators. Yet nostalgia buffs, who remember the socially concerned art of the 30's and 40's, will get a charge from some wonderful relics, like Paul Cadmus's rip-roaring satire, "The Fleet's In" (Glueck).

* RINEKE DIJKSTRA, Marian Goodman, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 977-7160, through Oct. 11. The Dutch artist presents two remarkable series of photographs tracing the progress of new soldiers, one an Israeli woman, one a Frenchman in the Foreign Legion, whom we see grow up over the course of the works. Ms. Dijkstra's subject is life in transition: the cusp of adulthood, parenthood, a new job or a refugee settling in a new country, passages through which people become themselves and in the process reveal themselves. As usual, her photographs are simple, head-on figures against plain backdrops, the subjects staring passively at the camera, presenting themselves as they wish, or trying to, alert but just on the edge of fatigue or distraction, which means their guard is almost down (Kimmelman).

"THE 1940'S: MODERN AMERICAN ART AND DESIGN," Michael Rosenfeld, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 247-0082, through Nov. 1. Set up like the living room of a sharp-eyed collector of Modernist antiques, this exhibition gathers paintings by Mark Rothko and Dorothea Tanning; sculpture by Alexander Calder and Jose de Rivera; furniture by Charles and Ray Eames and Frank Lloyd Wright; and much more. (In another room, Charmion von Wiegand's colorful, abstract gouache paintings, titled "Improvisations: 1945," are lightweight but infectiously playful.) (Johnson).

* JUDY PFAFF, "Neither Here Nor There," Ameringer & Yohe, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 445-0051, through Oct. 11. Given the ubiquity of the installation-piece-as-planned-chaos, Ms. Pfaff should get more respect. "Neither Here Nor There" shows her fluency with a newly transparent, levitating compositional approach, which more than ever offers a seamless melding of drawing, painting and sculpture. It provides a global tour of architectural traditions, materials and motifs, mixing past and present, East and West, decorative and structural, into an elegantly articulate global reverie (Roberta Smith).

VINCENT SMITH, Alexandre, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 755-2828, through Oct. 11. After the recent Jacob Lawrence retrospective and with a Romare Bearden survey now at the National Gallery in Washington, this is a good time to revisit the work of Mr. Smith, a painter who learned much from both artists but struck out in directions of his own. A figurative painter of an abstracting and material-intensive kind, he is generous with pigment. Many of his images are pattern-based, made up of nested rectangles and fields of stippled flecks and dots in glowing colors. The results, without overplaying their political hand, generate a smoldering eschatalogical fervor (Cotter).

Galleries: SoHo

"INTERNAL EXCESS," the Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166, through Oct. 18. Highlights of the Drawing Center's latest selection of emerging artists include Arthur Aghajanian's sly charts analyzing familial relations; Mie Yim's pastel pictures of stuffed bears and bunnies in anxiety-fraught situations; Lamar Peterson's coolly surrealistic cartoon images of middle-class blacks; Douglas Florian's idiosyncratic abstractions painted on paper towels; Christine Hiebert's elegantly airy mural made of blue tape; and Astrid Bowlby's bewideringly complex accumulation of cutout cartoon fragments (Johnson).

"O907," Swiss Institute, 495 Broadway, near Spring Street, (212) 925-2035, through Oct. 25. Three neo-Duchampians. Francis Baudevin makes elegant, hard-edged, geometric wall paintings exactingly based on actual corporate logos; Mathieu Mercier glues toothpaste, candy and roach trap boxes together into abstract, Constructivist-style structures; and Nic Hess created an expansive, faux-brick wall out of brown plastic packing tape (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

* ROGER ANDERSSON, Sara Meltzer, 516 West 20th Street, (212) 727-9330, through Oct. 11. Mr. Andersson, a young Swedish artist, uses the letters of the alphabet and a hyper-polished illustrational style to create a corrupt version of fairy tales. Each letter is painted large and embellished with tiny figures and emblems that refer to adolescent politics, pop music and drug culture, and with minutely observed depictions of Scandinavian flora. The primer format, executed in Delft tile blue-and-white, is a clever, if small-scale idea, but Mr. Andersson's smooth, sweet virtuosity gives it some bite (Cotter).

BONNIE COLLURA, "Rebel Angel," Susan Inglett, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 647-9111, through Oct. 11. Ms. Collura's life-size sculptures of angels expelled from heaven have twisted, bulbous, broken and otherwise fantastically altered bodies; and she gives them masks and costumes from sources like Bernini, the Commedia del Arte, "The Wizard of Oz" and Disney's "Snow White." Despite tendencies toward confusing generalization, the work exudes a compelling baroque pathos (Johnson).

TIM DAVIS, Brent Sikkema, 530 West 22nd Street, (212) 929-2262, through Oct. 11. Mr. Davis's nocturnal photographs of nondescript houses with electric commercial signs reflected in their windows were magical. This show's pictures of paintings in museums, photographed to emphasize glaring surface reflections, similarly conflate different levels of reality -- the physical and the illusory -- but the effect is more interesting conceptually than visually (Johnson).

* PHILIP-LORCA DICORCIA, "A Storybook Life," Pace/MacGill Gallery at PaceWildenstein, 534 West 25th Street, (212) 929-7000, through Oct. 11. An unusually personal show from a master of the baroque of everyday life, this show arranges 75 photographs from 25 years into a loose (but not chronological) narrative that intimates an artistic development, an array of personal ties and a penchant for fusing the artificial and the natural in pictures whose emotional and formal resonances seem to unfold in real time (Smith).

* LYLE ASHTON HARRIS, "Memoirs of Hadrian," CRG, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 229-2766, through Oct. 18. The large-format photographs in this New York artist's first local show since 1996 were inspired by Marguerite Yourcenar's fictional autobiography of the aging Roman emperor. At the heart of the story is the figure of Antinous, Hadrian's young lover, who drowned and was posthumously deified by imperial order. Their relationship is described in the book as a power struggle, with the emperor fixated on his lover's physical beauty and un-Roman exoticism. The focus of Mr. Harris's pictures is a young black boxer, played by the artist, an object of intense public fascination, but one routinely cast in racist terms of hero, villain and victim (Cotter).

SETH KELLY, "Pseudomorphosis," Derek Eller, 526-30 West 25th Street, (212) 206-6411, through Oct. 11. Mr. Kelly's clunky, allegorical sculptures look like the work of a pretentious teenager who wants to say something about the Middle East. They include an inverted ceiling-mounted mosque, painted to suggest a starry night sky; an army of 14-inch-tall desert warriors derived from Egyptian mythology and Hollywood movies; and a wall drawing of a rocky mountain cave that has the overall appearance of a hand grenade -- a clever allusion, presumably, to Osama bin Laden (Johnson).

JULIAN LETHBRIDGE, Paula Cooper, 521 West 21st Street, (212) 255-1105, through Oct. 18. Mr. Lethbridge paints with a rough immediacy that calls to mind Terry Winters and harks back to the all-over gesturalism of Pollock and de Kooning. In grays or two-color palettes, he creates busy fields of short straight lines, which seem to circulate in response to invisible electromagnetic currents over more broadly and loosely painted lower layers. The paintings have frontal authority; what they want is more adventurous unpredictablility (Johnson).

HANS NELEMAN, "Night Chicas," Ricco/Maresca, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 627-4819, through Oct. 11. It is a curious coincidence that Mr. Neleman's big, glossy photographs of prostitutes in Guatemala are up at the same time as Reagan Louie's pictures of Asian sex industry workers (at Von Lintel Gallery). Or maybe it's not, given the popularity of photographic slumming. In any event, Mr. Neleman's best pictures are powerfully theatrical and visually lush. The almost surrealistic image, of a beautiful naked teenager with her feral-looking pet racoon, is stunning (Johnson).

ALESSANDRO RAHO, Cheim & Read, 547 West 25th Street, (212) 242-7727, through Oct. 11. Under the influence of Alex Katz and David Hockney's realist period, this young London artist paints life-size, whole-figure portraits of trim, beautiful people, floral still-lifes and small pictures of palatial tropical homes. If his paintings weren't so clearly sincere in their sensitively deft execution, you might wonder if Mr. Raho might intend a subversive parody of a certain high bourgeois taste (Johnson).

EDDO STERN, "GodsEye," Postmasters, 459 West 19th Street, (212) 727-3323, through Oct. 11. Unlike most artists working with computers, Mr. Stern pays as much attention to the physical presence of the generic desktop as he does to the development of digital imagery on the monitor. Four sculptures inventively transform the familiar beige plastic outer shell into Lego-like models: an aircraft carrier, a castle, a windmill and a cathedral. Each houses appropriate video game-style imagery, like dragons, medieval warriors and contemporary soldiers (Johnson).

JIL WEINSTOCK, "Cool White"; GERHARD MAYER, "Medium Resolution Imaging Spectrometer," Caren Golden, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 727-8304, through Oct. 11. Ms. Weinstock soaks striped men's shirts in clear rubber, stretches them on rectangular wood frames and lights them from behind so they glow like stained glass. Women's negligees, similarly treated, add an alluring feminine spin to her commentary on art and its commodification. Mr. Mayer, a German sculptor, makes abstract ink drawings that are amazing for their trippy, systematic complexity (Johnson).

Other Galleries

* "EVERYTHING MATTERS: PAUL KOS, A RETROSPECTIVE," Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780, through Dec. 6. Mr. Kos's name will ring too few bells here. He helped germinate the Bay Area Conceptual movement that pioneered video, performance and installation art in the late 1960's and early 70's. The spirit of his work is lighthearted and sly. One of his best early videos, from 1974, was shot in Wyoming: "Pilot Butte/Pilot Light" switches back and forth between that eponymous butte and Mr. Kos fashioning a lens out of a block of ice (you see him spinning the block on the inside of the lid of a pot to get the proper curvature), then focusing sunlight through the ice to spark kindling. The through-line is Mr. Kos's catholic approach to materials. He balances a candle and a bell on the tip of a broomstick, which he discovered one day would stand up on its own if he jammed the business end of the broom against the floor just right. Better late than never to remind New Yorkers that some of what we take to be fresh or our own discovery in art has been done before, and elsewhere (Kimmelman).

TAKASHI MURAKAMI, "Reversed Double Helix," Rockefeller Center, (212) 980-3942, through Oct. 12. At the center of Mr. Murakami's eye-grabbing outdoor sculptural tableau sits Mr. Pointy, a giant slug-like cartoon character in colorful molded plastic who meditates with Buddha-like complacency upon a pair of hovering 33-foot black balloons emblazoned with winking eyes. Surrounded by pudgy, cherubic guards and flanked by patches of giant mushrooms, which serve as seats for weary parents and gymnastic pedestals for toddlers, Mr. Pointy might be a beneficent god of child-centric fantasy or a Pied Piper of contemporary digital oblivion (Johnson).

Last Chance

DERRICK ADAMS, Jack Tilton, 49 Greene Street, SoHo, (212) 941-1775, through tomorrow. The ingredients in this young New York artist's solo debut show include sex, children's toys, racial stereotypes and breakfast cereal, which is actually not that unusual a mix in art these days. A video shows a gluttonous Teddy Bear's picnic shot near the Hudson River at 125th Street, while a sculpture in the back room involves a fuzzy pink elephant trunk spouting cornflakes. In short, there's a lot happening of an innocence-and-experience kind, and Mr. Adams's approach is evenhandedly naughty and nice (Cotter).

FRED BECKER, "A 90th Birthday Celebration," Susan Teller, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 941-7335, through tomorrow. A painter, draftsman and printmaker, Mr. Becker began his career doing etchings and wood engravings with the W.P.A. in the 1930's and later mastered a variety of techniques and styles. This show presents works going back to 1935, among them a winning, complex little color drawing of a bicyclist. But its highlights are a group of colorific acrylics from the mid-1950's, like "Abstraction," a gestural painting of black and white lines and shapes that dance on a ground of brilliantly hued planes. There's much else here, too, to surprise and entertain the eye (Glueck).

* BJORN DAHLEM, "Coma Sculptor," Friedrich Petzel, 535 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 680-9467, through tomorrow. This young German sculptor is not really a zany madman, but he does a good job of playing one. With the skills of an inept handyman, Mr. Dahlem has used raw lumber, packing tape and ordinary electric lights to cobble together a sprawling, hovering model of what he claims to be a "galactic supercluster." At the center, inside a silver-painted wooden pyramid framework, is a symbol of essential life: a hot dog in a bottle of clear liquid (Johnson).

* SAMUEL FOSSO, Jack Shainman, 513 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 645-1701, through tomorrow.This African artist, who was born in Cameroon and lives and works in Central African Republic, makes an overdue Manhattan solo debut with 33 photographs spanning his career. In the 1970's Mr. Fosso opened a professional photo-portrait studio, and between sessions with his clients took pictures of himself dressed in local versions of Western fashions. A result is self-portraiture both autobiographical and fictional, an art of trying on styles, moods and selves in the years after independence movements left Africa colonial and postcolonial, liberated and trapped. His pictures reflect much of that, and none with more immediacy than a 1996 photo made during political turmoil, in which he depicts himself as a naked prisoner, looking startled, intruded on, hurt (Cotter).

* "IN THE PUBLIC DOMAIN," Greene Naftali, 526 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 463-7770, through tomorrow. A great idea. For this show the gallery is functioning as a modest-size bookshop stocked with inexpensive and hard-to-find publications, in several media, by or about contemporary artists. From Lucas and Sternberg Press come polished books on Kai Althoff and Marcel Odenbach. A collaborative called Continuous Projects (Wade Guyton, Seth Price and Bettina Funke) offers photocopies of a hot publication of yesteryear, Avalanche. The musician Arturo Lindsay is represented by CD's; Ara Peterson, of the disbanded Forcefield collective, by a riveting video of horror movie outtakes. Most fun, and very cheap, is a tabloid newspaper published by Aleksandra Mir, a young New York artist who should be on everyone's radar by now (Cotter).

"MATERIAL DIFFERENCES: ART AND IDENTITY IN AFRICA," Museum for African Art, 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-7700, through Monday. Part Art Methods 101, part Advanced Connoisseurship, this handsome, thoughtful show examines the potent connection between matter and meaning in diverse African cultures and shows them to be organically connected. The material is spiritual in these cultures, and the show's 130 mostly ceremonial objects, arranged strictly according to materials and techniques, reflect the power of that belief. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; students and 65+, $3 (Smith).

MARC SWANSON, "Live Free or Die," Bellwether, 335 Grand Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 387-3701, through Monday. Mr. Swanson has assembled an elaborate two-room installation dense with personal symbols of what it meant to grow up gay and artist in rural America. Sculptures of black deer, sparkling with glitter, stand by the entrance; a rainbow-colored target fills a wall; marijuana leaves lie on a pedestal; weblike nets hang from the ceiling. The prevailing themes are hunting and escaping, and Mr. Swanson handles them with episodic elan (Cotter).

* JAMES WELLING, "Los Angeles," Gorney Bravin & Lee, 534 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 352-8372, through tomorrow. Looking at Mr. Welling's melancholy, beautifully composed and printed photographs of scenes in Los Angeles, including images of battered parked cars, industrial buildings tarted up with bright new paint and a ghostly seaside amusement park, you might feel as if you were seeing through the eyes of a burned-out movie detective on a hopeless case (Johnson).

GRAPHIC: Photos: Guillermo Kahlom's portrait of Frida Kahlo, at Jewish Museum. (Photo by Throckmorton Fine Art); "Wellfleet" by Philip-Lorca diCorcia, from his series "A Storybook Life" at Pace/MacGill Gallery at PaceWildenstein in Chelsea.

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk; Pg. 3

HEADLINE: REVERBERATIONS; 
Opening Night: Glamour, Grumbling and Even Opera

BYLINE:  By John Rockwell

 BODY:
Even with air-conditioning and year-round union contracts and summer festivals under every tree, a new season stirs to life every fall. For culture mavens nothing -- not the first blockbuster exhibition opening at the Metropolitan Museum, not the first television shows or post-summer semi-serious films -- symbolizes that new beginning like an opera opening.
 Two of the country's grandest and most venerable companies, the San Francisco Opera and the Metropolitan Opera, began their new seasons recently, and they made an instructive contrast. Even though San Francisco's opener by tradition was actually in late summer, on Sept. 6, while the Met procrastinated until Monday night. 
 Before the contrasts, however, some similarities. Opening nights are an occasion for social display: social more than big-star glamour, although the Met is trying this year to pump up the glamour quotient by hiring an outside public relations firm to reach television and the gossip columnists. San Francisco opening nights have usually been shorter on glamour (except when Sharon Stone was still married to the executive editor of The San Francisco Chronicle) but longer on flamboyance, since along with the penguins sporting tuxedos in their boxes comes all manner of flamboyant display by the more flamboyant members of the community.
San Francisco's finest (or at least some of its richest; not much flamboyance here) partied in a big tent set incongruously in a parking lot but looking inside like a harem fantasy of Araby. The Met confined its post-opening gala diners to the (formerly Vilar) Grand Tier, with 69 tables around which New York's finest/richest were packed elbow to elbow.
Both companies need their patrons more than ever, since both, along with nearly every other major opera company in the United States, have suffered in the wake of terrorist jitters and the current recession or slow recovery or whatever it is. Donations are down, and so is attendance. Using a not entirely original metaphor, Joseph Volpe, the Met's general manager, suggested last season that during the week a cannon could be fired in the parterre and kill not a soul. He blamed the situation on a dearth of Japanese tourists, but surely it's more complicated than that.
What was instructive was how each company responded to the downturn. San Francisco had intended to open with a new production of Rimsky-Korsakov's "Coq d'Or." That wouldn't have fulfilled conventional wisdom, which is that high society likes its opening-night operas short and familiar. "Le Coq d'Or" is at least short and peppy and accessible, and would have answered to San Francisco's much-trumpeted desire, under the still-young regime of Pamela Rosenberg, to attract new audiences through boldness and innovation.
But budget crunching forced the cancellation of "Le Coq d'Or" and its replacement with Virgil Thomson and Gertrude Stein's "Mother of Us All." This was presented in the Christopher Alden production familiar to New York operagoers from Glimmerglass and the New York City Opera, although in San Francisco it was deftly recast (with Luana DeVol as a Susan B. Anthony both imperious and maternal) and lushly conducted by Donald Runnicles.
There are those of us who think of "The Mother of Us All" as the great American opera. That opinion was not shared by the dominant local music critic, Joshua Kosman of The Chronicle, or by a good portion of the company's monied patrons. Grumbling at the intermission and the dinner was loud, and the next day came threats of suspended donations and worse. All the fuss seemed odd for an opera that speaks to American themes in a quirky but eminently accessible American folk idiom. But opening-night audiences want their operas to be as smoothly palatable as their post-performance dinners.
On Monday night the Met gave them what they wanted, what they expected from the Met and more. The opera was that seeming chestnut, Verdi's "Traviata." But the singers, along with Valery Gergiev's fleet conducting, made the hoary old drama pulse with life.
In recent seasons the Met has shown signs of frisky spirit in its repertory and production choices, but the terror-recession nexus seems to be driving it back into its old, conservative ways: comfortable operas in comfortable productions with the best singers around. Of course there are still innovations forthcoming this season; Berlioz's "Benvenuto Cellini" and Halevy's "Juive" are among the new productions. But mostly it's tried and true, and on Monday night it was true indeed.
One hopes that not too much of the audience's evident rapture was sparked by Franco Zeffirelli's production, which combines handsome period decor with his trademark gigantism. But with endemic laments about a lost golden age of Verdi singing, Renee Fleming and the rest of the cast made a pretty persuasive counterargument.
For all her current fame, Ms. Fleming has had uneven success in her recent Met roles. Sometimes her singing sounds brittle or uneasy. (An Arabella two years ago comes to mind.) But one might have anticipated her success with Violetta from the way she attacked the "Libera me" from Verdi's Requiem at Carnegie Hall in April 2001. On Monday her line was firm, and her tone was beautiful, but what stood out was her passion: the way this basically demure and light-voiced soprano dug chestily into the notes.
There is something thrilling about a singer who stretches beyond her natural capacities without distorting her basic gifts: I still remember how Elisabeth Schwarzkopf tore into the role of Elisabeth in Wagner's "Tannhauser" in Vienna decades back. Ms. Fleming brought the same kind of intensity to "La Traviata."
Singing this intelligent and gifted and impassioned justifies the Met's conservatism. You can't rely on it all the time. But when it appears onstage, it creates a link back through generations of great singers to the composer's original inspiration. Monday's audience seemed to recognize it was in the presence of something special. Even on opening night.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dressed-up patrons mingle as the Metropolitan Opera's season opens. (Photo by Bill Cunningham/The New York Times)

 Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 31

LENGTH: 2725 words

HEADLINE: Treasures of the Russian Evolution 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD LOURIE; Richard Lourie is the author of "Sakharov: A Biography."

 BODY:
Russians are like New Yorkers. Their own world is so vast and fascinating that very little of what happens outside it can compete for their attention.
 For example, in November 1988 I was in Moscow at the time of the American presidential elections. The cold war was still on, the missiles were still aimed and Americans were still not sure what to make of Gorbachev. So you'd think who would be occupying the Oval Office for the next four years would be a matter of more than passing interest. But on Election Day no Russian I asked had heard anything. Finally I ducked into a hotel bar, but neither the clientele nor the bartender could tell me who had won. Overhearing me, an old cleaning woman pushing a wide broom across the floor looked back over her shoulder and said impassively: "Boosh." 
 But Russians are like New Yorkers in the exactly opposite sense as well. Both are open, expansive, susceptible to international influence. The Russians took Christianity from the Greek Orthodox Byzantines, the novel from Western Europe, Communism from a German Jew. Like any great living enterprise, Russia is a bundle of contradictions. No one put it better than Will Rogers: "Russia is a country that no matter what you say about it, it's true." 
The New York Public Library's exhibition "Russia Engages the World, 1453-1825" deals squarely with Russia's emergence from subjugation and obscurity to become a presence and a power in the world. Running from today through Jan. 31, the show also includes a companion book, a Web site, a lecture series, symposiums and a film series that features the classic "Alexander Nevsky" and the new cult film hit "Russian Ark," shot in the Hermitage in St. Petersburg in one continuous take.
But the centerpiece is the exhibition: tasteful, intelligent, lively, even a touch witty at times under the curators Edward Kasinec and Robert H. Davis Jr. of the library's Slavic and Baltic division and Prof. Cynthia Hyla Whittaker of Baruch College and the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. The show does not just explicate history; both its contents and sponsorship were shaped by history. The library's surprisingly diverse and copious Russian collection was amassed in the 150 years since the founding of the Astor Library.
Acquisition was particularly intense after the 1917 revolution, when the Bolshevik government was in sore need of ready money and placed little value on relics of the religious and imperialist past. Among those at odds with the Bolsheviks were the family of Boris Jordan, who fled to the United States. Mr. Jordan returned to Russia in the 1990's and to its hurly-burly capitalism. Fittingly, some of the fruits of his success have been used to pay for this exhibition.
"Russia Engages the World" makes ingenious use of the library's physical space by housing the show in two rooms. The first, the Sue and Edgar Wachenheim III Gallery, is small and enclosed, physically suggesting the Russia of the 15th century where few foreigners ventured and from where few travelers went forth to explore. The room, full of the beautiful a cappellas of Russian Orthodox liturgical music along with icons and bibles both hand-lettered and printed, is a reminder that in the Russia ruled by the Mongols from 1240 to 1500 it was the church that kept the nation's soul and culture alive.
This exhibition will provide pleasure and instruction to aficionados and the uninitiated alike, though some background knowledge of Russia before 1453 does help. Russia accepted Eastern Orthodox Christianity in 988 from Byzantium, largely because of political and economic advantages. Legend has it that Judaism and Islam were also considered but Islam was rejected because, as Grand Prince Vladimir put it: "The Russian cannot bear to think/of life devoid of all strong drink." (This section has an elegant, typically Russian drinking vessel called a kovsh that held a fearsome amount of liquor and was presumably not to be sipped.)
The earliest civilization, Kievan Russia, was vibrant and progressive; when a Kievan princess married King Philip of France, she proved the only literate member of the royal family and signed all France's state documents. Russia's happy childhood came to an end when Genghis Khan's Mongol horde arrived, sacking cities and celebrating victory by covering Russian princes with planks and feasting to their death cries.
Mongol rule was waning in 1453 but was not over when Constantinople fell to the Turks. The spiritual capital of Eastern Orthodoxy was in the hands of the Muslim enemy. During the reign of Ivan the Terrible a new doctrine would be promulgated, that of Moscow as the third Rome, the third and last capital of Christendom. Expansionism now had the highest justification. Ivan created the first secret police to help coerce reluctant principalities into the new aggressive Russia of which he became the first czar.
Russia was more visited now, the English among the first to penetrate the Slavic hinterlands. Some of the books on display, like that by Giles Fletcher, the English ambassador to Russia, "Of the Russe Common Wealth," and "The Reporte of a Bloudie and Terrible Massacre in the Citty of Mosco" by William Russell, remain valuable source materials to this day. Ivan took advantage of the English contacts to propose marriage to Queen Elizabeth. Nothing came of it, of course, but the marriage night of the Virgin Queen and the Terrible Czar might yet make great Monty Python material.
Among other oddities and rarities in this room is "A Brief History of Moscovia" by John Milton. This book, a mere compendium, the curators note, "leaves much to be desired." Curiously, centuries later, the great Soviet film director Sergei Eisenstein made "Alexander Nevsky" and choreographed the famous battle scene on the ice based on Milton's description of the war in heaven in "Paradise Lost."
Engravings were the photojournalism of an unimaginably slower time that was even slower in Muscovy than in Western Europe. It took a hundred years for Gutenberg's invention to reach Russia. Images of audiences with Ivan the Terrible and with the new dynasty of the Romanovs hardly differ at all. Travelers leaving Muscovy in the 16th century were glad to escape its gloom and gravity. And it is with a similar feeling of release that one leaves the enclosed world of the Wachenheim Gallery and enters the D. Samuel and Jeane H. Gottesman Exhibition Hall, which feels appropriately expansive and imperial.
At the entrance the visitor is arrested by a large copy of "The Sacrifice of Isaac" by Rembrandt. Abraham's hand has been stayed by an angel, his other hand still covers his son's face. The knife falls through the air. Violence has been averted, sacrifice sublimated. This picture was chosen, says Mr. Kasinec, one of the curators, because it was so "magnificently ecumenical." The work of a Dutch master bought by a Russian empress, Catherine the Great, from the Walpole collection of England, the original is now in the Hermitage. All the same, something bothered me about the choice, though I couldn't say exactly what.
No one hated medieval Muscovy with its superstitions and Kremlin intrigues more than Peter the Great. Three hundred years ago he founded a new city, St. Petersburg, named for his patron saint, to be both Russia's "window on the West" and an aperture through which it could fire cannon at its enemies, principally Sweden.
As the exhibition's lithographs show, the city was beautiful from the start, though there was always something paradoxical about it: a "Western" city modeled on Amsterdam and Venice that was the product of one man's command and the forced labor of thousands. It's also known as a city "built on bones." Some of the best early engravings of St. Petersburg were made by foreigners like John Augustus Atkinson while at the same time Moscow was being lovingly rendered by Francesco Camporesi of Bologna. A great deal of what we take as quintessentially Russian, from St. Basil's on Red Square to the Winter Palace, was designed by Italians and recorded by them in lithographs.
Russia was now an empire, Peter its first emperor and St. Petersburg its capital. After centuries of subjugation and stagnation, the Russians were exploring, conquering and annexing with a vengeance. All of Siberia fell to Russia, then Alaska. The conquest of those territories resulted in some of the most lovely and startling images in the exhibition, like those of the aborigines of Alaska and the South Sea Islands, which the Russians in their passion for expansion also reached.
The conquest of Siberia was relatively easy, but Russia soon bumped up against China, no pushover. Some of the exhibition's more intriguing images are of the fabled city, half Chinese (called Maimachen), half Russian (Kyakhta) on the Mongolian border, one of two where trade between the countries was allowed. As late as the 19th century, travelers were amazed by the place, passing from the Russian side of log houses and golden cupolas to the Chinese side of paper lanterns, pigtails and black silk clothing. This section of the exhibition includes not only objects like Chinese porcelain vases but also reflections of the Russia in Chinese and Japanese eyes. The show also contains equally rich cultural artifacts from Russia's intersection with Muslim lands and India.
What Peter began, Catherine completed. She linked their names forever on the base of the statue of Peter known as the Bronze Horseman: "To Peter I from Catherine II." An engraving by Jacobus van der Schley depicts the delivery of the 2,000-ton "Thunder Stone" for the base of the monument as Catherine looks on. Peter built the city, Catherine made it a glittering capital, buying the libraries of Diderot and Voltaire, with whom she corresponded, though she failed to entice Voltaire to her court.
Many artists were, however, attracted by St. Petersburg for its exotic splendor and as a market hungry for culture. Those German and French artists not only portrayed court life but also created invaluable images of the time -- dancing peasants and caviar vendors. (Caviar was a staple in those days, not a luxury.)
The exhibition quietly reminds us that not all was progressive in the realm of the "Adorable Catherine." When an English writer, William Coxe, described Russia's oppressive government and the nearly successful peasant uprising of 1773-74, his book was banned in Russia. The French Revolution of 1789 put the fear of free thought into Catherine. But she knew how to distract herself from her imperial anxieties. Her entourage included the sexual equivalent of a food-taster. One sly watercolor of guarded palace doors opens to show Catherine and Potemkin (he of the villages fame) exchanging more than opinions.
It was in the reign of Catherine's grandson, Alexander I, that Russia most fully engaged the world and its literature began its astounding flowering. Russian literature had a certain international quality from the start. The poet Mikhail Lermontov was the descendant of Scottish mercenaries, and Aleksandr Pushkin, Russia's Shakespeare, had African blood, spoke French at home and was taught Russian by his nanny.
In 1812, the year the Russians founded Fort Ross in Northern California, their easternmost point of expansion, they were attacked from the west by Napoleon. Illustrations of the time depict Napoleon as small, sinister and ridiculous as he watches Moscow go up in flames. Two years later Russia's Army entered Paris as conquerors. The army was composed of a great variety of peoples, as one of the exhibition's stronger images, that of a Kalmyk horseman, makes clear.
The Don Cossacks were so taken with Paris that upon their return to Russia they built their own Arc de Triomphe and Place de l'Etoile in their capital, Novocherkassk. The glory was short-lived. By 1825 Alexander I was dead, and in the interregnum Russian officers revolted, calling for constitutional monarchy and the end of serfdom. Russia was on the road to revolution.
Emerging from the show's engravings, maps, proclamations and frontispieces that somehow miraculously recreated nearly four centuries of Russia, I take another look at "The Sacrifice of Isaac," still wondering why it disturbs me. Then it comes to me. Russia is the land where the father kills the son! Both Ivan the Terrible and Peter the Great were directly involved in the slaying of their own sons, whom they suspected of treachery. (Stalin carried on the tradition by refusing to exchange a German general for his son, who was a P.O.W., saying, "I have no son.")
The march from the isolation of 1453 to the engagement of 1825 was epic and heroic. The price paid in blood, lives and suffering was immense, perhaps incommensurate. And the hope now for the sons and daughters of Russia is that all that is part of the past.

HEADLINE: Measuring Poverty 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 In "Who's Poor? Don't Ask the Census Bureau" (Op-Ed, Sept. 26), Jared Bernstein sends a helpful message about the woeful inadequacy of the United States definition of poverty. 
The adjustments he proposes would come much closer than we do now to measure the true, and shocking, poverty rate. 
 But even an adjusted measure, based on better budget studies, would fall short. Poverty is best measured in relation to the incomes of other Americans. Economic growth should translate into rising incomes across the income scale. A poverty definition that captured whether this was occurring, such as a percent of median income, would be a good beginning.

SUMNER M. ROSEN
JUDITH DAVIDOFF
New York, Sept. 29, 2003

HEADLINE: JOURNEYS; 
When 'Welcome' Doesn't Mean Junior

BYLINE:  By CHRISTINE EGAN and ANNA BAHNEY

 BODY:
NOT long after Gil and Liz Riviere checked into their richly appointed room at the Inn at Ocean's Edge near Camden, Me., the phone started ringing. But it wasn't housekeeping offering turn-down service. It was the front desk saying they would have to leave immediately and that a state trooper was coming to make sure they did. 
 Their offense: They had brought along their 21-month-old son to the "adults only" hotel. 
 Mr. Riviere, a mortgage broker in Waialua, Hawaii, and his wife, a teacher, were in Maine for the wedding of Ms. Riviere's sister two years ago. "I couldn't believe that an innkeeper could throw me out for having a child," Mr. Riviere said in a telephone interview. "We had paid for the room. We were going to use it." 
No one tracks just how many hotels have added "no children" policies in recent years. But the practice has become so common that the latest edition of the Zagat Survey of hotels, spas and resorts in the United States has a new category, "Children Not Recommended," with more than a dozen listings, from the Kenwood Inn near Sonoma, Calif., to the tiny Point resort on Upper Saranac Lake in New York. "If parents brought children, they'd be tiptoeing around ordering the kids not to touch this or that," said Tim Zagat, the co-publisher of the guides. "These probably aren't places where kids would feel comfortable."
The hotels say the adults-only policy is a way of maintaining their sophisticated atmosphere, with three-hour dinners and well-stocked wine cellars, and of cutting down on upkeep (no sticky handprints to clean up). Safety may also be an issue when there are swimming pools without fences and balconies with widely spaced balusters. 
Besides, the hotels say, the guests -- parents among them -- like it, too. "Seventy-five percent of our guests are New Yorkers looking to escape their kids," said Philip Wood, the chief operating officer of the Garrett Hotel Group, which owns both the Point and the nearby Lake Placid Lodge, which recently increased its minimum age from 12 to 14. 
That's fine with Sheila Addis, a Philadelphia singer and actress and the mother of two. While she is happy to take the children along on family vacations, when it comes to a quick getaway with her husband, Andy, she looks specifically for adult-friendly resorts. "I choose a property where there's not an overwhelming family scene," she said. "I don't mind one or two kids around -- as long as I'm not in charge of them."
Many of the hotels say that children wouldn't like them much, anyway. The Twin Farms resort in Barnard, Vt., has a 28,000-bottle wine cellar, art by Jim Dine and David Hockney and a spa offering facials and massages (all for $950 and up a night). "These kinds of things require an adult appreciation," said Beverly Matthews, the resort's vice president. "The Twin Farms experience would be somewhat wasted on children." The hotel does not allow guests under 18.
At the Soniat House in New Orleans (no children under 10), Frances Smith, an owner, said that the biggest issue is maintenance. When children were allowed, she said, the hotel staff found baby-food stains on the $1,000 bedspreads and crayon marks on the custom-made tablecloths. 
"A couple with a child once stayed five nights and paid $2,400 for their suite," Ms. Smith said. "After they checked out, we paid $3,000 to repaint the walls, all of which were covered with black fingerprint smudges."
But not all adults-only properties, are protecting the expensive artwork or Pratesi linens. At the trendy Post Ranch Inn in Big Sur, Calif., the bungalows resemble treehouses and the hotel offers seemingly child-friendly touches like nightly stargazing sessions and outdoor showers with big buckets of rainwater. But the hotel, which cantilevers 1,200 feet over the Pacific Ocean, says that its guests must be 18 or older.
"Our clients go to great lengths to leave their own children with someone else so that they can get away alone," said Nikki Baker Nusbaum, the assistant general manager. "To be able to see and hear someone else's children is a problem."
What happens when a couple turns up at a "no guests under 18" property with (surprise!) children in tow? Most hotels said that they would not go as far as the owners of the Inn at Ocean's Edge and actually evict anyone. But they won't exactly be welcomed, either. At the two Adirondack resorts, for instance, Mr. Wood said that offenders are encouraged to dine in their cabins. And when a family recently showed up at the Post Ranch Inn with a nanny and children, "they made a wise decision and canceled," said Mrs. Nusbaum, who added that the hotel refunded their money and found them a more family-friendly place nearby.
There is no federal law prohibiting discrimination against children at hotels. But some states like Maine take a dim view of age restrictions, said Patricia Ryan, the director of the Maine Human Rights Commission, which earlier this year ruled that there were reasonable grounds to believe that the Rivieres had been discriminated against by Ray and Marie Donner, the owners of the Inn at Ocean's Edge.
After an hour of discussions with the trooper and the Donners, Mr. Riviere said, he and his wife and son left the inn, forfeiting the $470 they had paid for the two nights they had booked. They have since filed suit against the inn in Maine Superior Court, Mr. Riviere said, and the case is still pending.
Mrs. Donner declined to comment on the incident.
For many hotels, the age limits are suggestions, not hard-and-fast rules. At the 1940's-modern Orbit In motel in Palm Springs, Calif., anyone under 21 is discouraged from checking in. "We have found that children can have a really serious negative impact on the serenity and the vibe here," said Patrick Richardson, the general manager. "Same goes for pets."
Still, he said, "there is a lot of gray area there -- we just try to dance around it as much as possible."
A "no children" policy may not be good for business, either, especially given the continuing travel industry slump, with occupancy rates running at just slightly over 60 percent this year in the United States. "In this day and age, I'm a little surprised that anyone has a no-kids policy," said John Fox, a senior vice president of PKF Consulting, a travel research group based in San Francisco. "With everyone trying to get any business, I'd think that they'd be open to any kind of guest." 
Economics can sometimes bring a little flexibility to no-children policies. For most of the year, Ballantines Original, a 1950's-era hotel in Palm Springs, is child-free. But in August, usually the desert resort's slowest month, David Smith, the owner, decided to open the hotel up to parents with children, and the 13 rooms sold out. (They still had cocktail hour, but by written request.)
Still, Mr. Smith is not contemplating changing the policy for the other 11 months of the year. "There are a lot of great hotels that have fantastic programs for kids," he said. "We don't discriminate. Just no kids."

HEADLINE: They Spent the Tax Rebate. Now What Will Consumers Do? 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
IF you send it, they will spend it.
 The third quarter was a phenomenal one for the American economy, which probably grew at an annual rate of above 5 percent. Corporate profits soared. 
 As that growth occurred, economic optimism grew both in this country and overseas. There was talk that the American engine was again pulling the world back into acceptable growth patterns. Even American business leaders began to seem a little more optimistic, with capital spending plans starting to edge up. Only the negative job market outlook put a shadow on the sunny picture.
Overlooked in some of the analysis at the time was the most obvious fact of all: checks totaling $13.7 billion were being mailed out by Uncle Sam to millions of families. The checks, for the child tax credit, did not go to the poorest Americans, a fact that outraged liberal legislators who learned of the details only after the bill passed. And they did not go to wealthier Americans, who would have been more likely to save the money anyway. They went to the parents in between the two groups.
Now comes the aftermath. The checks were in the hands of Americans in July and August, and clearly lifted spending in the back-to-school season. We don't have September numbers yet, but there was probably some stimulative effect then. But it's over now.
It was fun while it lasted. Personal income was growing slowly on a pretax basis, but after-tax disposable income rose more rapidly in July and August than at any time since early 2002, when tax cuts were also helping the economy along.
For business, that created a bonanza. Revenues leaped, but payrolls, the biggest part of most companies' expenses, stayed the same. A result was a surge in profits.
It would be nice to think the profit surge would lead to more investment and more hiring. There has been a gradual increase in capital spending, which was cut after the 1990's bubble burst. And there are reports of retailers stepping up Christmas orders after being favorably impressed by the back-to-school season. But hiring continues to lag and a big increase in Christmas orders could lead to a blue Christmas as retailers deal with excess inventory.
Another big tax cut seems unlikely, with the federal budget deficit ballooning and the costs of the Iraq occupation rising. So we may be left with what we had before: slow growth and an economy gradually recovering from the overinvestment of the bubble era, particularly in telecommunications and technology.
"The fading of the tax-cut impact means consumption growth will slow significantly in coming months," said Greg Jensen of Bridgewater Associates, an institutional money management firm. "There is some chance this decline will be muted if corporations start hiring, but there are no signs they are doing that yet. Without a significant increase in labor compensation, spending growth will decline significantly and we could be in the early stages of a renewed dip in the economy."
Such a dip need not be severe. The economic recovery lives on, but it will be a gradual one, not the rapid one that some saw in the summer numbers. Monetary policy is likely to remain easy for a long time to come, and as Robert J. Barbera, the chief economist of ITG/Hoenig, notes, the very strong productivity numbers, even after the bubble burst, are a good long-term sign. But the big engine of summer spending is gone, and the economic news may get worse before it gets better.

HEADLINE: Unemployment Claims Rose Last Week 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits rose last week, while factory orders fell sharply in August, the government said Thursday in reports showing a wobbly economic recovery. 
 The Labor Department said filings for state unemployment benefits rose by 13,000, to 399,000 in the week ended Saturday. The level was slightly above the expectations of Wall Street analysts. 
 The increase was partly attributed to Hurricane Isabel, which caused many claims-processing offices to close the previous week, preventing people from filing. 
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that factory orders dropped a larger-than-expected 0.8 percent in August, led by a 2.3 percent drop in transportation-related orders.
Orders for durable goods, which are items meant to last three or more years, were revised to a 1.1 percent decline in August from the 0.9 percent drop reported last week. 
In Thursday's factory report, orders for July were revised up slightly, to a 2.0 percent gain. 
The August decline was the first since April, when orders slid 2.6 percent, and was steeper than Wall Street forecasts for a 0.2 percent decline. 
Manufacturing has been among the sectors most affected by the sluggishness in the economy. Companies have been slow to invest in plants or equipment, or hire new workers, because they have excess production capacity. 
The manufacturing sector has given off conflicting signals about itshealth in recent weeks. The Federal Reserve said industrial production gained a smaller-than-expected 0.1 percent in August, while a closely watched monthly survey released on Wednesday by the Institute for Supply Management showed factory activity grew in September but at a slower pace. 
Referring to the Labor Department's payroll report scheduled for release on Friday, Gary Bigg, an economist with Banc of America Securities in New York, said: "Today's report continues to indicate that labor markets have stabilized. We expect to see a small decline of 20,000 in payrolls this Friday with the unemployment rate rising to 6.2 percent."

HEADLINE: M.T.A. to Include 19th Century Building in Downtown Transit Hub 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
The gateway to Lower Manhattan's 21st-century transit hub may be through the Renaissance Revival arches of an ornate 19th-century office tower.
 In planning the enormous Fulton Street Transit Center on Broadway, between Fulton and John Streets, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has agreed to preserve the 115-year-old Corbin Building at 11 John Street and, if it proves possible, incorporate it into the station. 
 "Our new transit center and downtown's historic architecture are both important to the future success of Lower Manhattan," Peter S. Kalikow, the authority's chairman, said yesterday in a statement. "So we are pleased to work with preservationists and the community to design the transit hub in a way that can preserve the Corbin Building." 
Besides saving a notably handsome work by the inventive architect Francis H. Kimball, the decision signals that historical structures will be seriously considered in downtown redevelopment. Preservationists and neighbors have worried that the push to rebuild Lower Manhattan might claim many of the smaller and older buildings that give the area its distinctive character.
Bernadette Castro, the state parks commissioner and historic preservation officer, called the Corbin Building an outstanding example of Renaissance Revival architecture and praised the M.T.A.'s effort "to recognize and incorporate it into the overall design" of the Fulton Street station.
The nine-story Corbin Building has stood in particularly high profile because it occupies part of the site on which the M.T.A. is planning a transit hub intended finally to bring some order to the ganglia of subway platforms serving the A, C, J, M, Z, 2, 3, 4 and 5 subway lines.
The Corbin Building was highlighted by the World Monuments Fund in its recently released list of the 100 most-endangered cultural heritage sites around the world. It was also identified as being at risk by a coalition called the Lower Manhattan Emergency Preservation Fund in its list of some 300 historical sites, most of which are unprotected by landmark status.
"It didn't take long to see Corbin as No. 1 on that list," said Robert B. Tierney, the chairman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission. Because it is not a landmark, he said, the question was how to save it.
Mr. Tierney said he decided to forgo the process of a formal landmark designation because of the time involved and the fact that the M.T.A., as a state agency, could demolish a structure with landmark status anyway.
Instead, he initiated discussions, negotiations and site visits that led up to a meeting about a month ago with Mr. Kalikow.
Working with Mr. Tierney and Ms. Castro and in doing its own research, the M.T.A. concluded that the Corbin Building was architecturally significant, William M. Wheeler, the agency's director of special project development and planning, said yesterday.
Only 20 feet wide on Broadway, but 160 feet long on John Street, the Corbin Building looks something like a Roman aqueduct with French Renaissance flourishes, arches over arches over arches. Though the ground floor has been badly altered, the upper floors, except for a chiropractor's sign, are remarkably intact. Under a sooty blanket are russet-colored bricks and terra cotta. Crouching griffins and grotesque masks greet visitors at the entrance.
The building's developer, Austin Corbin, also consolidated several insolvent rail lines into the Long Island Rail Road, a slight but intriguing transportation connection that preservationists emphasized to the M.T.A.
"The historic community has said to us that there are places all around the world where old and new have been mixed successfully," Mr. Wheeler said, "where you can balance meeting transportation needs in a modern way and at the same time respect the historic nature of the area you're working in.
"They're right."
The architect of the Fulton Street Transit Center is Nicholas Grimshaw & Partners, a British firm whose projects include the Waterloo International Terminal in London. The engineers are Ove Arup & Partners.
Mr. Wheeler said there was not yet a design for the Lower Manhattan transit center because the project is still going through an environmental impact study. He said that document should be complete this winter.
"We won't have a picture of the project until sometime next year," he said. 
But he added that it was possible that the Corbin Building might be incorporated into the transit center and not simply stand alongside it.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Corbin Building, at 11 John Street in Lower Manhattan, was listed by the World Monuments Fund as one of the 100 most-endangered cultural heritage sites in the world. At left is some of the ornate detailing on the building, designed by the architect Francis H. Kimball. (Photographs by John-Marshall Mantel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Home Sweet Home 

 BODY:
The Bush administration's tax experts are properly skeptical about an eye-popping new windfall Congress is trying to create for multinational American corporations that already escape taxes on billions of dollars they earn abroad.
 Legislation before the Senate Finance Committee would grant a supersweet tax amnesty to companies that agreed to bring their accumulated foreign profits back to the United States in the mere hope -- and without a firm guarantee -- that the money would be spent at home to create badly needed jobs. The proposal, part of an important global trade bill, would give the prodigals a special 5.25 percent tax rate on an estimated $400 billion in profits now sitting overseas because of a law that shelters money earned abroad if it stays abroad. This would be in contrast with the 35 percent rate theoretically paid by the domestic corporations fighting through hard times without overseas shelters. 
 The Treasury Department is rightly critical of this gilded welcome mat. It feeds the average taxpayer's perception that Capitol insiders too often and too easily circumvent the tax system's supposed fairness. And there is no certainty that the windfall would be spent as intended; indeed, Senator John Breaux's amendment to require that the money be reinvested in job-creating incentives was defeated by Republicans on the committee. He intends to offer it again in the floor debate, scoffing at proponents' insistence that the measure would provide a one-time-only tax holiday.
There is "no such thing," says Mr. Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat, envisioning an ongoing shelter-plus-forgiveness boon that would invite even more companies "to make their widgets overseas."
The larger bill, rated vital by most lawmakers, would replace the current tax breaks for exporters that the World Trade Organization has declared an illegal subsidy. The bill is needed to head off retaliatory tariffs. Honest taxpayers should demand that the shelter provision be amended to direct the windfall at job creation, not corporate enrichment.

HEADLINE: REVISED ADMISSION FOR HIGH SCHOOLS 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
New York City education officials have quietly instituted a new mandatory high school admissions policy that allows students this year to apply to as many as a dozen schools but will admit them to only one. 
 The changes are intended to re-engineer a system that for decades has given the city's brightest students multiple offers to attend some of the most popular schools while others ended up assigned to schools they never wanted. 
 Officials said their plan would ensure that far more students are accepted to one of their top choices, and that any student who applied to 12 was virtually guaranteed a seat in one of them. Some parents said they feared that it would limit choices, especially for better students.
The new system will not affect admissions at the six prestigious high schools that accept students based on an entrance exam, or at La Guardia High School, which judges applicants by audition or a portfolio of artwork. 
But admission to more than 200 other high schools will be decided by a computer using a complex formula intended to match student preferences with the schools they are qualified to attend. Schools will retain their admissions criteria, be it grades, an audition or simply a lottery, and will prepare a ranking of the students they want. Final assignments will be decided by computer. 
Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said in an interview yesterday that the new system, modeled on the method used to assign medical school graduates to residency programs, was the most efficient way of matching students to high schools while distributing opportunities as fairly as possible. 
"I have a chronic shortage of good high schools," Mr. Klein said. "I am trying to maximize what's good for 80,000 kids in the system. That's my obligation." 
He added, "The City of New York has gone to the model that is recognized by virtually any economist as the welfare-maximizing model." 
The city's Department of Education, which often holds news conferences to announce big changes, did not publicly announce the new admissions formula, which will determine placement of about 100,000 incoming ninth and tenth graders. 
Applications will be distributed to students in mid-October and must be returned by mid-November. In January, students will get a confirmation sheet, allowing them to adjust their choices. 
Under the old system, students received their admissions results in March, and students on waiting lists were given final decisions in April or May. This year, some students will get admission offers in March, along with acceptances to the exam schools. The remaining students will get results in April, and those that are still not matched to a school will be asked to submit another application. There will no longer be any waiting lists. 
Peter Kerr, a spokesman for Mr. Klein, said yesterday that officials felt that efforts to publicize the changes within schools and at recent high school fairs in Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island had adequately spread the news. 
City officials insisted that the new process would give students more choices than ever before. "They can now apply to up to 12 programs," said John Lee, executive director of student enrollment, planning and operations. "That's seven more than they were able to apply to last year." 
Some parents and guidance counselors who are just beginning to hear about the changes said they feared that the new system would restrict choice for many students, who have until now applied to high schools much in the way students apply to colleges. 
"You can choose to put 12 down, but when push comes to shove, they have placed you in just one school and you don't have a choice anymore," said Pamela Wheaton of InsideSchools.org, a Web site run by a nonprofit group, Advocates for Children.
Alvin E. Roth, a Harvard economist and one of the leading experts on such matching systems, said he agreed with the chancellor's assessment that the school system as a whole would benefit from the new admissions process, but, he said, some people were bound to be disappointed. 
"What I can't say is that it would be absolutely better for everyone," he said. "I think it's going to be better for many people. It's going to be better for the city. But I can't say that everyone will be better off because some people benefit from the private dealing, some people benefit from the inefficiencies."
The new application process is described in a high school directory that was distributed to students last month, Mr. Kerr said, and a flier answering questions about the program was sent home to parents by junior high school principals. 
"We felt that all these activities were sufficient and that it was not necessary to make a general announcement to the public because this was after all a narrow-cast announcement to eighth and some ninth graders and their parents," Mr. Kerr said.
Education officials pointed to a number of flaws in the old admissions process. In many cases, a high school would simply not consider applications from students who did not rank it as their first choice. 
Officials said that would cause some parents and children to list false preferences so as to remain in consideration by more schools. Under the new system, schools will not know how the applicants rank them. 
As a result, some schools will consider substantially more applicants, which will increase fairness but also increase the workload for those evaluating applications. Some schools already get thousands of applications for perhaps as few as 250 seats.
Another major problem with the old system, officials said, was that each year tens of thousands of 13- and 14-year-olds were subjected to painful rejections, or an agonizing process of hoping to be lifted from waiting lists.
"What I have seen too often is kids getting in nowhere and being absolutely, abjectly depressed and humiliated," said Ms. Wheaton of InsideSchools.org. "And I'm talking about kids who have 90 averages."
Professor Roth of Harvard, who attended Martin Van Buren High School in Queens, said that as a parent he would prefer the new admissions system. 
"I can now actually put down my first choice as my first choice," he said. The old system might force him to say to his child, "You are unlikely to get into your first choice and it's too risky to try," he said. 
He added that a system that asked him "to put down my true choices" and assured him of getting "the best one I can" would be "a lot better than maybe not putting down my choices and maybe never getting one."
Many parents said the problem was the shortage of good schools, and some complained yesterday that they found it difficult enough to come up with five schools where they would want to send their child and would not even try to find a dozen. 
"Being able to apply to 12 and only be accepted to one is not better from my perspective," said Roberta Segal-Sklar, whose daughter, Rachel, is an eighth grader at Middle School 54 on the Upper West Side.
After considering academic rigor, student diversity and extracurricular programs like sports and music, Ms. Segal-Sklar said her family was left with few options. "I don't have 12 choices in Manhattan," she said. "I don't have five choices in Manhattan." 
In some cases, education officials said, the old system allowed for back-room deals and special favors because principals could easily understate the number of seats available for incoming students. 
After most students had made their selection, officials said, the principals could then make the previously "hidden" seats available to children who might otherwise not have been accepted to that school.
Under the old rules, many students were assigned to their local zoned school, by default, which is an unpopular result in many neighborhoods. To avoid this, the new rules require that students actually apply to the zoned school. But in some neighborhoods, particularly in Queens and Staten Island, the local zoned schools remain popular. Officials said students in those neighborhoods would be assured a seat in their local school if they were not admitted elsewhere. 
Professor Roth said that creating the best admissions policy would require long-term research and understanding the flow of information about schools and choices. 
Many large school districts are grappling with similar problems and looking to matching models as a solution. But he said: "None of these guys have time to do careful surveys. They are always doing things at the last minute."

HEADLINE: In Iraq, Seeking Arms and Dollars 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The Iraq Reconstruction Bonanza" (editorial, Oct. 1) and "Who's Sordid Now?," by Paul Krugman (column, Sept. 30): 
 When an opportunity exists to provide employment for Americans in the worthy cause of helping a country in need (Iraq), why should that be dismissed as "profiteering" or something "sordid" because of a Republican connection to the companies involved? 
 The use of American companies, like Halliburton and Bechtel, in the rebuilding of Iraq is good for Iraqis and good for (the jobs of) Americans in general. The alleged excessive benefit to a few is in fact a benefit to many in need of jobs.

JEFF GIBSON
Henderson, Nev., Oct. 1, 2003
