HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
Builder of Upscale Homes Is Active in Several Cities

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
LAST February, Annette Mostato, an insurance investigator who works in Manhattan and had been commuting an hour and a half from her home in Carmel, N.Y., moved even farther out. Now she commutes two hours from her new two-bedroom town house in Danbury. "There's a price you have to pay for good living," she said. "I live alone, and it's wonderful to know I'm coming home at night to a country club and the birdies chirping."
 She is part of a growing army of nontraditional home buyers that the Ginsburg Development Company, based in Hawthorne, N.Y., caters to in luxurious fashion at prices below those charged in lower Fairfield County. Two years ago, it opened an office in Danbury to oversee its portfolio of eight Connecticut projects, worth $347 million, some completed, others in various stages of development. Its entry into Connecticut consisted of 32 single-family clustered homes in Georgetown called Redding Ridge, which sold out rapidly. 
 Summing up Ginsburg's marketing strategy, Joseph Novella, president of the Connecticut operations, said: "We have blown away the concept of town houses as an entry type of housing. Some of it still is, but the luxury town homes and luxury multifamily communities that we develop meet the requirements of well-to-do nontraditional buyers. They are coming from multimillion-dollar homes; they are singles, gays, empty nesters, active older adults -- in a range of lifestyles." 
A certain synergy is developing with the company's Westchester projects in part because of the favorable price differential of Fairfield homes compared with Westchester. A home that costs about $325,000 in Danbury, for instance, costs about $540,000 in Greenburgh, the company said. 
"We get a fair amount of people coming from one of our homes in Westchester to one in Connecticut," said Martin Ginsburg, president and chief operating officer. According to Tom Gissen, vice president of development, "last year Westchester led in numbers of units" under construction. "This year it will be Connecticut," he said.
In 2004, he said, the company's plans are for six projects in Westchester County with 1,008 units, and in Connecticut it expects to build seven developments with 1,038 units.
Woodland Hills, the 65-acre Danbury project where Ms. Mostato lives, is the largest. Of 252 town homes that will eventually be clustered on winding roads surrounded by dense forest, 157 units are occupied. Two-thirds of the 80 buildings will have four units per building and the rest have two, but each building is designed to look like one spacious semi-Victorian home with bay windows, porches and gables. 
"We like Danbury," said Mr. Ginsburg. "It was already going through downtown revitalization with a lot of improvements that other communities could look to. It's well located and has had a good, professional governmental presence."
It is also in the middle of a housing boom, which Mayor Mark Boughton welcomes. "Most of the development does not generate a lot of school children and overcrowded schools, and it does provide more ratable properties," he said.
Eight Woodland Hills models of 1,578 to 1,991 square feet, with two or three bedrooms, two and a half baths and one- or two-car garages, are priced in the low $300,000's to the low $400,000's, or $100,000 more than they initially cost a year ago. Six furnished models are replete with options and upgrades that elevate the price for some buyers by $30,000 to $100,000. The attractions include lofts that can be expanded or turned into additional rooms, standard 9-foot ceilings, stylish architecture, and landscaping that appears to have been there for years.
Monthly common charges of $192 cover maintenance of the landscaping, building exteriors and roads, and use of adult and children's outdoor pools, a tot lot and tennis court. An 8,000-square-foot clubhouse has a fitness center, basketball court, men's and women's lockers and showers, kitchen and large room for meetings and parties. 
Michael Timan, 50, who works in the Danbury office of PTM Technologies, a circuit board manufacturer based in Washington, D.C., and Betsy Taylor, 45, an import-export specialist at Vanderbilt Chemical in Norwalk, moved into a Woodland Hills town house in July 2002, after extricating themselves from a contract to buy a unit in another less attractive development. "In comparison to other builders," Mr. Timan said, "the quality of workmanship and materials and choice of options are the difference between night and day. The price point is a bit higher, but my property value has gone up dramatically." 
The 39-year-old development company, which was founded by two architects, the brothers Martin and Sam Ginsburg, has developed and built 4,000 homes. In addition, it has built mid- and high-rise apartments in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Florida as well as office buildings and commercial shopping centers. It also owns and manages 3,500 apartments in three states.
Besides cosseting the nontraditional buyer, the company is paying attention to the older generation. Upscale housing is to open in December at Liberty of Newtown, where one adult in the household must be 55 or older and no one 18 or younger may live there permanently. 
ON 37 wooded acres, 12 three-story buildings will hold 92 units, with six or eight units per building. Four models of about 2,000 to 2,300 square feet have twobedrooms, two and a half baths, two-car garages, a library, a den or both, and large storage areas off common hallways. Monthly charges of $306 cover use of the clubhouse, pool, fitness center and party room and maintenance of landscaping, roads, building exteriors plus common hallways. 
In Farmington, outside Hartford, Ginsburg Development has town approval to build 44 single-family detached homes for adults 55 and older called Chimney Hill. Clustered on 36 acres, the 2,200 to 3,200 square foot units will be priced from the low $500,000's to low $600,000's. Construction will begin as soon as state traffic commission and engineering permits are issued.
The most challenging of the current ventures is the $20 million redevelopment of the 1903 Goodwin Estate, a National Historic site in Hartford's West End, home to high government officials and professionals. The company has been working for months to repair heavy damage to the mansion from assaults by vandals and a fire in 1996. Facing Asylum Avenue on a 17-acre parcel, the property was given to the state by the Goodwins in 1953, then bought by the city for $1.9 million in 1989 as a temporary outpost of the University of Connecticut. The Ginsburgs acquired it in distressed condition last year for $409,500. 
A waiting list of 30 buyers includes a former speaker of the state House of Representatives and a number of physicians, lawyers and professors, eager to move into the development, believed to be the first luxury housing offered in Hartford in 20 years. The mansion will have seven uniquely designed flats and penthouses accessed by elevator, and 56 attached and semiattached town homes will be built on the property at prices of $300,000 to the mid-$500,000's. Delivery of the first units is scheduled for January. 
Plans have been approved in West Hartford for Quaker Green, where 64 new high-end town homes will be built on the former Talcott Junior High School property. The school itself will be redeveloped as 24 condominium units, a community meeting room and fitness center. An outdoor pool will also be installed. Prices are expected to be in the $200,000's to low $300,000's range. Construction is begin within two weeks, contingent on a decision by the Superior Court in Hartford on whether an objector to the development has standing to appeal the approvals. 
An unusual situation in Bloomfield arose when Cigna, which is gradually vacating its campus there, provided Ginsburg an opportunity to reconfigure some of the buildings into 158 single-family homes and duplex town houses on 72 acres. Most units will face the Arnold Palmer golf course that Cigna is developing. The housing is approved under Cigna's master plan and prices are expected to open in the mid-$500,000's. 
Plans for 103 typical Ginsburg town homes in Litchfield were reduced from 138 units to comply with the town's wishes, but it still denied the developer's applications for wetlands and site plan approval. Two appeals filed by the company in Litchfield Superior Court are pending. 
Like many buyers, Beth Chandler, an actress, and her husband, Sterling Rome, found Woodland Hills, the company's Danbury project, online. They like the mix of people, the sense of community, the golf outings, brunches, barbecues and holiday parties -- the urbanity. Former New Yorkers, they note that their common charges are the equivalent of monthly gym membership in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: For Rental Buildings, A Rising Market 

BYLINE:  By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
PERSPIRING in his shirt sleeves on an August afternoon, Frank Pecora directed the workers completing his new Italian restaurant in a building he bought on First Avenue near 73rd Street. It opened on Labor Day as the new Delizia, next door to the old Delizia, which was in space he had leased in 1983. 
 But Mr. Pecora, 52, is more than a restaurateur and no novice as a real-estate investor. With a brother and other family members, he owns 23 buildings in Manhattan, most of them purchased since 1990. This year he bought four of them, three in East Harlem. 
 They put him in the ranks of those who have been active buyers of modest-sized rental buildings lately, a group that includes everything from hands-on owner-managers like himself to nationally oriented real estate investment trusts. Most of the buildings have fewer than 60 apartments, and often they have commercial as well as residential space. 
The buying comes at a time of favorable interest rates, if weaker rent levels than owners had grown to expect before the events of Sept. 11. But lower rents have not fazed buyers. They complain about a paucity of offerings. In New York City, sales offerings are abundant mainly in hard times, when owners or their lenders are driven to unload inventory. 
Nevertheless, the buyers keep looking. The philosophy that drives them differs, but Mr. Pecora's is a familiar one. "For me, it's always a good time to buy when I have the money," he said. "I buy it and forget about it. In the long run it has no way to go but up."
Interviews with sales brokers and buyers themselves reveal that this underlying faith is common. Since total rents in regulated buildings are usually below market levels, some buyers are willing to forgo any return at all in the early years of their investment, in the conviction that higher rental income will eventually justify the prices they paid. Building improvements and other changes in operations or occupancy may be needed to bring this about.
With certain properties producing incomes far below their potential, some buyers have been willing to pay as much as 12 or 14 times the current rent roll in Manhattan. That is not the norm, however. The more typical range in recent sales in Manhattan is 9 to 12 times the annual rent, brokers and investors say.
To some extent these multiples reflect favorable mortgage-interest rates, about 5 percent in recent years, but 6 percent or a more lately. As interest rates decline, prices typically rise. 
The concept of "multiple of the rent roll" is a standard way of speaking of sale prices in rental buildings in New York City. It means, for example, that if the average rent is $1,000 a month in a 60-unit building -- or rent of $720,000 a year, assuming full collection and full occupancy -- the building would sell for $5.76 million at eight times the rent roll. At 10 times the rent roll the same building would sell for $7.2 million.
"It's counterintuitive," said Robert Knackal, a principal in the sales brokerage firm of Massey Knackal Realty Services. In general, he said, "The lower the rents the higher the upside, and the higher the upside the greater the multiple of price to rents."
Another factor in the current market, active buyers say, is that in recent years some wealthy individuals have found real estate more appealing than the stock market as a place to invest. "Equity financing is easy to come by," said Eric S. Margules, principal in Margules Properties, which has bought four Manhattan buildings in the last two years.
Massey Knackal was the broker in the sale of a portfolio of 12 West Side elevator buildings with 786 apartments this year. They sold for $109 million, or 11.28 times their total rents. These buildings had been held by the same family for 80 years, Mr. Knackal said, and because of long-term occupancies, about 40 percent were renting at less than half of what they would rent for if vacant. The new owner is Acquisition America L.L.C., in which Fred Shalom, president of Empire Management, is a principal.
"We bought them for the long term," Mr. Shalom said. "In 20 or 30 years down the road, they will be valuable."

Manhattan Sales Trends
Prices Have Risen For a Decade
The Massey Knackal firm keeps statistics on sales of multifamily buildings. One measurement has tracked sales of buildings under 100,000 square feet in Manhattan south of 96th Street, with 27,300 buildings in the survey, since 1989.
Using rolling averages over a 12-month period, the firm found that the average price rose to $465 a square foot in the 12 months that ended on June 30. The rise has been consistent since a low of $115 a square foot in 1993. 
Based of sales volume so far, the firm projects sales of 638 buildings this year, or 2.3 percent of the 27,300 buildings. This would be a rise from 510 sales last year.
Prices, too, have risen markedly, although thefigures suggest that since the year 2000 the averages have hovered within consistent ranges: for elevator buildings in Manhattan, between 10 and 12 times the rent roll; in Queens, between 8 and 10; and in Brooklyn, between 6 and 8.
Walk-up buildings have lower average multiples -- between 9 and 10 in Manhattan over the last three years, 7 to 9 in Queens and 5 to 7 in Brooklyn. Elevator buildings are more sought after, Mr. Knackal said, since buyers usually perceive a greater upside in them, so they will pay more.
The report has no information on the Bronx. One broker active in northern Manhattan and the Bronx, Robert Chambre of Chambre & Company, said multiples had risen to a range of 6 to 7.5 times the rent roll in the Bronx and to 7 to 8 times in Washington Heights.
The New York City Finance Department also has numbers. They show increases in values citywide. For example, in 2000 the average sale price of a residential unit in rental buildings with 4 to 10 apartments in all Manhattan was $217,200; last year the comparable figure was $223,000. In 1995 the figure was $86,000.
In these buildings the buyer is often planning to occupy one or more units, or otherwise alter the property for personal use. Since considerations other than pure investment are involved, the sale prices tend to be higher per unit than they are in larger buildings. Finance Department figures show, for example, that the average sale price per apartment in Manhattan buildings with 11 to 20 units last year was $115,600. In 1995 it was $40,800.
Other boroughs have also experienced increases in sale prices, but not of the magnitude of Manhattan's. In Queens, for example, the average price per apartment rose to $67,300 in 11-to-20-unit buildings last year, from $27,500 in 1995. In Brooklyn the comparable figures were $50,200 last year and $25,100 in 1995.
The buildings that are sold in any given year are only a tiny fraction of the whole inventory. There were only 106 sales last year of 11-to-20-unit buildings in Manhattan out of a total inventory of 5,500 such buildings. Citywide there are 10,000 such buildings; only 250 of them were sold.
None of these figures take commercial space into account in mixed-use buildings, so they somewhat distort true residential values.

Effect of Regulation
Building Owners Rely On Steady Rent Rises
Many sales are of buildings that are fully rent-regulated and are likely to remain so even after vacancies occur. Tenancy turnovers in units rented below their market value may run as low as 2 or 3 percent a year, and in very small buildings owners may wait years for any turnover at all.
What the buyers are mainly relying on, they report, is the steady rise in overall rents. Some believe these will average 6 to 7 percent a year over the next few years, taking both vacancies and lease renewals into account. This assumes that most of the apartments are currently renting well below vacancy value.
Buyers and brokers say that the opportunity to deregulate an apartment once it is vacated and the rent that a new tenant can legally be charged reaches $2,000 has little effect on the sales market. However, under a law passed this year, owners can achieve deregulation even if the owner is unable to get a rent that high.
When a regulated tenant moves out or dies, an owner may achieve a legal rent of $2,000 a month via the new-lease guideline increase, a vacancy allowance and the rent increase permitted for apartment improvements. If significant investment is needed to bring this about, it will be made if the owner believes the unit isactually worth that much on the market, or soon will be.
At one time after the enactment of the Rent Regulation and Reform Act by the State Legislature in 1993, regulations of the state Division of Housing and Community Renewal freed the apartment from regulation only if the incoming tenant actually paid $2,000 or more. But the law change allows deregulation even if the tenant pays what the rent-stabilization code calls a "preferential" rent below that amount. Owners are required to inform incoming tenants of the status of apartments that have become deregulated.
Mr. Knackal said that buyers of the buildings he sells in Manhattan often assume their rent rolls will increase by an average of 10 percent a year in the first few years of their ownership. This will come from a combination of guideline increases, lease renewals, vacancy rent increases, major capital improvements, more efficient operations and the new owner's ability to put a stop to illegal occupancy. "A lot depends on how neglectful the prior landlord was in running the property," Mr. Knackal said.
But the range in building values is wide. Robert Shapiro, vice president of Manhattan Property Investor Group L.L.C., said that in 13 deals in the last 16 months in which he was either a buyer or a seller prices ranged from 6 to 10 times the annual rent. The company is a short-term holder of properties, a deal maker whose buyers include Mr. Pecora. "The biggest factor in price is the location of the property," Mr. Shapiro said. 
Buyers also have to take into account the weakened rental market of the last three years. Many owners told of a need to reduce vacancy rents from the levels of three years ago. At the higher end of the market in particular, the vacancy rate has risen. It is about 5 percent now in apartments that rented for upward of $1,800 a month three years ago, estimated Nancy Packes, president of Halstead/Feathered Nest Leasing Consultant. It was about 2 percent then, she said. 
But, as Martin Newman, a recent buyer on the West Side and East Side, remarked, "The juice in the sales market is the low-rent apartments." 
Mr. Newman, who buys property in partnership with Nathan Halegua, owns 33 buildings with 700 apartments and 46 stores in Manhattan, almost all south of 96th Street. He said that over the last 18 months he has profitably resold 11 buildings that he acquired between August 1999 and January 2001. He was able to raise their rental income by an average of 30 to 35 percent through a combination of rerenting vacancies, evicting or making settlements with low-rent or illegal tenants, normal increases in stabilized rents and higher commercial rents. 
"There's a limit to how many buildings like this are available," Mr. Newman said. "And there's a limit to how much we would pay. I would not pay more than 10 times the gross rent -- maybe 11 in an elevator building."
Tenant turnover is not necessarily what creates value, he said. At 589-593 First Avenue, at 34th Street, purchased three years ago, there has been little turnover. But the rent roll has risen to $67,100 from $35,000 a month, largely because he was able to cancel three store leases and rewrite them, he said. The tenants stayed.
Another successful recent investment involved a property on the southwest corner of Second Avenue and St. Marks Place in the East Village -- three contiguous six-story walk-up buildings with 64 apartments and 11 stores, three of them little more than kiosks. The property was purchased for $7.6 million in 1998, when the total rents were $1.07 million. The buyers projected arent roll of $1.35 million in five years.
After five years, rents have actually reached $1.54 million, Mr. Newman said. The rise in residential rents was the principal reason in this instance. The turnover of 12 apartments, through a combination of deaths, buyouts and eviction, accounted for roughly half the growth in the residential portion of rent roll, which itself accounts for about half of total rental income.
"We still have tenants paying $300 a month and a couple are using toilets in the hall," Mr. Newman said. But once vacated and upgraded, a typical one-bedroom apartment will rent for $1,500 to $1,800 a month, he said.

Dealing With Tenants
In Shared Spaces, Owners' Opportunity
In Manhattan buildings, a significant percentage of newly arriving tenants are sharing, and the rents are coming from two, three or four individuals. Many sharers have gone into buildings owned by Baruch Singer and his partners. Mr. Singer, who operates 2,500 apartments in moderate-rent locations, says he has bought 20 buildings in the last three years. More than 40 percent of the new arrivals in his buildings are apartment sharers, he said. Of the rest, half are one-person households.
One recent purchase was the 55-unit building at 894 Riverside Drive, at 160th Street, near Columbia Presbyterian Hospital.
He paid 10 times the rent roll there, he said, because the average rent was much lower than what would normally be expected. He suspected a high degree of illegal activity.
"From my experience, 10 to 15 percent of the tenants are illegally renting out rooms," Mr. Singer said. It is not unusual for the tenant to be collecting $1,200 a month in an apartment in which the landlord is collecting $400, he said. On some occasions the tenant has "sold" the apartment and moved out. The new "tenant" pays the rent with money orders using the name of the tenant on the lease.
Mr. Singer's efforts to evict these tenants keep his lawyers in Housing Court, where he estimates he initiates about 100 actions a year. The outcome is mixed, he said. Some tenants leave, some settle and some are evicted.
But most buyers appear unwilling to pay prices predicated on their ability to gain possession of low-rent, possibly illegally occupied, apartments. There are other ways to add value. Mr. Margules, who owns 43 buildings with 800 apartments owned through various partnerships, said that there was little illegal occupancy in the buildings he had bought in the last two years, but considerable opportunity for adding value.
In one case he was able to negotiate a settlement of a harassment complaint against the former owner that was impeding rent collections, he said. In another case he was able to change the status of a single-room-occupancy building to a rent-stabilized building.
At 43 Clinton Street, on the Lower East Side, he bought a dilapidated 18-unit building with two stores four years ago. It had six vacancies and a need for $100,000 in structural and apartment improvements. Now he is able to get $1,500 a month for vacant one-bedroom apartments, usually from two sharing tenants, he said.
Many of the new owners know at least some of their tenants personally. But that is not likely to be the case with the executives of the Denver-based Apartment Investment Management Company, a publicly listed real estate investment trust known by the acronym Aimco, a recent buyer of residential property in Manhattan. 
Last March Aimco bought 311-313 East 73rd Street, two 1920's walk-ups with 35 apartments, a sale that pointed up the interest of a national real estate company even in a Class B property in the city if it is well located. Aimco's 2002 annual report says that its portfolio includes 1,800 properties with 318,000 housing units.
This year Aimco bought 181-199 Columbus Avenue, a strip of older buildings on the east side of the avenue between 68th and 69th Streets, with 12 stores and 88 walk-up apartments. The price was $37.5 million.
"When rents are down in a lot of cities," said Georgia J. Malone, who represented Aimco in both purchases, "national companies like New York properties, because the rents are stable in regulated buildings even when market rents weaken."
But competition from large buyers does not worry hands-on owners like Frank Pecora, the restaurant owner who buys small buildings in Manhattan. "I have an advantage on them," Mr. Pecora said. "I don't depend on contractors. I don't depend on other people. I depend on myself."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME; 
Sidewalk Liability Hits Home

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
UNTIL last month, the strip of concrete between the curb and the front of most commercial and multifamily residential buildings in New York City was essentially the city's turf and ultimately the city's problem. While property owners -- including co-op corporations and condominium associations -- have long been responsible for keeping the sidewalk in front of their buildings in good repair, the ultimate liability for injuries sustained in "slip and fall" cases has always rested with the city.
 That changed, however, on Sept. 15, when three amendments to the New York City Administrative Code took effect. The changes not only make property owners responsible for keeping the sidewalks that abut their properties "in a reasonably safe condition," but also require them to carry insurance to cover injuries sustained on those sidewalks and make them legally liable for monetary damages that arise from such injuries. 
 That, real estate lawyers say, is likely to have a significant impact on property owners throughout the city. "The new laws are legally sound and logical," said Paul F. Clark, a former assistant New York City corporation counsel who is now a partner in a Manhattan law firm. "But their provisions are unwieldy and leave lots of gaps that courts and lawyers are going to have to deal with over the next few years." 
Before Sept. 15, Mr. Clark said, property owners had a legal duty to maintain the sidewalks in front of their buildings in "safe repair" and "free of all snow and debris" even though the sidewalk itself was owned by the city. Notwithstanding that obligation, the city remained civilly liable for any damages sustained by people who were injured as the result of defects or unsafe conditions.
As a practical matter, the laws requiring the owners to keep their sidewalks clean and in good condition basically had no teeth. For example, Mr. Clark said, if there was a crack or other unsafe condition in a sidewalk in front of a building, the city would send a notice to the owner requiring him to address the problem. If the owner failed to do so, the city itself would make the repair and then bill the property owner for the cost of the repair.
"A lot of property owners would just sit back and let the city do it," Mr. Clark said. In addition to getting the repair done at a reasonable price, the property owner, by waiting for the city to take care of the problem, would avoid having to deal with private contractors, he said. "And if the owner was lucky, the city might never get around to billing him for the work."
A similar situation existed with regard to snow removal. "The building owners were legally responsible for snow removal, but the only real penalty was a fine," Mr. Clark said. Since the city was ultimately liable for injuries sustained by people who fell on a slippery sidewalk, he said, it was safer -- from a legal liability perspective -- for property owners to let nature take its course after a snowstorm. 
"If the owner tried to clear the sidewalk and did it negligently, he could be legally liable for someone's injuries," he said. "But if the owner did nothing at all, he might get a fine, but he wouldn't be responsible for damages. That would be the problem of the city."
Now, however, the city's problem is also the owner's problem. "The new laws," Mr. Clark said, "put the responsibility for the sidewalks in the hands of those who are in the best position to take care of them: the owners."
Basically, he said, the law requires property owners to "install, construct, reconstruct, repave, repair or replace" defective sidewalk components. The law also requires the owner to remove "snow, ice, dirt or other material from the sidewalk." (Mr. Clark noted that the law does not apply to one-, two- or three-family properties that are at least partially occupied by the owner and used exclusively for residential purposes.)
While many provisions of the new law basically mirror the current state of sidewalk law, one new provision is a dramatic departure from the status quo. "Property owners are now going to be the prime target of most slip-and-fall litigation in the city," said Eva Talel, a Manhattan co-op and condominium lawyer. "This is going to have an economic impact on the owners, and it's not going to be a positive one."
In addition to shifting the liability for damages directly onto property owners, the new laws also require building owners to carry liability insurance to cover such exposure.
Ms. Talel noted that most large co-op and condominium corporations and associations generally already have liability insurance coverage. However, she said, insurance companies that insure commercial buildings have been well aware that when the lawsuits start flying in New York City, the city itself was probably going to ante up for the damages. In the past three years, in fact, the city paid $189 million in such claims. With the owners -- and their insurers -- now primarily liable, that money will have to come from somewhere else.
"We're talking about increased insurance premiums and that means increased maintenance charges," Ms. Talel said, adding that when exposure increases, so do premiums, sometimes unexpectedly.
Moreover, she said, it is likely that carriers will require sidewalk repairs to be made as a condition of coverage, thereby imposing an additional expense on the property owner. "In the end, the money is ultimately going to come out of the shareholder's and unit owner's pockets," she said. 
Ms. Talel noted that while the new laws require building owners to carry liability insurance to cover "slip and fall" cases, they do not indicate just how much coverage there must be. Moreover, she said, the law does not specify what the penalty will be for failure to obtain such coverage. 
As a result, Ms. Talel said, it is possible that some owners may have too little coverage and others may not have any coverage at all. But, she said, the law allows the city to pay an injured person who obtains a judgment against a property owner up to $50,000 in uninsured medical expenses and then go after the property owner for reimbursement. 
Marc Luxemburg, a Manhattan lawyer who is also president of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums, said the change in the law would have far-reaching impact on co-op and condominium boards and their managing agents.
"What it means is that every time somebody slips and falls in front of your building, the building is going to get sued," he said. "And that means that managing agents, superintendents, doormen and board members are all going to end up being witnesses in litigation."
In addition, Mr. Luxemburg said, the change in the law now clearly puts the responsibility on boards to identify damaged sidewalks and then do something about the damage. "Now the board and the manager has to go and put out specifications for the job, hire a contractor and then make sure the job was done correctly," he said. 
Susan Lipp, legal editor of the Apartment Law Insider, a newsletter for property owners, agreed.
"Building owners should inspect their sidewalks at least once a month," Ms. Lipp said. "Look for any defects that might cause a hazard. And if a sidewalk slab rocks or seesaws or if one slab is higher than the one next to it, make a note of it, repair it and then document that the repair has been made."
Since property owners are now specifically liable for any injuries caused by a defective sidewalk, they should not wait for the city to identify problems and order the necessary repairs. "You have to keep track yourself," she said. "You have to be proactive."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; 
Irene Gallagher, John Podewils

 BODY:
Irene Brooke Gallagher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent E. Gallagher of Greenwich, Conn., was married last evening to John David Podewils, a son of Mr. and Mrs. 
Robert C. Podewils of Aiken, S.C. The Rev. Jeffrey H. Walker officiated at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, with the Rev. Charles H. Allen, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.
 The bride, 30, is a broker at Round Hill Partners, a real estate company in Greenwich of which her mother, Renee Gallagher, is the president. Her father is a managing director of Needham & Company in New York and the portfolio manager for the Needham Growth Fund and the Needham Small Cap Growth Fund. The bride graduated from Champlain College. 
 The bridegroom, 32, is a research analyst at Ferrell Capital Management in Greenwich. He graduated from the University of Vermont and received a master's in international economic policy from Columbia. His father, who is retired, worked in New York as the chief executive of Sogem, the United States subsidiary of Union Miniere, a Belgian metals trading firm.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Don't Overconsume Natural Resources

BYLINE:  By J. ALEX TARQUINIO

 BODY:
NATURAL resources mutual funds can be used in two distinctly different ways, analysts say. They can be short-term speculations by traders who think that commodity prices are ready to climb, or they can be a long-term hedge against inflation.
 "One goal is to get a little bit of pop in your portfolio, the same way another investor might use a limited portion of a technology fund or an emerging-markets fund," said Langdon Healy, an analyst at Morningstar Inc.who covers natural resources funds. "The other goal is, ironically, a conservative play." 
 Investors looking for an inflation hedge should choose a fund that is less concentrated in oil-and-gas stocks than the typical natural resources fund is now, he said. He cited the Jennison Natural Resources fund or the T. Rowe Price New Era fund.
Lewis J. Altfest, a financial planner in New York, listed several reasons for using the category to counter inflation: Most commodity prices tend to rise with inflation; a weaker dollar lifts the value of oil and base metals produced overseas; and some investors hoard precious metals if they think that inflation is getting out of hand.
Morningstar advises investors not to devote more than 5 to 10 percent of their portfolios to natural resources. But Mr. Altfest said he might put as much as 20 percent of a portfolio in natural resources if he expected an inflationary period. 
While the economy is not inflationary now, he said, the dollar's decline and spikes in commodity prices over the past year are classic early warning signs. He expects higher inflation to return sometime over the next two or three years, because "the rise in defense spending and tax cuts will by themselves result in inflation over time."
Even without runaway 1970's-style inflation, natural resources funds can smooth out the rough edges of a portfolio, Mr. Altfest said, because "natural resources zig when the portfolio zags." The fund category's movement differs significantly from that of the Standard & Poor's 500 index, according to Morningstar. 
After a year of rising energy prices, many funds with "natural resources" in their names are almost pure energy funds. State Street Research Global Resources, Putnam Global Natural Resources and Fidelity Advisor Natural Resources, among others, hold 75 percent to 85 percent of assets in energy, according to Morningstar. A fund manager who tends to diversify across natural resources might be 60 percent invested in energy today.
Even after considering the current lofty state of oil prices, energy investments are less risky today than some investors might think, said Karl E. Bandtel, manager of the Vanguard Energy fund. Over the past year, energy prices have risen faster than the shares of oil and natural gas producers, largely because many investors doubted that prices would stay high.
Over the long run, Mr. Bandtel tends to agree. He expects oil prices to fall over the next three to five years, possibly to $21 to $22 a barrel, roughly the 10-year average. Oil is now close to $30 a barrel. But even if oil drops, he said, certain stocks should do well.
FOR instance, he said he thought the market had underestimated the growth potential of two foreign oil companies that the fund owns. Total FinaElf, based in Paris, is poised to increase production in West Africa, Latin America and the North Sea, and Petrobras of Brazil is revving up production, just as the country's macroeconomic situation is improving, Mr. Bandtel said.
"We look for stocks with good value now and growth opportunities in terms of production," he said. 
Leigh R. Goehring, manager of the Jennison Natural Resources fund, is decidedly more bullish on energy stocks. He predicts that oil prices will remain high and that the gap between the commodity and stock prices will narrow over the next year. The portfolio he manages has a 60 percent weighting in energy stocks, which he says is high for him. Historically, energy stocks have accounted for 35 percent to 65 percent of the Jennison fund.
"Oil is drying up outside of OPEC and Russia," Mr. Goehring said. "Everywhere else, production growth is basically zero. This gives OPEC pricing power." Some of the biggest beneficiaries of this trend will be oil services companies, he said, citing BJ Services and Smith International, both of Houston.
Mr. Goehring is largely optimistic about commodities like base and precious metals, but not about forest products. "The world is still wrestling with a massive expansion in pulp-making capacity in the 1990's," he said, and demand will take a few years to catch up.
But Charles M. Ober, manager of the T. Rowe Price New Era fund, sees opportunity even when pulp prices are falling. The fund was introduced in 1969 to buy stocks that might do well during periods of inflation. Because it has a broader charter than many other natural resources funds, Mr. Ober is free to invest in companies that might benefit if commodity prices drop. 
"I'm less inclined to exit a sector completely," he said. All else being equal, low pulp prices should benefit paper companies, and falling natural gas prices should help fertilizer companies, because natural gas is a raw component of fertilizer, he said.
Mr. Ober said he was becoming relatively enthusiastic about base metals, because "the Chinese transition from an agrarian society to an industrial power will stimulate demand for more than 10 years." 
For example, when the Chinese used 17 percent of the world's copper last year, that amounted to only 2.9 pounds a person, compared with about 23.5 pounds per capita in Western Europe and Japan. 
Despite the fund managers' optimism, Mr. Altfest cautioned that investors should expect volatility in natural resources funds. These funds tend to be more erratic than general stock funds, he said, so anyone investing in them "had better be prepared to close their eyes to short-term fluctuations."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Higher Interest Rates Could Crimp These Muni Funds

BYLINE:  By ILANA POLYAK

 BODY:
FOR more than three years, leveraged closed-end municipal bond funds have had a good run, delivering year after year of double-digit gains. But that ride may be coming to an end.
 While the funds have continued to perform well this year, their momentum may be slowing. In the first nine months of 2003, leveraged closed-end muni funds returned 5.8 percent, according to Lipper Inc. In contrast, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index returned 14.7 percent, including dividends. But when interest rates move higher, as is expected in a recovery, the funds could be in for losses. 
 "When short-term rates go up, these funds get hit pretty hard," said Jeffrey Margolin, senior closed-end fund analyst at Ryan Beck & Company, a brokerage firm in New York. "And it happens very quickly."
In early September, Mr. Margolin downgraded several leveraged closed-end muni funds. Positive economic data, like faster growth in gross domestic product and improving equity prices, indicates that a turnaround is under way, Mr. Margolin said. When the economy heats up, interestrates generally move higher. In the first nine months this year, rates on 10-year Treasury notes rose to 3.95 percent percent from 3.82 percent. Additional increases could hurt the leveraged funds more than other bond funds.
Unlike the more common, open-end variety, closed-end funds issue a limited number of shares. These can trade at a premium or a discount to the funds' net asset value, depending on investor demand. Traditional open-end mutual funds can create as many shares as investors want to buy, and they can buy back shares that are redeemed. The share price and net asset value are always virtually the same. 
The impressive gains of closed-end leveraged muni funds have not been lost on shareholders. Since the beginning of 2001, when the Federal Reserve enacted the first of 13 rate cuts, 93 of the funds were started, according to Lipper. Investors put almost $14 billion into closed-end bond funds in the first six months of 2003 alone, accounting for nearly 10 percent of their overall bond assets.
There are now 225 closed-end municipal funds; 87 percent of these use leverage to amplify returns, according to Lipper. That could set the stage for a fall when interest rates move higher.
Thomas J. Herzfeld, president of Thomas J. Herzfeld Advisors, a Miami firm that specializes in closed-end funds, said, "The funds will have to reduce their dividends amid heavy selling pressure, and funds will flip over from trading at premiums to trading at discounts. 
"It's a very expensive lesson to shareholders," Mr. Herzfeld said.
The risk to leveraged funds is even greater. They have been borrowing money at low short-term rates and reinvesting the proceeds at higher long-term rates. The funds profit from the difference, adding it to the yield that is paid to shareholders as dividends. The strategy is well suited to an environment of low and falling interest rates, which is why it has been popular over much of the last three years.
The median dividend yield of a closed-end municipal bond fund that uses leverage was 6.55 percent at the end of the third quarter, compared with 3.91 percent for a fund that does not.
"It's a great strategy unless the market goes against them," said Donald L. Cassidy, a senior research analyst at Lipper.
Just as leverage magnifies gains, so, too, can it make losses more painful when rates start to rise. The funds typically borrow money at very short terms, usually 28 days; they can buy bonds that do not mature for 10 years or longer. So when rates rise, the funds must repay their debts at increasingly higher costs, while the income they receive is locked into an older, lower rate. To deal with that situation, they often cut the dividend. In addition, if long-term rates were to increase significantly, the value of the funds' investments would fall because bond prices move in the opposite direction of their yield.
"It's an example of the principle of 'there's no free lunch,' " Mr. Cassidy said. "If you are getting extra return, you are probably taking on extra risk."
Mr. Margolin added that a leveraged fund could fall by 50 percent more than one that does not use this strategy. "Clearly, there's more volatility in the leverage," he said.
The last time that funds faced such a predicament was in 1999, when the Fed was worried about an overheated economy and raised rates. As a group, closed-end leveraged muni funds fell by 18 percent. 
In 1994, the funds also declined, by 15.8 percent, amid rising rates. Open-end municipal funds that do not use leverage fell 5.7 percent. 
Many investors may not realize that similar losses may be in the offing, Mr. Margolin said. "A lot of the money that's gone into the funds lately is people looking for safety," he said. "They hear the words 'municipal bond fund' and they want to invest. They're not looking for risk."
Fund managers have some tools to dull the blow of a sharp climb in rates, but their prospectuses typically do not allow them to rein in leverage completely. Thomas Spalding, manager of several portfolios at Nuveen Investments in Chicago, said he planned to sell some longer-dated bonds and to buy shorter ones to bring down his funds' overall duration. But for the most part, the funds are at the mercy of the market. If rates go up, their performance suffers; if rates fall, they excel. 
"Deleveraging is not something that could be done without approval of the funds' board of directors," Mr. Spalding said, "and the only reason they would grant something like that is if there was a major change in the federal tax code or something."
DESPITE occasional blips, leveraged closed-end muni funds have proved to be sound investments over the long term. In fact, in the last decade, they have declined in value in just two calendar years, 1994 and 1999. 
"If you go through a whole cycle, you will have gotten the extra yield because of the leverage," Mr. Cassidy said. "But does the average individual investor have the staying power to stick with the funds when things get rough?"

HEADLINE: A Diaspora of Young Israelis, Decompressing 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER BLEYER

 BODY:
IN an art gallery converted from an auto repair shop in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a few dozen young people milled about in chic black eyeglasses and designer sneakers. They laughed and swirled wine in plastic cups. Some dipped into a Brie wheel. The artist whose opening was being celebrated, a lanky 26-year-old with disheveled hair and ponderous eyes, darted around explaining his installation.
 The recent scene was no different from many others in the neighborhood -- except that virtually everyone was chatting in Hebrew. The artist, Uri Aran, glanced around at his friends, an amalgam of Israeli designers, musicians, students and filmmakers who had recently emigrated. "A lot of us want a normal life, where we don't have to read in the newspaper about explosions and make phone calls to see if everyone's O.K.," he said. 
 His sister, Tal, 27, a dancer, moved to New York from their Jerusalem home four years ago. "I miss home," she said, "but it's too much right now." She shrugged. "I feel guilty about not being there. We're young, and we need to take care of ourselves." 
The Aran siblings and their friends are part of a subculture of young secular Israelis transplanted to New York's bohemian precincts. They have left behind political conflict, violence and a depressed economy.
At sleek bars like Pianos on the Lower East Side, at places like Cafe Orlin and Cafe Mogador on St. Marks Place in the East Village and at the Grand Cafe and Anytime, both in Williamsburg, they are as much purveyors as consumers of youth leisure.
"The East Village is so full of Israelis," said Mr. Aran, with a wry smile. "Sometimes you hear so much Hebrew you want to avoid it." Citywide, Israelis are not a new phenomenon. The Department of City Planning counted around 20,000 Israelis living here in 2000 as authorized residents, a number that has changed little from 1990. They have long been noticeable in parts of Queens and south Brooklyn, and to anyone hiring a moving company in Manhattan. (Los Angeles and Miami also have sizable Israeli populations.) There is no way to tell how many are here on student, artist or tourist visas.
"They're definitely here -- their impact is out there," said Ido Aharoni, a spokesman for the Israeli Consulate in New York. He observed that with many younger Israelis here on nonresident visas and a minor number here illegally, the population is difficult to quantify, though he estimates it in the tens of thousands.
Whatever their numbers, the image of young Israelis living in New York has apparently improved in their homeland.
"People who left in the 70's were considered losers who couldn't hack it," said Daniel Bailey, 34, an architectural welder and furniture designer, at Mr. Aran's opening. Back then, Mr. Bailey recalled, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin denounced Israelis who left as cowards. Even the Hebrew word for those who move away -- yordim -- translates as "those who descend," a phrase that connotes treason. "Now, things have changed," Mr. Bailey said. "Today, people say, 'You're so smart that you left.' "
Many expatriates wrestle with inner conflicts. "My friends and I worry that we are yordim," said Vardit Gross, 30, an administrator of a nonprofit arts organization, who, like many contemporaries, participated in the peace movement in the 1990's. But, she emphasized, "We're not just here because it's bad in Israel; we're here because it's good for now, and it's fun."
Daphna Mor left Tel Aviv seven years ago to study at the Boston Conservatory. After graduation she made a beeline to New York. "Boston is boring," she said. "We're used to living in a rough environment. New York is chaotic, dirty, people are rude -- just like home." 
Ms. Mor, 29, has woven a successful life as a musician and educator, with a band that plays at Joe's Pub in the East Village and the Knitting Factory in TriBeCa, and with regular gigs teaching at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She has a SoHo-born-and-bred boyfriend, a network of friends and a stream of Israeli guests crashing on her couch.
Ms. Mor's best friend, Yael Cohen, 31, joined her two years ago and now goes to a community college, does freelance interior design and works as a waitress at a Williamsburg haunt not far from where they both live. The two seem utterly at home, as if they have spent their entire lives sipping cappuccino and chain-smoking in cute Brooklyn cafes. On weekends, Ms. Mor says, "sometimes we don't even go into Manhattan." 
They talk on the phone nightly and have the keys to each other's apartments. Being in New York together makes them feel closer to home. Still, they are never far from "the situation," as the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is called. They served in the army, and their feelings about the conflict -- passionate, contradictory, exasperated -- illustrate how inseparable it is from their lives.
Ms. Mor grew up in an urban left-wing household, and, like Ms. Gross, is a former peace activist. "I'm disturbed on a daily basis with our struggle," she said intensely. "I love Israel because it's my home, but it's like a family -- sometimes you're ashamed of your parents' view."
Ms. Cohen grew up in an agricultural moshav in the Jordan Valley, in the West Bank. A classmate was killed in a terrorist attack, as were several other people there, she said. "Some things I just choose to avoid," she added. "It's too emotional. It's a tragedy, and I cannot deal with tragedies in my daily life." 
Ms. Cohen sounded despondent, but Ms. Mor is optimistic, at least about incremental change. Living in Tel Aviv, she hardly ever met Palestinians, she said. In New York, the people running the delicatessen below her Williamsburg apartment are Palestinian, and she and Ms. Cohen have become friends with them. "None of us talk about politics, but there's something so similar about us," Ms. Mor said. "Sometimes you have to go outside your country, I guess, to see the similarities."
Like many compatriots, they do not show hipness the way American counterparts do. Among those who stroll on Bedford Avenue in Williamsburg in trucker caps and white belts, they look a little less ironic and a little more European. But as is customary in the neighborhood, they're enjoying an extended adolescence, postponing what Ms. Cohen called "the dogma of life."
For Israeli women, she said, that means high school, the army, traveling for a year, college, getting married and having a baby, all by the age of 26 or so. "I needed more time," she said. "Maybe because I'm curious. Or immature."
At a trance party last month in Hell's Kitchen, hundreds of Israelis bounced around all night to a relentless beat, with a smattering of Japanese, Americans and Europeans among them.
"It's a lot of young, progressive-minded people who just want to live a peaceful life and have fun," said Shai Raban, 26, one of four D.J.'s working. A mix of Eastern mystic and downtown cool, Mr. Raban finished his army service three years ago and because of "bad vibes" in Israel came to New York, diving head first into a scene that closely resembled the one at home. "There's this whole Israeli trance community here -- D.J.'s, promoters, musicians," he said. "People come here for decompression."
Indeed, there's a trance party just about every weekend -- some celebrating Jewish holidays like Purim and Rosh Hashana (New Year), though not the more solemn Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, which begins tonight. 
The music -- a lush, psychedelic, upbeat genre of electronica -- attracts huge Israeli crowds, mostly in their early 20's. At 1 a.m. on a Friday, a line had formed outside a trance party in Chelsea. Friends welcomed each other with European-style kisses on two cheeks. They waited patiently, knowing that the main set -- two Israeli D.J.'s spinning for the first time in the United States -- would not start until 2 or 3 a.m.
Unlike the more artsy, sophisticated Israelis in Brooklyn, the trance crowd is younger, wilder and fresher from the army. They work as movers, retailers and waitresses. Some say they are here just to make money and are eager to go home. Others say they are here as a temporary stop on their global wanderings, planning to head to India or South America next. Still others say that they love it here and would like to stay.
Many say that they are having fun but just cannot imagine what the future holds -- a sentiment that does not necessarily change with age. 
Oren Kaplan, 37, who came in 1996, plays with Gogol Bordello, a band that has performed its mix of gypsy music, Russian punk and cabaret at the Whitney Museum. Mr. Kaplan has the chill, laconic demeanor that is de rigueur on the Lower East Side, where he lives. Sipping tea at a cafe, he perked up to consider whether he would ever return to live in Israel. "I would go back there one day when I'm older, if there's peace and quiet," he said. "The weather's great. The food is great. It's beautiful." He paused. "Or maybe Barcelona."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Deep-Value Investing, Now Back in Style

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE

 BODY:
THE investment procedure at First Eagle Funds sounds simple enough.
 As Jean-Marie Eveillard, the lead manager of First Eagle, the five-fund value boutique, explained, "We are trying to figure out what a somewhat knowledgeable buyer expecting a reasonable return would be willing to pay in cash -- no paper, please -- for the entire business." 
 If the price of the stock is a lot less, say 30 percent, it is a buy candidate.
Though the strategy proved ineffective during the technology boom of the late 1990's, it has been especially sound over the last three years. The bear market left plenty of bargains for Mr. Eveillard and his deputy, Charles de Vaulx, to choose from. 
The flagship First Eagle Global fund rose by 15.6 percent, annualized, during the five years through September, according to Morningstar, handily beating the 6.1 percent return of the average global equity fund.
First Eagle's Overseas and Gold funds show similar five-year outperformance. U.S. Value, which was introduced in September 2001, has also beaten its sector average comfortably during its short history.
Global, Gold and Overseas, which invests solely in foreign markets, have five-star ratings -- the highest -- from Morningstar and Standard & Poor's. U.S. Value, being somewhat new, is unrated by either company.
First Eagle Fund of America, the remaining offering of the fund family, is the only one that has done worse than other funds of its type. Morningstar and S.& P., however, still give it a respectable four-star rating. 
The fund is also the only one that is not managed by Mr. Eveillard and Mr. de Vaulx. Its managers are Harold Levy and David Cohen. The family of funds is owned by Arnhold & S. Bleichroeder Inc., the 200-year-old New York investment bank.
FIRST EAGLE'S managers covet companies and sectors that others avoid. From early 2000 until very recently, that was almost the entire stock market. At the bottom of the market's decline, they were finding value just about everywhere they looked.
"In the second half of 2002 and the first three months of 2003 we thought there were attractive valuations in the United States, Europe and Japan," Mr. Eveillard said. "We were buyers practically every day."
Now that the markets are recovering, the managers say, acquiring cheap companies is more challenging. 
"As prices for securities go up, the number of opportunities is reduced," said Mr. Eveillard, who has managed First Eagle Global since 1979.
That is particularly the case in the United States, which is "much more expensive than foreign markets," said Mr. de Vaulx, who began working for Mr. Eveillard in 1987, fresh out of business school. 
"As a result, we are struggling to find anything of decent value in the U.S., especially since we tend to focus on small and midcap stocks," Mr. de Vaulx said. "They lagged tremendously in the late 1990's and have recovered in the last three or four years."
Knowing what a company is worth is harder than it may seem. The French bank Societe Generale might have discovered this after it sold its American fund management arm, the Societe Generale Asset Management Corporation, to Bleichroeder. The acquisition included the Overseas, Global and Gold funds and the services of Mr. Eveillard and Mr. de Vaulx. 
The sale was completed in January 2000. That was just two months before global stock markets topped and the popularity of momentum investing -- buying more of whatever was rising fastest -- ended abruptly on Wall Street and Main Street, and value investing came back into vogue.
Mr. Eveillard said: "Societe Generale decided they didn't love me anymore, so they decided to sell me and my operation. In the late 90's, in less than three years, shareholders in our Global and Overseas funds abandoned us. One said I was half senile."
Mr. Eveillard conceded that shareholders had reason to be disillusioned. "I'm a one-trick pony," he said. "Between the spring of 1995 and the spring of 2000, we made money for shareholders in our funds, but less -- sometimes much less -- than people who were willing to buy new-economy stocks." 
Gregg Wolper, an analyst at Morningstar who covers First Eagle, said that this strict adherence to a deep-value style would leave the funds prone to weakness again should growth stocks enjoy another run of lopsided outperformance. "The managers would not adjust their approach to try to fit in," he said.
But over the long haul, First Eagle's hit-them-where-they-ain't strategy has done more good than harm, Mr. Wolper said. The managers have achieved success by seeking securities that are out of favor "and being willing to wait a long time for their market values to rise," he said.
As other investors were deserting Japan, First Eagle was buying stocks of insurers like Mitsui-Sumitomo. 
Calling insurers "disguised investment companies," Mr. Eveillard said their core business was not appealing but share prices were so low that buyers could pick up the companies' ample investment portfolios at deep discounts.
The funds also own Japanese drug stocks like Ono Pharmaceuticals, which are much cheaper than their American equivalents, he said. Another holding, one of the largest in the global and overseas funds, is Shimano Inc., a Japanese maker of high-end bicycle parts.
The funds own several stocks in Korea, where the managers "went back in last year when the market fell back sharply," Mr. de Vaulx said. Among its holdings there are Samsung Electronics, the office furniture maker Fursys and Lotte Confectionery.
One of Mr. Eveillard's favorite European stocks is Robertet, a French producer of flavors and fragrances. 
"We figure the business is conservatively worth 150 euros per share and the stock is selling at 90," he said. "We already have a fat profit, but as long as we believe the stock is worth 150, we'll continue to hold it."
First Eagle's American stocks include Hawaiian Electric Industries, a power generator that "happens to own a savings bank," Mr. de Vaulx said. The stock, which recently yielded nearly 6 percent, has been depressed by disdain for utilities among investors, who seem to be ignoring the fact that much of the business is tied up in the bank. 
When Mr. Eveillard describes Rayonier Inc., an American forest products concern, it is hard at first to see why it is First Eagle Global's largest holding. "The processing of wood into pulp and paper is a terrible business, very capital intensive," he explained. 
What makes the company appealing, he said, is that "Rayonier moved away substantially from processing and became almost entirely focused on ownership of timberland," a much more lucrative enterprise.
"You could see a year or two ago, when the stock was lower, that the market failed to consider that Rayonier was almost entirely in timber ownership," Mr. Eveillard said. The share price valued the land at nearly a 30 percent discount, he said.
MR. EVEILLARD is no slave to investment fashion, but time is another matter. He is 63 and due to retire in January 2005, although he will stay as a consultant for two additional years. 
Mr. de Vaulx will take over, and both managers say that the funds will continue to be run according to the same philosophy -- but not necessarily at the same speed.
"Stocks do not stay cheap as long as they used to, so I guess I would have a tendency to acquire positions faster than Jean-Marie would," Mr. de Vaulx said. "But he and I happen to have the same aversion to risk. We're not gamblers. We hate the idea of losing money."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
For 3 Funds, Fireworks in Small Stocks

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
FUNDS that focused on stocks of small companies generally did well in the third quarter, and those that held small, fast-growing companies did particularly well.
 Managers of three of the top-performing funds talked about the reasons for their strong performance and about their expectations for the stock market. 

Risk Was Rewarded
Strong sales growth among its portfolio companies helped the $105 million Henlopen fund, up 23.8 percent, take first place for the quarter.
"We look for companies with growing revenues," Michael L. Hershey, the fund president, said from his office in Kennett Square, Pa. "Growth starts on the top line." The fund is named for a cape on Delaware Bay where Mr. Hershey has a vacation home.
His investing strategy did not change during the third quarter, he said, but after the market lows in March, investors willing to take more risk began to be rewarded.
Among his winners was Igen International, a biotechnology company in Gaithersburg, Md. Its stock advanced 83.8 percent in the quarter. On July 25, Igen and Roche Holding jointly announced that they had reached a definitive agreement to resolve a long-running dispute over the rights to Origen, Igen's electrochemiluminescence technology, which is used by Roche's diagnostics division. In electrochemiluminescence, certain chemical compounds emit light when electrochemically stimulated.
Igen's share price surged on the day of the announcement, closing at $59.25, up from $37.20 the day before. Before the settlement was announced, Igen was losing money, much of it because of legal expenses associated with the lawsuit, Mr. Hershey said. The Federal Trade Commission approved the merger last week, and the deal is expected to close by year-end, Mr. Hershey said.
Another biotechnology company, Applied Molecular Evolution, in San Diego, also benefited from the economic turnaround, Mr. Hershey said. Its share price climbed 107.8 percent in the quarter. The company has a robust product pipeline, he said, and works with bigger companies like Medimmune, which uses Applied Molecular's protein immunization technology to improve some drugs.
The fund also made money with the WSFS Financial Corporation of Wilmington, Del., the parent company of the Wilmington Savings Fund Society, which operates 25 retail banking offices. Its shares gained 11 percent in the quarter.
The company's strong share price is "recognition of what has been hard work by the bank's management over the last few years," Mr. Hershey said. Another factor was its sale of a big portfolio of reverse mortgages, which "put real value directly on the balance sheet and into the price of the stock," he said.
He expects the economy to continue improving gradually. "I think interest rates will stay low and we'll see opportunities for growth ahead," he said.

Explosive Growth Sought
Small, rapidly growing companies helped the $230 million Oberweis Emerging Growth fund secure fourth place among diversified stock funds in the third quarter, with a 19.5 percent return.
"We identify high-growth, small-capitalization companies that still trade at reasonable valuations and that are in explosive stages of their growth cycle," said James W. Oberweis, 29, the fund's lead manager.
He buys companies with market caps below $1 billion that have at least 30 percent average annual growth in revenue and per-share earnings. The fund holds about 75 stocks.
"We're at a point in time that's exceptionally favorable for small growth stocks," Mr. Oberweis said from his office in North Aurora, Ill. "The outlook for the economy is a bit more upbeat than earlier this year and certainly all of last year, and smaller companies typically adapt most quickly to economic changes to take advantage of an upswing."
One of the fund's strongest performers was Switchboard, in Westborough, Mass., which provides Internet yellow pages and other online directories. Its share price rose 151.4 percent during the quarter. "Many Internet companies have gotten beaten up because they're unprofitable," Mr. Oberweis said. Switchboard turned profitable in the second quarter, he said, and "the stock took off as people saw that the business model really worked."
He also made money with Abaxis Inc., in Union City, Calif. Its stock price gained 115.2 percent. The company sells blood analysis systems to for veterinary and human use. 
Another winner was Bradley Pharmaceuticals, in Fairfield, N.J. The company's stock price rose 65.2 percent, driven by strong sales of its Carmol prescription skin lotions. The company reported 81 percent growth in earnings per share and 75 percent growth in sales for the three months ended June 30, Mr. Oberweis said.
He expects that stock prices of small growth companies will be less explosive in the months ahead. "Certainly, valuations are not as cheap as they were in the beginning of the year," he said. "But we're still optimistic that small growth companies will do well over the next two to three years as the period of the recession gives way to economic growth," he said.

Environmental Screening
Smaller stocks also drove the returns of the $73 million Winslow Green Growth fund, which returned 18.1 percent and finished in seventh place. Its manager, Jackson W. Robinson, 61, said the fund bought what he considered to be environmentally responsible businesses.
"Our green screens eliminate companies that have environmentally related issues, which ultimately can be disastrous for balance sheets," he said from his office in Boston. The fund will not buy companies involved with things like asbestos, tobacco and percolate, a chemical used in rocket fuel, he said.
One of his top performers has been the Polymedica Corporation, based in Woburn, Mass., a medical products and services company. He began buying shares in September 2001, after the stock price fell to about $15 from nearly $50 because of news of investigations into its accounting practices by the Department of Justice. Last quarter, the Securities and Exchange Commission closed its investigation, finding that the company's accounting practices were appropriate. Its share price was up 15.6 percent in the quarter.
Another winner was Flamel Technologies, a French biotechnology company whose shares trade as American depository receipts on Nasdaq. Management recently announced a contract with Bristol-Myers Squibb for a timed-release system for delivering insulin to diabetics. Mr. Robinson called the deal "a very big win for the company." Its timed-release drug technology is unique, he added, and has other potential applications. The share price climbed 150.6 percent.
Mr. Robinson also holds shares of Chiquita Brands International, based in Cincinnati, which emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization in March 2002 with a new chief executive, a strong balance sheet and, in Mr. Robinson's opinion, greater sensitivity to the environment. Chiquita's shares gained 22.1 percent in the quarter. After selling its noncore businesses, the company reported record earnings for the second quarter.
It is planning to grow, Mr. Robinson said, by using its well-known brand name to introduce a fresh-fruit product line in what is a $1 billion market growing at 20 percent annually. And it is considering a line of Chiquita Smoothies juice drinks, he said. Based on his 2004 earnings estimate of $2.50 a share, he said, the company's stock price could reach $50 in the next 12 to 18 months.
Mr. Robinson said that a lot of money that flowed out of small growth stocks into value stocks during the last three years is now returning. Over all, he expects companies that can meet their earnings targets to perform strongly.
