HEADLINE: The Untouchables 

BYLINE:  By John Colapinto; John Colapinto, a contributing editor to Rolling Stone, is the author of "As Nature Made Him" and "About the Author," a novel. His last article for the magazine was about young Republicans.

 BODY:
Last May, Mayor Michael Bloomberg, facing an almost $4 billion budget gap, made the difficult decision to close six New York City firehouses -- including one in Williamsburg, Brooklyn: Engine Company 212, popularly known as the People's Firehouse. Neighborhood residents refused to take it lying down. By the fall, some three months after the closings -- and long after demonstrations at the five other closed houses (in Harlem, Brooklyn and Queens) had faded -- the protest at Engine Company 212 was still going strong. Firefighters and local residents draped the facade of the two-story, redbrick building on a scrubby section of Wythe Avenue with banners reading "fire cuts kill" and "budgets slashed, brooklyn burned." In a tent on the sidewalk in front of the firehouse, volunteers from the neighborhood took turns sleeping each night. By day, they collected signatures on a petition, determined to get their firehouse reopened. 
 Their goal was not as quixotic as it might seem. In New York City politics there are few issues more volatile than firehouse closings -- especially after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, when the Fire Department lost 343 men and New York City firefighters became known around the world as America's Heroes. But even before that tragedy, politicians knew that closing a firehouse was not to be done lightly. It is, as one source in the Bloomberg administration says, "a third rail for politicians -- touch it and expect to do damage to yourself." The People's Firehouse protesters knew this from experience. 
 Back in 1975, Mayor Abraham Beame also closed Engine Company 212 -- or tried to. Before the building was actually shuttered, a local factory worker named Adam Veneski roused the north-side neighborhood by bullhorn, then he, his wife, his 11-year-old son, Paul, and others stormed the building and occupied it for 18 months. Beame was hammered by regular news stories about the little engine company that wouldn't die. After Beame lost his re-election bid, his successor, Ed Koch, reopened Engine Company 212 and the legend of "the People's Firehouse" was born. 
Adam Veneski died a few years ago, but Paul, now 39, is carrying on the fight for Engine Company 212 today. On the morning of its most recent closing, Veneski sneaked into the firehouse basement and chained himself to the fire truck. Since then, he has put himself in front of a lot of TV cameras and microphones, vowing that he will get the firehouse reopened. On the day I recently visited Engine Company 212, Veneski wasn't there; he was at work, but he had fine spokespersons in the three protesters camped out on folding chairs in front of the building.
"I'm going to be out here as long as it takes," said Leonides Reyes, a 40-something unemployed man whose hair was wrapped in an American-flag bandanna. "I've lived in this neighborhood all my life, and I'm going to fight for our firehouse."
Leonore Russo, a grandmotherly woman from the neighborhood, chimed in, "They're using Gestapo tactics." She was referring to a recent raid by police in riot gear, who seized the fire truck from the building while protesters tried to fight them off. "We're going to get our engine back." 
"I was born after the Second World War," said the third protester, Del Teague, an attorney who has lived in Williamsburg for 25 years. "It was ingrained in me how sacred democracy is. I lived through a time when people said, 'Don't ever, ever accept a leader who gets up there and says, "It doesn't matter what you think; just do what I say." ' Bloomberg did that when he closed this firehouse." 
You have to admire the passion of the People's Firehouse advocates -- fighting against a budget cut that, they're convinced, has made their lives and property less secure. 
But there are some stubborn realities that make the story of the People's Firehouse, with its stirring overtones of dynastic struggle against a bullying and autocratic City Hall, a little difficult to conform to the movie-of-the-week treatment it begs for. Chief among these is that Engine Company 212 has been among the city's most inactive firehouses. At the time of its closing, it ranked near the very bottom in every category of measurement for activity of the city's then 203 engine companies, including number of calls to structural fires, medical emergencies and total number of runs. Nor can it plausibly be argued that removing Engine Company 212 has left north-side Williamsburg without fire services. Another engine company is situated within blocks of the closed house, and two others within three miles. According to the Fire Department's preclosing computer analysis and to real-time statistics gathered in the two months after the closings, those companies are able to respond, on average, in under four and a half minutes to any location within the area that Engine Company 212 had covered. This response time is well within the city average of 4 minutes 50 seconds, and one that, even after the removal of Engine Company 212, makes the residents of Williamsburg's north side, statistically, among the best-protected of city residents. Which goes some way toward explaining why Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta says that the closing of Engine Company 212 was a "no-brainer." At a time of dire budget crisis, it made no sense to keep open an almost moribund firehouse that was costing the city $1.2 million a year to staff and operate. 
But Mayor Bloomberg's decision to close the six firehouses sheds light on a little-remarked-upon fact about the New York City Fire Department as a whole. Namely, that today it rarely fights fires. Indeed, Deputy Mayor for Operations Marc Shaw told a budget panel last spring that firefighters spend only 5 percent of their time performing the skill for which they are so highly trained and so widely lionized. The reason for the vast reduction in firefighting is obvious enough: New York City isn't burning the way it used to -- especially when compared with what firefighters call the War Years, that extraordinary period from the late 1960's to mid-1970's when a confluence of social and cultural factors made New York City a kind of perfect storm for fires. Arson-for-profit spiked as the city slid from recession into bankruptcy, and desperate business owners, trying to save themselves from financial ruin, torched their own premises for the insurance money. Laws stipulating that welfare recipients could escape their grim city-subsidized dwellings in case of fire led to a rash of apartment arsons (one veteran firefighter recalls arriving at an apartment fire only to find the occupant out front on the street with bags packed and ready to go). Add to this a heroin epidemic that had junkies nodding off, cigarettes in hand, all over the city and a roiling climate of social protest ("Burn, baby, burn" was a favorite slogan of the day), and you had a metropolis that was, literally, going up in flames. Firefighters in the worst-hit neighborhoods -- the South Bronx, Harlem and Bedford-Stuyvesant -- routinely fought three or four major blazes a night. So difficult was it for the Fire Department to keep up with the conflagrations that they resorted to throwing up two temporary firehouses in corrugated metal Quonset huts on vacant lots and doubling up engine companies in single firehouses. 
Things are completely different today. The number of structural fires in New York has dropped to a rate unheard of since the 1950's; last year, the city had the lowest number of civilian fire fatalities in 75 years -- statistics that reflect not only a more pacific social climate, but also improved building codes and construction over the last 30 years: fire-retardant materials and automatic sprinkler systems are the norm in buildings today. Large demographic shifts have further rendered the city's firehouses less active than when many of them were built 75 to 130 years ago. Back then, the siting of firehouses was dictated by the limited firefighting technology of the day. Engines were pulled by horse-drawn carts and fires were doused with water that was hand-pumped, so firehouses needed to be close together to keep response times down. But what was effective siting for a city of the postindustrial revolution is considerably less so for a city of the 21st century.
Given these realities, and the size of the city's yawning budget hole, Mayor Bloomberg decided that cuts to the Fire Department were unavoidable. Everyone in his administration knew how tricky it would be. New York City mayors have struggled with theproblem of declining productivity in the Fire Department ever since the mid-1970's, when fires started to decline and the War Years began to come to a close. Mayor Beame's standoff with the protesters at Engine Company 212 was only the first in a series of clashes over the shuttering of a firehouse, but it stood as a potent warning to every city politician who came after. When Mayor Ed Koch closed Engine Company 232 in Brooklyn, he ordered his men to figure out a way to, as one former aide in the Koch administration puts it, "avoid another People's Firehouse." The solution they arrived at was effective, if unsubtle. On Super Bowl Sunday, 1988, the Fire Department issued a false call to Engine Company 232, summoning them to cover for another firehouse. When the firefighters returned to their building, they found guards out front and a padlock on the door. Koch had avoided a showdown with activists, but the tactic backfired. More than 4,000 firefighters marched across the Brooklyn Bridge chanting obscenities at him.
Koch's successor, David Dinkins, was also hurt by a firehouse closing. In January 1991, he shuttered Engine Company 294 in Richmond Hill, Queens, and then suffered the nightmare every politician who closes a firehouse fears. Within days, a fire swept through a nearby home, killing two men. Two years later, Rudolph Giuliani resurrected the incident when he ran against Dinkins for mayor, assailing Dinkins repeatedly over the tragedy and making the reopening of Engine Company 294 a campaign promise. (Giuliani did reopen the firehouse after he defeated Dinkins.)
In the weeks leading up to the recent closings, it quickly became clear that Mayor Bloomberg was not going to avoid the problems of his predecessors. Rallies were held at the six firehouses, and City Council members in those districts leveled a lawsuit to block the closings; it was denied. Joining in the chorus of voices were the two firefighters' unions. Pete Gorman, president of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association, insisted that the firehouses were not redundant, that despite fewer fires, other calls -- stuck elevators, gas leaks and emergency response -- were increasing. Steve Cassidy, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, devised a plan for corporate sponsorship of the houses slated for closure. "I spoke with several corporations who were absolutely interested," he says. "It would have cost them $1.3 million per corporation per year, and we were looking for a three-year commitment. I said to the mayor: 'They'll want something for it. They may want to put their logo on the firehouse door, or something, that's to be negotiated.' They didn't want to do it."
A close adviser to Mayor Bloomberg explains why the administration dismissed the scheme. "How do you give essential municipal services to a corporation?" the aide says. "How do you allocate them? Is a corporation willing to pay for a firehouse on Fifth Avenue but not on 169th and Third Avenue in the Bronx? If we're going to get corporate sponsorship, we should decide what service we need and where we need it. We shouldn't do it because somebody's willing to pay for a firehouse, if it's not what you need in the end."
Bloomberg stuck to his plan to close the houses, but took a different approach than previous mayors. In the weeks before the closings, he visited each firehouse personally and spoke to the firefighters. "The guys weren't happy, clearly," says a Fire Department insider, "but he went there to take the heat, to say to them: 'Blame me. Don't blame anybody else.' Talk about gutsy." It did little good. The unions and firefighters continued to attack Bloomberg publicly, arguing that the data on postclosing response times is flawed. (The Mayor's office counters that it used the same system for computing response times that it has always used and is employed by fire departments across the country.) 
The unions weren't the only ones to pile on. One City Council member, when asked how much the mayor harmed himself with the closings, told me, not without relish: "Deeply. He may never recover."
Some within the Bloomberg administration seem inclined to agree. "If you're a politician and you close six firehouses," says one of Bloomberg's senior aides, "you just gave your opponent six communities to go into, at the next election, with a bludgeon. Which makes it incredibly difficult to do. That's why mayors don't want to do it." But Bloomberg, he argues, had no choice. Facing a budget gap that exceeded, in dollar value, even that which nearly sank the city in the late 1970's, he had to make cuts, and it only made sense that they would include one of the city's most inefficient agencies. As Ray Horton, a professor at the Columbia Business School and former president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit group that monitors the city and state, puts it, "If a well-run operation seeks to use its people and its facilities as fully as possible, then the Fire Department falls about as far short of that as any organization you could ever think of." In addition, firefighters are among the best paid of all city workers. With overtime, the average annual pay for a member of the Fire Department is more than $60,000. 
Even at that, however, Bloomberg was mindful of the politics of fire cuts. Despite the six closings, the Fire Department took a light hit compared with other city agencies. More than half of the city's public health assistants were laid off. Three thousand members of the city's municipal work force lost their jobs. Other essential agencies had 25 to 30 percent of their operating budgets axed. In comparison, the New York City Fire Department took a 10 percent cut to its operating budget of $1.2 billion, and none of its workers were fired. The firefighters who worked in the six engine companies that were closed were reassigned to other houses, and indeed were given a pick of where they wanted to go. Yet the firefighters fought the cuts, telling reporters that the closings would lead to deaths, festooning their firehouses in banners that attacked the mayor's decision. 
But then, the Fire Department has always been reluctant to accept any changes that would make it more cost-effective. In the mid-1990's, Mayor Giuliani, determined to get greater productivity out of a department that was fighting fewer and fewer fires, initiated a plan to make firefighters first responders in medical emergencies, with a long-term plan ultimately to fold E.M.S. into the Fire Department. The unions fought the change furiously, then agreed to take on the added work only if they got extra pay on top of their regular firefighting salaries. Negotiations between the unions and the Fire Department took years to settle. Still, many in the Fire Department continue to resent doing E.M.S. work, and the comfortable integration of E.M.S. into the Fire Department is far from complete. 
The fire department's deep resistance to change is, in some respects, an inevitable aspect of the firehouse culture. Firefighters, who sometimes refer to themselves as the Brotherhood, are second family to one another. They live together, sleep together, shop together, cook together, clean together and socialize together. And sometimes they die together. As in the military, such enforced fraternity breeds the trust necessary for the performing of life-threatening duties as a team. But the culture also breeds a mentality that rebels against authority outside its direct chain of command, a deep suspicion of the outside world and a sometimes poisonous attitude of Us against Them. 
Thomas Von Essen knows the culture in the New York City Fire Department as well as anyone. He worked in the department for 32 years, first as a firefighter with Ladder Company 42 in the South Bronx, then as head of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, and eventually as fire commissioner under Mayor Giuliani. (He is now a senior vice president at Giuliani Partners, a consulting firm created by the former mayor.) Von Essen is one of the few former department insiders who will speak on the record about firehouse closings. His willingness in part reflects his alienation from the Brotherhood. Von Essen first angered the unions and firefighters when, as commissioner, he pushed hard for the department to take on expanded E.M.S. duties, but he was most ferociously criticized by the unions and the rank and file after Sept. 11, when he tried to reduce the number of firefighters assigned to clean up at Ground Zero. Von Essen was booed by the firefighters at a Madison Square Garden tribute after the attacks -- a major humiliation.
Today, Von Essen is, at the very least, a man no longer interested in upholding the myths that can obscure what ails the department. He is blunt in saying that Mayor Bloomberg was justified in closing the six firehouses, and that, indeed, "he probably could have closed a few more." He points to the vast reduction in fires, the changing demographics of the city, and the simple, unavoidable fact that in slow firehouses firefighters are sitting on their hands. These firefighters "are often bored, but unwilling to admit it," Von Essen says. 
He also scoffs at the union officials who say that the absence of a given engine in one of the closed neighborhoods will eventually lead to a death that could have been prevented. "You could absolutely create any scenario you want to make it impossible to ever close anything," he says. "It's like the police. If you want to give everybody maximum protection, I suppose we should have a police officer in the vestibule of every apartment building. At some point somebody has to say, 'Well, we can't afford one in every vestibule.' You can't run a city or an army or anything like that." As Von Essen goes on to explain, "Any time you say that there's any logic to closing a firehouse, it's like the end of the world."
Indeed, often firefighters from closed houses are ultimately happy to be reassigned to a busy house. As one longtime veteran of the Fire Department told me, firefighters "just say they don't want to go because that's the thing you're supposed to say. They're afraid of the Brotherhood coming down on them." 
It's 10:30 a.m. at Engine Company 55 on the fringe of Little Italy and, since shift change at 9, the house has answered three calls. The first was an E.M.S. run to the corner of Lafayette and Canal streets -- what one of the firefighters sardonically calls a "popular call." It involved helping a local homeless man, Juan Cruz, whom the firefighters of Engine Company 55 regularly escort to a detox center. The second call was to a construction site where a wire shorted out and caught fire under a board in the street. The third call was a stove fire that the apartment dweller had already doused with a home extinguisher. Capt. Richard Sautner describes Engine Company 55 as a "middle-of-the-road house, in terms of activity." Now it's moving toward 11 a.m., and Captain Sautner is having coffee with one of his fellow firefighters in the kitchen out back, beyond the treadmill and exercise equipment. In front of the building, two younger firefighters are lounging around the firehouse entrance, sipping ice water, smoking cigarettes, watching the tourists pass along the sidewalk on Broome Street. Every few minutes someone stops and asks directions. Only one member of the five-man company is working hard today, and that's the new guy -- a probie fresh out of the fire academy. 
"Yeah, he's our new janitor, laundry man, sous chef and cleaning man," says one of the firefighters in front of the building. "One of Brooklyn's own." 
According to Captain Sautner, Engine Company 55 was rumored to have been on a list for closing back in the 1960's. Judging from the pace of things around here today, that doesn't come as much of a surprise. When Engine Company 55's splendid Romanesque and Beaux-Arts firehouse was built in 1898, it serviced a neighborhood of tightly packed tenement houses honeycombed with immigrant sweatshops and cell-like basement rooms that housed workers who lighted their quarters with candles, and later, bulbs powered by overloaded sockets and extension cords -- a serious firetrap that made the area busy indeed for the local firehouses. But demographic changes over the last century have transformed the neighborhood. Today, the surrounding area is filled with renovated multimillion-dollar loft spaces, upscale boutiques, and the glamorous bars and restaurants of Nolita and SoHo. And many of the buildings are now equipped with state-of-the-art sprinkler systems, alarms and fire-retardant materials.
Captain Sautner admits that these changes have resulted in a lot less work for him and his men. "Well, we're busy," he clarifies, "but there are more 'busy' things to do." By this, he means the round of regular, daily drills to keep their firefighting skills sharp (with fires down so drastically, New York's firefighters no longer learn primarily on the job; they learn in the classroom and in simulated situations). They also go out, twice a week, on the dreaded building inspection -- or "B.I." -- to make note of fire code violations in the neighboring buildings. The rest of their time is filled with E.M.S. runs. They get the odd heart attack, of course, but often it's calls like the one to ferry Juan Cruz to detox. Since the anthrax attacks that followed Sept. 11, every firehouse in the city has had an increased number of calls to stem biochemical terrorist attacks -- which, so far, have all turned out to be nothing more harmful than spilled Ajax on a subway platform or unspecified powders in buildings. "You name it," Sautner says. 
But despite its drastically reduced workload, and the fact that there are other engine companies nearby, it's doubtful that Engine Company 55 will ever be closed -- not now, not after Sept. 11, when Engine Company 55 took a particularly devastating blow. Five of its six men on duty died when the twin towers collapsed, crushing their fire truck. The engine company has built a shrine in their firehouse, just inside the front door, where it's visible to passers-by on the street: at its center is the truck's crumpled door still whitened by the dust from ground zero. In the days after Sept. 11, Engine Company 55 became a mandatory photo-op backdrop for visiting celebrities and politicians -- in part thanks to the actor Steve Buscemi, who was a firefighter at Engine Company 55 from 1980 to 1984. Among those who visited were Paul McCartney, the actor Denis Leary and President George W. Bush, who ate pizza at Engine Company 55's kitchen table three weeks after the World Trade Center attacks. 
Chris Geraghty, a tough-looking man in his early 30's, is a firefighter with Engine Company 55. After stints in advertising and bartending, he joined the department four and a half years ago. He was off-duty the morning of the terrorist attacks but reported to a firehouse near his home in Manhattan. He later helped to clean up the site. Geraghty has better reason than most to know how different the life of a firefighter is today from that of a firefighter 30 years ago. His father was a firefighter in the Bronx and Brooklyn during the height of the burning in the early 70's. "We wouldn't see him for days at a time," says Geraghty of himself and his five siblings. "He told us stories of going to three, four fires a night."
By comparison, Chris fights perhaps one serious structural fire a month. His last "real fire" -- by which he means one that his engine company was first responder to and which was more than a pot of beans left on the stove -- was a mattress fire; dangerous, but not the kind of five-alarm row-house inferno that would have been routine in his father's day. Geraghty reluctantly admits to the itchiness that comes with inactivity. "Everybody gets excited when they hear 'Fire,"' he says. When I ask if his father ever ribs him about the relative ease of his life as a firefighter, Geraghty shoots back: "You mean because he went to a fire every day? No. My father tells me, 'After 9/11, you've seen more than I saw in 30 years on the job."' 
The answer makes emotional, but not rational, sense. Horrible as it must have been to dig out at ground zero, that experience was different from the daily dangers faced by Geraghty's father. But Chris's answer does get to the heart of why firefighters are so opposed to firehouse closings, or indeed any changes in the Fire Department. Tradition, firehouse culture, the Brotherhood -- whatever name you give it -- blind them to the realities at play when a mayor is facing a disastrous budget crisis. Unable, or unwilling, to acknowledge that the huge reduction in fires has introduced redundancies into the department, most firefighters feel only bitterness at the closings. As Geraghty puts it, "Makes you feel a little like the flavor of the month. One minute you're heroes, the next minute they're shutting houses."
If any event underlined the enormous differences in the flammability of New York City today versus the New York City of the so-called War Years, it was the blackout of Aug. 14, 2003. Though a higher than usual number of fires did occur that night (mostly because of mishaps with candles), the city's 197 firehouses proved sufficient to handle all facets of the emergency, from fires to stuck elevators to subway evacuations (in comparison with 1977, when the city exploded in arson and looting). Still, this summer's blackout did point up the huge political risks Mayor Bloomberg has taken in shutting the six firehouses. One of the fires that broke out that night trapped four elderly people in a four-story apartment building in north-side Williamsburg, within the first-call zone of former Engine Company 212, the People's Firehouse. It was one of those incidents that no computer model could have predicted. All the engine companies meant to cover for Engine Company 212 were tending to other emergencies in the blackout. No deaths occurred, thanks to Ladder Company 106, the sole company to respond to the scene, but it was a close call and not just for the four people rescued from the blaze. If history is any guide, Mayor Bloomberg's re-election hopes might not have survived a fatal fire in a neighborhood where a firehouse had been closed. That put a peculiarly personal cast on a ceremony held five days after the blackout, at City Hall, where Mayor Bloomberg presented citations to a number of agencies that helped with the crisis, including Ladder Company 106. "While the true heroes of last week's blackout were the eight million citizens of this city," Bloomberg said in his opening remarks, "I want to say a special thank-you to members of our municipal work force." You can bet he meant it.

HEADLINE: An Accidental Radical 

BYLINE:  By Peter Beinart; Peter Beinart is the editor of The New Republic.

 BODY:
 THE GREAT UNRAVELING
Losing Our Way in the New Century.
By Paul Krugman.
426 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $25.95.
 IF you want to understand Howard Dean, read Paul Krugman. Krugman, who has compiled more than three years of columns for The New York Times (and some for Slate and Fortune) in "The Great Unraveling," is to liberal journalism what Dean is to Democratic politics. Like Dean, Krugman is a relative newcomer to his field: Dean practiced medicine for a decade before running for office; Krugman enjoyed a highly successful academic career (he's still an economics professor at Princeton) before becoming a columnist. These unusual career paths have left both men with a sense of themselves as outsiders in their current professions. In particular, both Dean and Krugman are acutely aware -- and proud -- of not living in Washington.
This self-conscious distance from their colleagues is crucial to both men's emergence as what one might call "accidental radicals." In the 1990's, neither Dean nor Krugman would have been obvious liberal-left standard bearers. Dean's fiscal conservatism angered many liberal Vermonters, and Krugman's unabashed support for free trade elicited attacks from the antiglobalization movement. But over the last year, both men have been radicalized by the presidency of George W. Bush -- more specifically, by the political and journalistic elite's docile response to the presidency of George W. Bush. Just as Dean caught fire by attacking Washington Democrats for acquiescing to upper-income tax cuts and the Iraq war, Krugman has repeatedly railed against Washington journalists -- including liberal Washington journalists -- for rationalizing and minimizing the Bush administration's extremism. "During the first two years of the Bush administration, many pundits insisted that the radical conservative bent of that administration was only a temporary maneuver," he writes in his introduction. "I was ahead of the curve in realizing that something radical was happening. As a professional economist, I was in a position to appreciate the disconnect between official claims and reality; as a media outsider I wasn't part of the Washington culture, in which it's considered bad form to suggest that leading politicians have ulterior motives that bear little resemblance to their stated goals."
Krugman is at least partly right: his economics background does give him an edge. As generalists, political reporters often lack the policy expertise to cut through a phony social security or energy proposal on deadline. And even when they do, the conventions of newspaper evenhandedness dilute their analysis. Krugman, by contrast, is blunt even compared with most opinion writers. Columnists who began as reporters (think of Krugman colleagues like Maureen Dowd, Thomas L. Friedman and Nicholas D. Kristof) often construct their columns around compelling anecdotes or scenes; conveying a mood is as important as building a case. For Krugman, like other columnists without newspaper journalism backgrounds (think of George Will, Charles Krauthammer or Michael Kinsley, whose hyperlogical, almost clinical style defines Slate, which employed Krugman for several years), argument is king. Many of Krugman's columns even contain mini thesis paragraphs near the top, followed by a systematic laying out of the evidence and ending with a forceful restatement of the central point. In the hands of a more plodding writer, such a structure could grow dull. But like Kinsley, Krugman scrupulously avoids jargon, never wastes words and pivots sharply between paragraphs to keep readers' attention. 
Krugman's best columns showcase his fluency in economics, analytical power and willingness to go out on a limb. Take the California energy crisis. Faced with such a complex and technical subject, many commentators latched onto the same vague, reasonable-sounding explanations; conservatives took it as axiomatic that the crisis in no way undermined the case for electricity deregulation. The result, as Krugman notes, was a mushy, safe consensus that California had brought the debacle upon itself through poorly implemented deregulation. Krugman, however, diverged early on, arguing -- on the basis of conversations with, and reports by, economists who study energy -- that while California may indeed have deregulated poorly, the real problem was willful gouging by large energy companies. Eventually, even the toothless Federal Energy Regulatory Commission acknowledged that the market had been manipulated.
In "The Great Unraveling," Krugman tries to harness his columns into one overarching argument about the Bush presidency. In the introduction, he calls the administration a "revolutionary power" -- a term he takes from Henry Kissinger's analysis of France under Robespierre and Napoleon -- that wants to replace the post-New Deal order with an undiluted plutocracy. But to make his case, Krugman has to do more than merely dissect the administration's policies; he has to explain its motives and culture. And here Krugman's unconventional background becomes a liability. He criticizes Washington reporters for being prisoners of their sources, and the dinner-party-going "commentariat" for succumbing to groupthink. But guest lists that cross ideological lines can help liberals understand the conservatives they write about. And many Washington conservatives genuinely don't see the Bush administration as radical: they see it as having ratified a big-spending, culturally liberal status quo. Krugman assumes a revolutionary consciousness that may not actually exist on the ground. 
Krugman's assumptions about the administration's motives are most problematic on foreign policy. He understands the Iraq war by analogy to the Bush tax cuts, as if rewarding corporate friends with military contracts via the Carlyle Group was a driving force behind the decision to depose Saddam Hussein. He wonders whether the Bush administration will "start threatening already democratic countries with military force." And he dismisses suggestions that President Bush's aggressive foreign policy was a genuine reaction to Sept. 11, writing that "we knew there were people out there who wanted to hurt us; it wasn't that much of a surprise when they finally scored a hit."
At one point, Krugman says he has "a vision -- maybe just a hope -- of a great revulsion." Among liberals, that revulsion is now on full display, powering the candidacy of Howard Dean. But most Americans do not consider the Bush administration corrupt, and Paul Krugman cannot convincingly prove it is. He should stick to what he does so well: simply proving, on issue after issue, that the Bush administration is wrong.

SECTION: Section 3; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 1302 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
A Good Quarter (In Spite Of It All)

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
THE third quarter is usually a quiet time for investors. That was not the case this year. 
 Mutual fund shareholders were confronted with one of the worst sell-offs in the history of the bond market and the onset of a scandal in the mutual fund industry. And evidence that the economy was gaining strength remained mixed, at best. 
 Still, optimism was the dominant sentiment in stock markets around the world, even though a late-September slide pared what had been extremely strong gains. 
"It was a good quarter," Christine Benz, a senior analyst at Morningstar Inc., said. But, she added, "Up until the last week, it was shaping up to be a stupendous quarter." 
Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, is investigating trading activities at a number of fund families. But there is little evidence to suggest that this has soured attitudes about investing in mutual funds. 
The scandal did prompt Morningstar to recommend that investors pull their money out of four of the fund families that have been named in the investigation: Banc One, Janus Funds, Strong Funds and most funds offered by Bank of America. 
"There is sufficient evidence in Mr. Spitzer's complaint to suggest some major ethical breaches at those funds," said Brian Portnoy, senior fund analyst at Morningstar. "It's an extremely competitive industry, and these violations are noxious enough that you should seriously consider moving your money elsewhere." 
Even with the mini-swoon in late September, the average domestic diversified equity fund rose by 4.2 percent for the quarter, according to Morningstar data.
Reflecting the breadth of the advance, virtually every fund group had positive returns. Among diversified stock funds, only bear market funds, which "short" the market, and utility funds,moved lower. Among sector funds, only utilities lost ground. 
Gold-oriented funds, which gained 24.6 percent, were the best performers, reflecting a steady rise in gold prices. Japanese funds rose 21.6 percent, and emerging-markets funds were up 14.1 percent.
Even bond funds were relatively unscathed, despite the huge sell-off that began in mid-June and ran well into July. Bond prices rallied during the last three weeks of September, erasing much of the loss sustained earlier in the quarter. 
For the period, taxable bond funds had an average return of 0.6 percent, according to Morningstar. 
William H. Gross, who manages the world's largest bond fund, the $73 billion Pimco Total Return fund, said that even after the big sell-off in July, redemptions from his fund were minimal. 
"We might have lost $500 million in August after the bad July," Mr. Gross said. "To be frank, we were saved by the fact that the Total Return fund is dominated by small institutions and the like who have a longer time horizon than others." 
Robin Thurston, global director of research at Lipper, said, "The fact that taxable bond funds ended the quarter flat to slightly positive is a surprise, especially after what happened in July." 
Investors started to pull money out of bond funds in July, according to figures from AMG Data Services, and withdrew $7.7 billion in August, the highest level of redemptions since March 2000. Most of that money was withdrawn from government bond funds that invest in mortgage-backed securities.
Even though science and technology funds had another strong quarter -- the funds posted an average gain of more than 10 percent, according to Lipper -- fresh investments in those funds were minimal. 
Investors "went into growth and value equity funds and were more focused on small-cap and aggressive-growth funds," said Robert Adler, president of AMG. "That suggests investors are taking more risk but are broadly ranging into other sectors where they see opportunity."
STILL, investors with money in technology funds were rewarded. The sector's strong performance was somewhat surprising, because the summer quarter is usually weak for technology companies. 
"Typically, the third quarter is a seasonally slow period," said Christopher K. McHugh, who manages the $23 million Turner Technology fund, which had gains of 21.5 percent for the quarter. 
"But the last two or three years have just been awful, so there was a back-to-school demand build-up that was better than anticipated. All of the work these companies have done in cutting costs is really beginning to filter through" to the bottom line. 
Mr. McHugh said that he was not concerned that the Nasdaq composite index had risen 33.8 percent this year through Sept. 30.
"I am not worried about valuations at this point," he said, "because we have not begun to see the operating leverage at these companies." Earnings reports for the third and the fourth quarters "will ultimately funnel out the good stocks from the bad stocks," he said.
It was hard to find a gold stock that did badly in the third quarter. The stocks rode the increase in the price of gold, which rose to $386.10 an ounce. Gold prices have climbed about 15 percent for the year. 
A weaker dollar, coupled with concern that expansive monetary and fiscal policies in Washington will fuel inflation, will keep gold prices firm for some time, said Darko Kuzmanovic, portfolio manager of the $200 million Scudder Gold and Precious Metals fund, which gained 44.3 percent in the quarter. "If prices stay at these levels, we have a lot of opportunity to make money for our unit holders," he said.
As the quarter drew to a close, the decline in the value of the dollar against the Japanese yen sent major market averages lower in Tokyo. But the price decline followed nearly three months of strong gains in the Japanesemarket, and barely nicked the performance of Japanese equity funds. 
From time to time over the past decade, there have been hints that Japan's moribund economy is on the verge of a recovery, so there is reason to be cautious about the positive data that have been flowing out of the country recently. Still, American investors have begun to pay attention
"We have had more questions from independent investment advisers, who recognize they have very small exposure in Japan," said Mark W. Headley, manager of the $33 million Matthews Japan fund. "The fund has had steady but small net inflows over the last six months. People are noticing, and the performance is of interest." 
Mr. Headley said it is not clear,, that Japan's economic recovery is sustainable. "We don't know the answer to that," he said, "but Japan has taken dozens of half steps in many areas that are adding up to significant change." Mr. Headley said he was pleased to see the Japanese yen gaining strength. 
"Personally, I think a strong currency is good for a stock market," he said. "It encourages people to keep their money at home, and it encourages foreigners to invest there." 
With major market indexes solidly in the black through the first three quarters, many fund managers might be happy to see the year end tomorrow. 
Nonetheless, as the fourth quarter begins, investors and the professionals who manage their money have to wonder if market leadership is about to change. 
Thomas McManus, chief investment strategist at Banc of America Securities, who has 75 percent of his model portfolio invested in stocks, said he was still positive about the market's prospects. But yesterday's stars are about to take a back seat to other stocks, Mr. McManus said. 
"I think midcap and small-cap outperformance is coming to an end," he said. "Growth expectations are no longer low, they are high, so the surprise is gone."
He added: "Between now and year-end, some of the large-cap, laggard stocks, including consumer staples, big drug companies and some large-cap laggards within the technology space like I.B.M. and Microsoft will simply catch up to the Standard & Poor's 500. If that happens, the S.& P. itself will be up 50 points."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Park Avenue Proletarians; 
Every Four Years, Blue Bloods Put on a Blue Collar

BYLINE:  By RICK LYMAN

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Vt. 

 BODY:
IN 1908, the populist presidential candidate William Jennings Bryan had an idea: he'd expose the Republican nominee, the rotund Ohioan Robert Taft, as a rich elitist by using pictures of him playing golf. Golf! The sport of blue bloods.
 In 1936, Franklin D. Roosevelt was castigated by fellow upper-crusters as a traitor to his class for using federal tax revenues to aid the impoverished. 
 And as recently as 1992, Democrats mercilessly lampooned the first President Bush as an out-of-touch patrician. His crime? During a visit to a national grocers' convention in Orlando, Fla., he appeared almost giddy about the wondrous technology of supermarket scanners, apparently unaware that they had been quite familiar to American shoppers for more than a decade. 
Americans famously like to think of themselves as members of a classless society, where merit and hard work determine fate, while at the same time, they scoop up magazines with the latest gossip about Britain's royals. 
In Europe, "there's always an angry left and people responding to arguments about rich conservatives," said Robert Frank, an economist at Cornell University. "Here, there doesn't seem to be so much of a resentment towards the rich."
This time around, with a sluggish economy and a bogged-down war effort in Iraq, Democrats are hoping to find more traction on the class issue, particularly in light of the administration's tax cuts, which rivals will try to paint as a looting of the Treasury on behalf of the president's super-rich cronies. 
But the mix of backgrounds among the candidates assembling for the coming presidential race has many wondering whether class warfare can become an issue in 2004.
Howard Dean, who has led the tirades against the current President Bush, is himself the scion of an established New York family that lived on Park Avenue, summered in East Hampton and went to all the right schools. John Kerry, who also attended the right schools and had affected a Boston Brahmin demeanor, married into a vast fortune and finds himself struggling on the campaign trail to redefine himself as a man of the masses. John Edwards, on the other hand, is a multimillionaire lawyer born into the working class, whose campaign message is liberally, perhaps even bitterly, sprinkled with reminders that his father was a factory worker who didn't get all the breaks that some other candidates' families enjoyed.
"I think class issues will get some traction in this election because of the Bush administration's tax cuts," said Alan Wolfe, a political scientist at Boston College. "There really are only two classes in America now -- that top 2 percent and everybody else. If the Democrats can't make an issue out of class this time around, then they will never be able to do it."
Many believe class will never be more than background noise in a presidential election, partly because of the decline of the old ruling class, as well as a deep-seated sense among voters that most rich people probably earned what they got.
"We don't deal with class anymore in this country, because we can't deal with class," said James B. Twitchell, author of "Living It Up" and a professor of English and advertising at the University of Florida in Gainesville. "What does class mean to us now? Class is based on such things as how many generations have lived in the same place. Who cares about that now? Or the number of vowels in your name, and who cares about that?
"It really used to be based on where your pew was in the Episcopal Church, but the Episcopal Church is in a state of absolute free fall. Everything that built class has been effaced."
Certainly, the track record of invoking class in presidential elections is a dismal one.
Even armed with his cross of golf, Bryan was unable to beat Taft in 1908. Earlier, Theodore Roosevelt did not deny his patrician roots but used them to highlight his reformist credentials. The attempts to paint Franklin Roosevelt as a class traitor resulted in his winning re-election three times. And while the first President Bush's grocery-scanner faux pas was followed by his loss to President Clinton, few regard it as anything more than a link in the chain that toppled him.
In the one election where class might have played a role -- the rich Senator John F. Kennedy versus the up-from-the-middle-class Richard M. Nixon in 1960 -- it was never really evoked. Kennedy opponents preferred to highlight his Roman Catholic roots over his bank balance. And besides, to true blue bloods, there was always something unsavory and arriviste about the Kennedy fortune; to attack him for being a member of their class would be to admit that he was one.
Mr. Twitchell said he believes class will not make an appearance in the coming campaign, if only because Mr. Bush so successfully squelched the issue in 2000.
"Look at this guy," he said. "He is Andover, Yale, Harvard, Episcopal Church, and yet he recast himself as a West Texas good old boy, a sportsman. The triumph of George W. is not that he denies his class, but that he so completely and sincerely recreated his class."
That might have worked in 2000, others argue, when the president's record was a blank slate, but it may not work again.
"It was an image rebranding," Mr. Wolfe said. "Now we will see if he can survive a policy rebranding."
Whatever the case, Mr. Twitchell said, the class issue is unlikely to unseat a sitting president. "Class warfare, it's absolute nonsense," he said. "That's really all that's left of class, sort of a dim memory of haves versus have-nots."
Whether candidates come from the upper classes or the lower orders will probably matter less than where they stand on class issues.
"Arguably the most left-wing presidency was F.D.R.'s, and he was from a 17th-century Dutch-manor background," said Michael Kazin, a Georgetown University historian. "When Nelson Rockefeller was running, he tried to use the argument that he couldn't be bought because he was already so rich, and perhaps that can be successful. The 'I was born in a log cabin' thing can help, it can be an add-on, but I can't think of a single instance in American history of it making the difference."
The bottom line in American politics, he said, has always been: what are you going to do for me?
"Americans are sort of realistic," Mr. Kazin said. "They're not voting for someone because of their background, but because they think they can help them."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 12, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about class warfare in presidential campaigns misstated the name of the candidate who ran against William Jennings Bryan in 1908. He was William Howard Taft. (Robert Taft, Republican senator from Ohio, was William Howard Taft's son.)

HEADLINE: The World: Three Wars Over Iraq; 
Staying the Course May Be the Hardest Battle

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq 

 BODY:
SOME prominent Americans said this time would come, and now it is here: the season when American staying power in Iraq is being seriously tested.
 In Congress, many Republicans are joining Democrats to challenge President Bush's decision to spend $20 billion on reconstruction without any commitment for repayment from this oil-rich land. The American military is as overextended as it has been since Vietnam, with tens of thousands of reservists facing career and family dislocations. The United Nations, with no discernible mission, is fleeing, having sacrificed some of its best and brightest diplomats in a vicious car bombing. Many humanitarian organizations are following. 
 And Iraqis -- even those who welcomed the overthrow of Saddam Hussein -- are rebelling against occupation. More Iraqis say they admire the French president, Jacques Chirac, than Mr. Bush. Go figure. 
Yet on the ground here, despite the staccato of gunfire in the night, optimism has never been stronger that Iraqis will pull through, if America can find a formula for letting them take control of their destiny as the allied armies and occupation administrators recede.
The streets of Baghdad, Basra and Mosul bustle with commerce. Restaurants are filled late into the night as the heat of summer abates along with the fear of crime. Schools, many refurbished with the help of Americans, reopened last week. New textbooks, cleansed of Saddam Hussein's image, are being printed. The curfew has been extended an hour, until midnight.
Iraqis are voting with their feet, figuring that it is time to reopen their shops because the violence here is not directed at them, but at the American military and, less, at Iraq's new police and politicians.
Still, consensus in postwar Iraq is as elusive as Mr. Hussein, who remains in hiding. And the war over Iraq policy has moved into a complex phase.
There are three wars, really: the guerrilla campaign inside Iraq, the diplomatic war between the United States and the international community over nation-building and peacekeeping, and the partisan war in Washington, where Mr. Bush's critics are challenging almost everything about the course he charted here.
The war inside Iraq is now about occupation, a word that conjures the worst memories in a region that has been a battleground for empires and still seethes over the plight of Palestinians under the Israelis. 
In Khaldiya last week, tribal elders surveying the wreckage of their cousin's home from an assault by 82nd Airborne troops railed against the foreigners in their land. Bash Abid Shehab, 74, said the resistance here that drew American fire was not about bringing back Mr. Hussein, nor was it about religion.
"We need our freedom and prosperity," he said. "The Americans should walk with us in freedom without pointing guns at us, and if they don't we will keep resisting them until we force them to leave the country."
The resistance in Iraq began growing in May, when the Bush administration decided against handing power immediately to a provisional government of untested exiles, Kurds and Shiite groups, and opted for a lengthy occupation strategy that seemed necessary to free up Iraq's assets and to get the oil flowing and United Nations sanctions lifted. 
That decision, made in the Oval Office, was announced with the arrival of L. Paul Bremer III, the occupation administrator. There was no consultation with Iraqis. Now many Iraqi political figures say that despite Mr. Bush's declared commitment to rebuild the state as a democratic model, the failure to consult them distorted Iraqi assessments of Mr. Bush's intent.
The occupation model put American troops into immediate confrontation with the minority of Iraqis invested in American failure and, more important, it antagonized a majority, who supported Mr. Hussein's overthrow. A blistering summer of power failures, water shortages and Mr. Bremer's practice of working with Iraqis only as token advisers made things worse.
In an off-the-record conversation three weeks before he died in the car bomb attack on Aug. 19, Sergio Vieira de Mello, the United Nations envoy here, said he considered his mission one of persuading Mr. Bremer to trust the Iraqis to rule themselves during the transition to a new state. He later admonished the Iraqi political leaders to take Mr. Bremer's offer of a "governing council" despite their reservations. Once in the council, he said, they should seize all the power they could because "Bremer will not be able to stop you."
But the experiment with the 24-member governing council may be failing, its members say. Mr. Bremer returned from Washington last week and scolded council members at a meeting for having taken independent decisions. Four times, members said, Mr. Bremer reminded them that he held supreme authority. One member walked out.
Mr. Bremer's authority has done little to quell the daily attacks on American forces. Some of those responsible are Mr. Hussein's men. Some are paid to do it. Some convince themselves that Islam demands it. Most are Sunnis in the arc around Baghdad. Some may be Shiites under the influence of radical clerics. Some are infiltrators from Syria and Al Qaeda. Some are tribal people seeking revenge for a humiliation or loss of a relative. Some are just criminals.
But the sum of this resistance does not necessarily amount to a military challenge to the United States. Many Iraqis see the security problem as an issue of policing -- which Iraqis should perform. Security is undermined, they say, when M-1 tanks and Bradley fighting vehicles roar through the streets with young American soldiers isolated behind machine guns they keep pointed at the people they have liberated.
The war inside Iraq feeds the conflict between the United States and those countries that questioned whether a war to oust Mr. Hussein was really necessary.
Many Iraqis are less concerned about this debate, aside from the fact that any sign of American and British duplicity about the evidence marshaled for the war undercuts the moral position of the occupation. For many Iraqis, the discovery of mass graves, the opening of the torture chambers, the discovery that Saddam Hussein sent his son to clean out the Central Bank in March is more than enough to convince them of the moral rightness of toppling the dictator.
But the United States does not get a pass. Many Iraqis look to the United Nations and to Europeans as more detached in their judgment of how to put things right. In this view, putting the Iraqis in charge under a United Nations mandate, as the Europeans argue, makes sense. 
But for the Bush administration, any loss of control threatens not only the economic payback for the $20 billion the United States is spending on reconstruction, but also the image of American pre-eminence in reshaping the world. And this fuels the third war -- the one inside the Washington Beltway, where American anxiety about the cost of the war in Iraq plays into the hopes or fears of anyone with a stake in the debate.
For most Iraqis, though, the deed has been done. Mr. Hussein is history. They are ready to move on. If members of Congress demonstrate that Mr. Bush went to war based on intelligence that did not support the assertions about Iraqi weapons of mass destruction or support for terrorists, where does that leave the commitment for rebuilding Iraq?
The anonymous guerrillas trying to blow up American convoys and shooting American soldiers hope they can break American will and send them home, as Mr. Hussein once thought he could with the "mother of all battles." The Iraqi politicians challenging Mr. Bremer's authority, making end runs to Congress and making nice with the French are trying to gain control of the country because they think they can do a better job than the Americans.
They don't want America to leave, but they fear an erosion of American staying power under the current policy. And this is the season in which that power will be tested.

HEADLINE: The World: Pakistan's Perennial Gadfly; 
In One Man's Life, a Glimpse of Democracy's Agony

BYLINE:  By DAVID ROHDE

DATELINE: NEW DELHI 

 BODY:
AS a young man, Nawabzada Nasrullah Khan excitedly watched South Asia's political lions lead the fight against British colonialism. Mohandas K. Gandhi, Jawaharlal Nehru and Mohammed Ali Jinnah, who read literature and wrote extensively while leading mass independence movements, became his icons.
 When he was 29, his dream came true. British colonial ruled ended in South Asia. Pakistan was born as a homeland for the region's Muslims. 
 But for the next 50 years Mr. Khan would spend his life in opposition, demanding democracy in Pakistan and deploring military dictators as well as authoritarian civilian rulers. He died last week in his mid-80's, still in opposition -- leading an alliance of diverse political parties that were trying to unseat Pakistan's current military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf. "It's like painting a dictatorship democracy," he said of General Musharraf in a recent interview in a Pakistani newspaper. "If a cock crows at midnight, it doesn't mean that it's morning."
In some ways, the story of Mr. Khan's long, sad struggle illuminates Pakistan's failure as a democratic state. Military dictators have ruled Pakistan for most of its history. No civilian government has completed its full term in office, thanks to repeated coups and rapacious political infighting. Today, Pakistan's neighbors to the east and west, India and Afghanistan, accuse it of breeding and exporting a virulent and violent form of Islamic militancy. And its 130 million people remain among the most poverty-stricken in the world.
In the midst of it all, Mr. Khan stood as an unrepentant political gadfly. He had a rare ability to forge coalitions among Pakistan's polarized political class. He accused the United States of helping to create Pakistan's problems by repeatedly backing military dictators, including General Musharraf. His supporters eulogized him last week as a rare phenomenon -- a member of the country's feudal elite who did not compromise his principles for power.
"The mere fact that he kept chipping away and did not lose heart, did not give up, was also this exemplary kind of conduct," said Aitzaz Ahsan, a veteran politician in the Pakistan People's Party. 
Mr. Khan, according to his admirers, representedwhat a Pakistani civilian leader should be. Of a political class accused of corruption, opportunism and jockeying for privilege, he lived most of his life in a two-room apartment in Lahore that served as his office and home. In the 1980's, Gen. Zia ul-Haq, Pakistan's military dictator at the time, confined him to house arrest there for five years. The general is said to have sent numerous emissaries to buy him off. Mr. Khan did not waver.
Steeped in South Asian culture, tradition and thought, he wrote Urdu poetry and backed the creation of a secular Western-style democracy with indigenous touches, including respect for a moderate version of Islamic law. During the few times he held senior posts in government, his performance was disappointing, Pakistani commentators wrote last week. He seemed to thrive, instead, in the role of rebel.
A red fez seemed permanently in place on his balding pate. He ceaselessly puffed on a hookah, or water pipe, while conversing for hours about politics and current affairs. Frail, skeletal and constantly seeming to be out of breath, he appeared in his later years to be living on by sheer force of will.
Mr. Khan's first disappointment with Pakistani politics came a decade after independence. In 1958, after a series of weak civilian governments brought Pakistan close to economic collapse, the army's commander, Gen. Mohammad Ayub Khan, seized power in a coup. Mr. Khan demanded the restoration of civilian rule and formed the first of many opposition alliances, the Democratic Action Committee.
Soon after, civilian rule arrived in 1970, Mr. Khan was again in opposition. Zulfikar Ali Bhutto was elected prime minister but began ruling with an iron hand. In what local politicians called the only blemish on Mr. Khan's democratic credentials, he denounced Mr. Bhutto as a dictator and backed General Zia's seizure of power. The general later hanged Mr. Bhutto.
Mr. Khan eventually turned on General Zia. In 1988, civilian rule returned and Benazir Bhutto, the daughter of the executed prime minister, became prime minister. Mr. Khan and many other Pakistanis criticized Ms. Bhutto's government for corruption and mismanagement. He then opposed the government of Ms. Bhutto's bitter rival, Nawaz Sharif, an industrialist who was accused of graft and incompetence. In a 1991 coup, General Musharraf drove Mr. Sharif from power.
Last week, Mr. Khan's closest friends insisted that in a way, he had been making headway in his long struggle for democracy. Its pace seems glacial, they say, but Pakistan is changing.
"We have moved forward a great deal since the 1960's," said Shafqat Mehmood, a former senator. "Now it's not possible for a military ruler to completely dominate the country the way they did then."
Mr. Mehmood called General Musharraf's rule a "very strange kind of democratic martial law." Pakistanis have a form of press freedom, he said, and a year ago they elected a Parliament with limited power.
Meanwhile, the army, with the backing of the United States, continues to dominate the country. An alliance of religious parties that won record support in last year's elections has emerged as the most powerful opposition force, with the country's two secular, mainstream parties dispirited and disorganized.
Mr. Khan's admirers said he represented a breed of South Asian politician that is vanishing. 
"Power and privilege did not turn him on," Mr. Mehmood said. "What did turn him on was fighting for a cause. That is very different from why most people get involved in politics in my country."

HEADLINE: Where Are All the New Drugs? 

BYLINE:  By GARDINER HARRIS

 BODY:
AT its birth in 2000, the executives who created GlaxoSmithKline crowed that the company would unleash a cabinetful of new medicines. "We will be the kings of science and innovation," Dr. Jean-Pierre Garnier, the chief executive, said at the time. 
 Three years later, GlaxoSmithKline is still a long way from its coronation. 
 The company has introduced just three new medicines, only one of which it discovered. Indeed, nine top scientists who recently left Glaxo said they believe its laboratories' productivity was getting worse, not better. "It's a disaster," said one of them, Dr. Peter G. Traber, who was the company's chief of clinical development until February. 
What went wrong? According to Dr. Traber and others, the very thing that was supposed to bolster the labs' output -- the merger -- has instead hampered it. 
If they are correct, GlaxoSmithKline's problems could have implications for the entire industry. Poor lab productivity is bedeviling almost every drug company. Across the industry, introductions of new drugs plummeted last year to 17 from a high of 53 in 1996, despite a near doubling in annual research spending, to $32 billion.
To survive the long drought at the lab, many executives have concluded that one company is better than two. The $400 billion worldwide pharmaceutical industry has rapidly consolidated; 38 major drug companies have merged since 1994. And at nearly every major merger announcement, executives said that lab synergies were a driving force behind the deals.
But many scientists say that if mergers are executives' cure for poor pipelines, the medicine is making the patient sicker. And they point to Glaxo, the world's second-largest pharmaceutical company, after Pfizer, as proof. 
"The effect of mergers on research productivity is an issue that this industry has yet to deal with," said Dr. Traber, who left Glaxo to run the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, one of the nation's top centers of biomedical research. "You save a bit of money, but it's disaster to the labs."
Dr. Garnier dismissed the comments of former employees and said the company's pipeline was just fine. "You can cry over spilled milk, but we are excited about the transformation," he said from his office in Philadelphia. "Transformations are disruptive and sometimes resisted by people who don't like change."
Dr. Tadataka Yamada, Glaxo's research chief, said the former scientists who blame the merger for productivity woes are wrong. "Yes, a merger is a disruption, but a disruptive period is a time to make big changes that shape the company to take on challenges we couldn't take on before," he said. 
The company says it plans to hold a meeting for analysts on Dec. 3 to describe in detail all the new drugs it hopes to roll out, including an AIDS drug and a medicine for incontinence, both of which are under review by the Food and Drug Administration. "If I can deliver this pipeline, the creation of value will be enormous," Dr. Garnier said. Convincing investors that the future is bright is crucial for Glaxo because the next several years don't look so good. Generics are threatening the company's biggest sellers, including the anti-depressant Paxil. The company's historical lead in AIDS drugs is slipping. And while its newest drug, Levitra for erectile dysfunction, is doing well, the company has few other potential big sellers ready for introduction in the next two years.
To increase its $27 billion in annual drug revenue, analysts said, Glaxo will have to do better than just one novel drug a year, its pace so far. In a speech last year, Jan Leschly, the former chief executive of SmithKline Beecham, said that Glaxo needs five new drugs each year to grow adequately. "They are far from being there," he said. He did not return telephone messages last week.
Mergers are hardly the only reason Glaxo and its competitors have produced so few new medicines. The science of drug development has become tougher. New technologies like robotic screening machines that rapidly test millions of chemical compounds against biological targets have not worked as well as industry executives hoped. And the avalanche of genetic information created over the last several years has led to more confusion than clarity. 
But studies of drug industry mergers have found that the combined companies generally lose market share and shareholder value. One reason is that merged drug companies have pipelines that are significantly smaller than those of their predecessor companies, according to a study by CenterWatch, a company that tracks clinical trials. The study blamed the disruption the deals cause in the labs. 
"Mergers may be harming the industry's long-term ability to innovate," said Ken Getz, the chief executive of CenterWatch. Sir Tom McKillop, chief executive of AstraZeneca P.L.C., said in an interview Friday that distraction among scientists is "a huge problem" during mergers. "I was terrified of all the internal focus during the merger," Sir Tom said. Astra A.B. merged with Zeneca P.L.C. in 1999.
Mention mergers to scientists in the industry, and they're prone to rant about their corrosive effects. The worst, they say, are "mergers of equals," like GlaxoSmithKline's, which can lead to months, and even years, of uncertainty and indecision. All of GlaxoSmithKline's previous mergers only added to the mess, according to its former scientists. 
The SmithKline Beckman Corporation combined with Beecham Group P.L.C. in 1989; Glaxo P.L.C. joined with Wellcome P.L.C. in 1995; and Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. and SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. announced their marriage in 2000 to become GlaxoSmithKline. The company is based in Britain, although it has significant operations in the United States, including corporate offices in Philadelphia and research operations in Research Triangle Park, N.C., and King of Prussia, Pa.

When Two Become One
A joke e-mail message making the rounds in the drug industry starts by saying, "You know you work in the pharmaceutical industry when: you've sat at the same desk for four years and worked for three different companies; your company welcome sign is attached with Velcro ." 
The joke elicits rueful laughter from former GlaxoSmithKline scientists. Many of them say they went through wrenching changes to remake the company's myriad standard operating procedures in 1995 only to see those procedures tossed out in 2001 simply because executives couldn't be seen to favor one company over another. Months were spent remaking procedures.
"I was in meetings thinking, 'My life is futile,"' one former researcher said. "Moving piles of dirt from here to there will make you crazy."
The bureaucratic task of combining the two companies became the sole chore for many top scientists, some of whom had to shuttle between continents, they said. That took a toll on research projects. "You simply can't do it all," said another former researcher, who did not want his name used because he continues to work in the industry.
Former company researchers say these are some of the results: Development of a cardiac arrhythmia drug was delayed for nine months, two gastrointestinal drug projects were sidetracked for 18 months, and work on a cancer drug was shelved for nearly two years, former company researchers say. In another case, they say, an allergy medicine project was stopped, started and stopped again while newly formed committees examined the science behind each project.
Dr. Yamada said, "We make scores of pipeline decisions in the course of a year." The old ways of discovering drugs simply weren't working, he said in an interview. "I had been head of R.&D. at SmithKline for 10 months, and it was enough time to know that fundamental change was needed." 
He said he wanted the labs to take the best from both the pharmaceutical and biotechnology industries. To him, drug discovery's first and last steps -- sifting through genomes and screening millions of chemicals at first, and finally testing drugs in large populations -- are more efficient in large pharmaceutical companies. Small organizations are better at tinkering with promising chemicals to make them into medicines, he said. 
So Dr. Yamada created a research operation in which the first and last stages of the process are done by large unified groups while the middle stages are split among six separate and competing organizations called Centers of Excellence for Drug Discovery, or CEDD's. "We created this notion of being both big and small at the same time," Dr. Yamada said.
Dr. Traber came on board in September 2000, nine months after the GlaxoSmithKline merger was announced and during discussions about how the company would combine its two huge research operations. The merger was consummated at the end of the year.
"What ensued was an incredible number of arguments about who was doing what," Dr. Traber said, echoing comments made by other former researchers. 

Who Makes the Call?
Dr. Traber led the company's clinical pharmacology and experimental medicine group. But the CEDD chiefs wanted to run their own clinical programs, at least for early trials. Arguments over who did what raged for months, he said.
"And I'll tell you what wasn't happening: Research projects weren't being pushed forward," Dr. Traber said.
As a result of the merger, the company had two clinical research groups -- one of which was called global medical affairs, and the other, clinical development product strategy. In March 2001, Dr. Traber was asked to lead global medical affairs after its chief left. For the rest of the year, he wrestled with his counterpart over who had control over the company's clinical trials. "Instead of making a decision right away, they let it decline to the point where no one could get anything done," Dr. Traber said. 
Dr. Yamada responded that global medical affairs was always the company's sole clinical group, but several former researchers confirmed Dr. Traber's version of events.
In December 2001, the company combined the two clinical organizations into a single department, Dr. Traber said. Executives throughout the clinical program were told to reapply for their jobs. So, for the second time in a year, their jobs were in jeopardy, Dr. Traber said.
"We had two vice presidents, and sometimes three, for every clinical area," he said. "Imagine the turmoil."
Once the vetting process was over, the new clinical group had to decide how it would operate, Dr. Traber said. Teams of physicians are needed to plan and execute tests in humans, but members of each team had different ideas about their responsibilities. "We had changed the organization to such an extent that no one knew what they did," Dr. Traber said. The new rules for the clinical group were announced in November 2002, he said.
"That means that nearly three years passed between the merger announcement and the time when anyone knows what they're actually doing," Dr. Traber said. "It's only this year that serious prioritization work has begun," he said.
Roughly two-thirds of research dollars are spent in the clinic, so turmoil there can be devastating to a company's research operations. 
David Webster, president of the Webster Consulting Group, which specializes in the drug industry, said that his research confirms Dr. Traber's conclusions. Mr. Webster noted that many of GlaxoSmithKline's top scientists left voluntarily shortly after the merger. A major reorganization in the midst of a merger. Mr. Webster said, increased the uncertainties for all and made even basic decisions difficult. "The outcome of all of this was a 'Lord of the Flies' kind of chaos," he said.
The chaos, Dr. Traber said, left GlaxoSmithKline's pipeline nearly bare when he departed in February. Paging through a 2002 analyst's report listing all of GlaxoSmithKline's promising projects of the time, Dr. Traber said that of the company's 18 projects that were in the Phase 2 of clinical development, 14 had been canceled by the time he left -- a 78 percent failure rate. There have been significant delays with most of the remaining four, he said. 
A recent study by Joseph A. DiMasi, director of economic analysis for the Tufts Center for the Study of Drug Development in Boston, found that, on average, Phase 2 studies have a 56 percent chance of failing.
Dr. Yamada says the company's pipeline is coming along nicely. "The notion that the merger created a sickly, dysfunctional organization is just the opposite of what happened," he said.

The Jury Is Still Out
A few former GlaxoSmithKline scientists said the jury was still out on whether the merger would ultimately improve the company's research. Two said some project teams worked well during the merger despite the distractions. George Poste, the retired chief scientific officer of SmithKline Beecham, said the merger was needed because "scale is very important in this industry."
But 11 other former GlaxoSmithKline scientists said that the merger was mishandled. The restructuring, they said, was overly ambitious and poorly executed. Nearly all did not want their names used because they had signed confidentiality agreements and continued to work in the industry. "You had to have one person from one side and another person from another with little regard as to whether the organization would run," one former researcher said.
Another scientist agreed: "They wanted real consensus, unity and oneness, so we had to get input from every part of both companies and all over the world. It took forever." After Sept. 11, 2001, many executives became reluctant to travel by plane, which further slowed the integration. This scientist continued, "The hallway chat was: 'Why don't they just tell us what to do? Somebody make a decision."'
As for the restructuring, Dr. Traber said, "there was so much arguing about structure and turf that what got lost was getting anything done." 
Dr. Peter B. Corr, the research chief at Pfizer, acknowledged in an interview that Pfizer's acquisition in 2000 of Warner-Lambert suffered a bit from indecision as well. "The biggest problem is that people don't make a decision," Dr. Corr said. "I think we spent too much time trying to get it perfect." Pfizer's merger this year with Pharmacia is not suffering from such indecision, Dr. Corr said.
Philip Ma, a principal at McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm, said mergers of equals in the drug industry were often destructive to lab productivity. "Mergers of equals sound great in concept, but in reality at every department, at every function and at every subfunction, there are arguments about what to do," Mr. Ma said. "When everything's up for grabs, it's not good. Taking the best of both in a feel-good process is not the way to go."
In the past two years, Dr. Yamada said, Glaxo has introduced several modified versions of older drugs, including Wellbutrin XL and Paxil CR for depression and Augmentin XR, an antibiotic. All were created to deal with looming losses to generic competitors. "This reflects work done in the first two years of the merger," Dr. Yamada said. "It could not have been done if we had dropped the ball."
It remains unclear whether the company can run with the ball in creating the kinds of new drugs that will make the merger worthwhile.
