HEADLINE: Balancing Cattle, Land and Ledgers 

BYLINE:  By JIM ROBBINS

DATELINE: THREE FORKS, Mont. 

 BODY:
HARD by the three small streams that tumble together here to form the headwaters of the Missouri River, George Kahrle tends to a herd of 50 or so bawling raven-black cattle.
 They look like cows at any other ranch, but from the time they are born, their lives and the lives of the people who raise them are different. The animals are bred later in the season than at traditional ranches, so calves are born when rich spring grasses are bursting up, and they spend less time in feed lots. 
 They roam more freely, which proponents say fends off the disease and stress so often found in pens on big ranches, and guards pastures from overuse. They are raised without growth hormones and with few, if any, antibiotics. They will even be raised a few months longer, so when they are sent to slaughter they fetch a higher price. 
Mr. Kahrle practices what is called sustainable ranching. By avoiding pesticides and relying more on range grass than feed grown with fertilizers, he says, he is helping to sustain the environment. By avoiding antibiotics and hormones, he is sustaining the quality of his beef. And by reducing his costs and becoming part of a network of distributors, retailers and chefs who care about what they are doing and are willing to pay for it, he is sustaining what is often an economically precarious way of life. "We use more of what nature gives us," Mr. Kahrle said. "It makes sense on every level."
Mr. Kahrle is part of a small, growing group of ranchers and business owners who say the meat industry has cut so many corners for the sake of profit that the environment and the quality of beef have been compromised and small ranchers have been driven out of business. With recent outbreaks of disease, like mad cow in Canada, and a larger trend toward organic and humane treatment of animals, those out West in big hat country feel the time is ripe to market beef with a known history.
Niman Ranch in California sells sustainable meat raised by 45 cattle producers who must meet certain environmental standards, use approved genetics, keep careful health records and pass inspections from Niman. Other ranchers who sell sustainable beef elsewhere follow the same general principles. There is no government or independent oversight of sustainable beef, but the ranchers are working to develop more formalized standards.
"It's about leaving the smallest and lightest footprint that you can," said Heather Hand, a chef and co-owner of the Savory Olive, a restaurant in Bozeman, Mont., that bills itself as serving sustainably grown food with an emphasis on local products. 
Meat production "can't be driven by economics only," said Rob Hurlbut, president of Niman Ranch. "It has to be driven by a quality product."
But, in a sense, sustainable ranching is about economics. Between the premium price he gets for his beef and his savings, on everything from fewer antibiotics to less hay and lower labor costs, Mr. Kahrle said he makes about $30,000 a year more than he would from traditional ranching. In a recent survey by the Corporation for the Northern Rockies, a Montana nonprofit organization that promotes sustainable agriculture, the 38 ranchers surveyed said their profits had increased by an average of 22 percent since abandoning traditional methods.
Mr. Kahrle, a native of Ohio, graduated from Harvard with a degree in sociology. "Unfortunately, that school didn't have an agricultural program," he said. He gave in to the pull of the West's open spaces, studied ranching in Montana and worked in Wyoming as a cowboy and irrigator on a large traditional cattle ranch near Casper. Some practices, he noticed, made more work. Breeding was timed so the calves would be ready for the fall market. But that meant the ranchers had to herd the cows into a barn to avoid late winter blizzards. It stressed the animals, who were used to a life outside, and made more work for hired hands. It also cost about a dollar a day more per cow to feed them hay instead of grass.
In 1989 Mr. Kahrle met Alan Savory, a guru of sustainable range management. In seminars, Mr. Savory teaches ranchers to rethink everything they do to make less work, better beef, a better environment and more profit. 
For several years after he bought his ranch, which he named Sara Faith after his grandmothers, Mr. Kahrle held himself to even more stringent standards, raising organic beef with no pesticides, herbicides, antibiotics, hormones or chemically fertilized hay. It meant a lot more work pulling weeds in his ditches by hand, for example, and prices weren't high enough to justify the extra effort. He decided to try the sustainable approach.
Sustainable beef takes a bigger picture into account, he says, and while it is not completely organic, it is mostly so. "I can use some spray to kill weeds in the ditches," he said. He doesn't use chemically fertilized hay, but in a pinch he can buy hay from a neighbor, something he couldn't do with organic certification. He can use antibiotics, but only if an animal is sick -- not as a preventative, as many ranchers do. 
One stumbling block has been finding enough processing plants, though small packers are emerging, especially in the West. And officials at Niman Ranch, which sells only sustainable beef, pork and lamb, say that in the last six years their revenues have risen to $30 million from $3 million. 
At its slaughterhouse near Boise, Idaho, Niman processes cattle when they are 18 to 24 months old, after they are "finished" with a diet of grain for four to five months. Because cattle companies do not want to spend the money to feed the animals so long, large packing houses slaughter the animals at 12 to 14 months. "That's way too premature," said Mr. Hurlbut of Niman Ranch. 
Niman's feed mix, he said, is fit for human consumption. Cattle raised in large feedlots often eat chicken parts and other waste products.
Niman's cattle have more room in their pens, he said, access to shade and a sprinkler, and ranch hands who are with them until the moment they are stunned and slaughtered, all of which reduce the ravages of stress. "You want an animal with proper, relaxed demeanor in the slaughterhouse," said Mr. Hurlbut, a former vegetarian. "You get more flavor out of the meat."
All of this tender loving care means, of course, that the consumer pays more. Mr. Hurlbut says his New York strip sells to restaurants for $11 a pound, while traditional beef sells for $7 to $8. Niman's beef is also available in stores for up to $20 a pound.
Other sustainable ranchers market free-range, grass-fed beef that never comes near a feedlot. 
"Grass-fed steaks are stronger in flavor and have more texture," said Rick Bayless, owner of the Mexican restaurants Frontera Grill and Topolobampo in Chicago, and a member of the Chefs Collaborative, a group of restaurateurs who promote sustainable food. He uses only grass-fed Montana beef.
The National Cattlemen's Beef Association, an industry trade group, says the concerns over how beef is raised and slaughtered are baseless. 
"It's a marketing distinction, not a distinction based on safety or nutrition" or taste, said Kim Essex, a spokeswoman for the group. "There's a high level of consumer confidence in the beef supply." 
Because many people worry that what they don't know will hurt them, Mr. Hurlbut says, meat with a pedigree is the future. His company tracks Mr. Kahrle's individual cattle, for example. After they are slaughtered, Mr. Kahrle gets a report card.
Now, a butcher who buys a pork loin from Niman Ranch can go to the company's Web site and see a picture of the farmer who raised the animal, his or her farm, and a short biography. Soon, the company hopes to expand that program to include lamb and the cattle Mr. Kahrle and ranchers like him raise. As Mr. Hurlbut put it, "It's all about knowing where your food came from and how it got to your plate."

LENGTH: 1019 words

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW; 
Poetry, Concrete and Cosmic, in a World of Losers

BYLINE:  By BEN BRANTLEY 

 BODY:
It's shameful, isn't it, what people will do these days to get their hands on a juicy piece of poetry? Deception, betrayal, kidnapping and assorted acts of violence are enlisted in the pursuit of things poetic in "The Night Heron," the teasing, brooding new play from Jez Butterworth.
 There is, on the one hand, that big cash prize for best poem that an unemployed gardener, trapped in a hardscrabble life in rustic England, plans to win if only he can figure out how to write the darn thing. On the other hand, there's poetry in the less literal, more cosmic sense: an uncovering of rhyme and reason in a brutal, random universe. 
 The self-sabotaging characters in "The Night Heron," which opened last night at the Atlantic Theater Company, are all looking for that kind of poetry, and the odds of their finding it are heartbreakingly slim. Which does not by any means keep them from being a highly entertaining set of losers. 
Mr. Butterworth made a blazing theatrical debut in New York in 1997 with "Mojo," a high-adrenaline play about crime, drugs and rock 'n' roll in the 1950's, also produced by the Atlantic. Though this production of "Night Heron" has the same director (Neil Pepe) and several of the same actors, it doesn't grab you with the immediacy that "Mojo" did.
The play wants to say so much that it chokes on its ambitions. And you're more aware than you were with "Mojo" of the problems of an American cast putting over regional English characters. Using poetry from writers like Andrew Marvell as its linguistic motor, "Heron" doesn't have the more easily addictive rock rhythms that kept "Mojo" in full spin.
But it is bracing to watch a talented dramatist stretch beyond the formula of his first success. And Mr. Butterworth -- who oversaw the film version of "Mojo" and wrote and directed the movie "Birthday Girl" with Nicole Kidman -- has by no means lost his gift for a kinetic use of language for the stage.
Mr. Butterworth belongs to a group of young English and Irish playwrights who have brought a heady new energy to the drama of disaffection. The more probing British plays of the mid- to late 20th century specialized in lives of quiet desperation.
Like his contemporaries Martin McDonagh (the "Leenane" trilogy) and Conor McPherson (in "This Lime Tree Bower" and "The Good Thief"), Mr. Butterworth likes his desperation loud, funny and flashy. He drags the subliminal menace of Harold Pinter to the surface, where it explodes into exotic, often violent mayhem that Quentin Tarantino might admire.
The central characters of "Night Heron," who live on the edge of a marsh in the Cambridgeshire Fens, certainly qualify as desperate. Wattmore (Chris Bauer) and Griffin (Clark Gregg) have lost their jobs as gardeners on the campus at Cambridge University.
They are getting hungrier and more frightened by the day, mysteriously cringing before the headlights of every car that passes. At Griffin's insistence they take in a lodger, a bruiser of a woman named Bolla (Mary McCann), who is just out of prison and eager to help her landlords make good.
As in "Mojo" and "Birthday Girl," Mr. Butterworth delights in imparting information with tantalizing slowness and in setting up situations that inspire double takes. The play bides its time, for instance, in explaining the unlikely presence of a wall-size copy of a Byzantine screen depicting the Last Judgment, in the squalid hovel shared by Wattmore and Griffin. (The skillfully claustrophobic set, which could do multiple duty for any number of Mr. McDonagh's plays, is by Walt Spangler.)
Then there's the moment when Wattmore wakes up to find an unknown naked man (possibly dead) on the floor and a large rabbit (definitely dead) dangling overhead.
Such seemingly dislocated elements are eventually sewn into a crazy quilt of a story along with a religious cult, a scout troop, the poisoning of a litter of puppies, tips for cultivating roses and the elusive heron of the title, who has been spotted in the region. Not to mention all that poetry of both the classic and the homemade variety through which the characters seek worldly and otherworldly salvation.
The zest of Mr. Butterworth's dialogue comes from mixed marriages of working-class vernacular and arty subjects, of earthiness and mysticism. And the careful, often touching performances never betray any awareness of incongruity. Especially fine is the symbiotic teamwork between Mr. Gregg, who suggests the feral cunning and fear of a cornered rodent, and Mr. Bauer, who has the glazed, suffering gaze of a martyred saint in a Baroque painting.
Ms. McCann, tricked up in a fat suit and a neopunk haircut, gives a deftly timed deadpan performance, and the audience seems to adore her. But the feeling that she is impersonating instead of embodying her character takes the edge off the very real danger that Bolla must exude.
Overall, this production -- which also features the reliable Atlantic regulars Jordan Lage and Jim Frangione -- is stronger on comic surface than tragic depths. And by evening's end you don't doubt that Mr. Butterworth is aspiring to tragedy of a sort, both particular and universal.
Like film noirs and ghost stories, "Heron" is most enjoyable when it sustains a state of suspense. Once things start falling into patterned place, an inevitable sense of letdown sets in. And Mr. Butterworth has combined so many anarchic quirks and twists of plot that the play finally sags beneath them. Before that moment arrives, though, there is plenty to bewitch and bewilder any theatergoer in search of an original and questing imagination.

THE NIGHT HERON

By Jez Butterworth; directed by Neil Pepe; set by Walt Spangler; costumes by Laura Bauer; lighting by Tyler Micoleau; sound by Scott Myers; production stage manager, Darcy Stephens; production manager, Kurt Gardner; general manager, Ryan Freeman. Presented by the Atlantic Theater Company, Mr. Pepe, artistic director. At 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea.

WITH: Chris Bauer (Wattmore), Clark Gregg (Griffin), Mary McCann (Bolla), Damian Young (Neddy), Jordan Lage (Royce), Joe Stipek (Boy) and Jim Frangione (Dougal).

HEADLINE: LETTER FROM EUROPE; 
Russia and Germany: A Reunion of Bookworms

BYLINE:  By Mark Landler

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 7 

 BODY:
The word here is that Russia's publishing industry is back on its feet, after languishing for years amid the country's economic collapse and political dislocation. But more interesting than that bit of news, perhaps, is that Russia chose the Frankfurt Book Fair, which opened Tuesday, to trumpet its literary comeback.
 Indeed, the timing and the place are rich in symbolism. The nearly 100 Russian authors who are flocking to this mammoth gathering of agents, publishers and booksellers follow on the heels of political leaders who have cultivated closer ties between Russia and Germany. 
 While Germany and the United States are barely on speaking terms after their dispute over Iraq, Germany and Russia, which made common cause against the war, are basking in the glow of a rekindled relationship.
Earlier this year, Berlin and Moscow kicked off an ambitious program of cultural exchanges that will include art exhibits, theater, opera and ballet performances, and film festivals in both countries. To coincide with the book fair, the Schirn gallery here is showing a major exhibit on Stalinist art.
In a visit to St. Petersburg University in April, while the Iraq war was raging, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder declared that "German-Russian relations are the strongest they have been for 100 years."
That is not saying a great deal, of course. While the Russian-German relationship is marked by deep cultural affinities, it has been disfigured by two world wars and the cold war.
"Lenin, Trotsky and the other Communist leaders spoke German," said Wolfgang Eichwede, an expert on Russia at the University of Bremen. "But in World War II, we tried not only to defeat, but to annihilate, the Russians. We are relatives in culture, but enemies in war."
The first thawing of the ice in German-Russian cold war relations came in the 1970's, when Chancellor Willy Brandt apologized for Nazi crimes in Eastern Europe and embarked on Ostpolitik. This reconciliation with the Soviet bloc fanned the suspicions of Western conservatives about Brandt's reliability as an ally, but initiated a steady stream of contacts between the Soviets and the Germans.
With the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989, Germany and Russia were able to start the arduous process of really normalizing their ties. The first steps were taken by Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Mikhail Gorbachev, the last leader of the Soviet Union, and continued through the 1990's.
Russia's current president, Vladimir V. Putin, is rare among Russian leaders in having significant first-hand experience of Germany. As a young K.G.B. operative in the 1970's, he worked for several years in Dresden, in the former East Germany. 
"This has been very helpful, of course," said Vladimir V. Grigoryev, the deputy minister of press, television, and radio broadcasting, who heads the Russian delegation in Frankfurt. "He lived here, he speaks fluent German, he feels somehow comfortable with German culture."
The United States, usually a major player in Frankfurt, has a subdued presence this year, in part because the American subsidiary of Holtzbrinck, which owns St. Martin's Press and Henry Holt, is boycotting the fair, after a dispute over hotel rates and exhibition fees.
"The organizers made certain guarantees, and then they reneged on what they promised to do," said a spokesman for St. Martin's Press, John Murphy. "It was basically a question of broken trust."
The decision is all the more remarkable because Holtzbrinck's corporate parent, the Von Holtzbrinck Group, is based in Stuttgart. Holtzbrinck is making an exception for one of its imprints, Farrar Straus & Giroux, but only because it publishes Susan Sontag, who is receiving a prestigious German literary award, the Peace Prize of the German Book Trade.
Ms. Sontag has a loyal following in Germany, yet the timing of her award is also noteworthy. She was a vocal critic of the war in Iraq, and aroused fury among some conservatives in the United States by questioning whether it was accurate to describe the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001 as "cowardly."
There are limits to how closely Moscow and Berlin can align themselves. Russia is not a member of NATO or the European Union. That is the very reason, some experts say, that the two are placing such an emphasis on cultural exchange.
But even such exchanges carry hidden dangers. On the eve of the fair, a Russian journalist whose reporting on her country's blood-stained involvement in Chechnya has won international acclaim said her invitation to appear on a panel there had been retracted because of pressure from Russian government officials.
The journalist, Anna Politkovskaya, was scheduled to appear on Saturday with two other Russians who have written about Chechnya -- a human rights activist and a philosopher. The German publisher who organized the panel denied feeling any pressure, and said it was simply not able to scrounge up the fare for her flight.
At this book fair, where rumor and cigarette smoke cloud the air in equal measure, the dispute has caused a stir. But in a measure of Russia and Germany's reconciliation, it is playing out less as an international incident than a publishing-industry tempest. 
Mr. Grigoryev also denied that Moscow had put pressure on the organizers, noting that the fair was likely to feature several panel discussions critical of the Russian government. 
A one-time book editor who worked briefly for Random House in New York, Mr. Grigoryev wondered whether Ms. Politkovskaya was practicing some shrewd marketing. "She knows that creating a little scandal is a great way to promote her writing," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Aremarkets for local advertising recovering? Yes, no, maybe: pick an answer, any answer.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
HOW fast the market for local advertising is recovering -- or even if it is recovering -- has become a subject of intense speculation along Madison Avenue. For those arguing whether or not there is evidence of a comeback, the answer echoes that from the old Certs commercial: Stop, you're both right.
 "Business pacings have become about as predictive as 'flipping a coin,' " one analyst, Marc E. Nabi of Merrill Lynch, wrote in a report titled "Radio Business Still Erratic -- Is It Up or Down?" 
 The answer: yes and no. 
The ardor of local advertisers' intentions to spend in media like television, radio and newspapers has been in question since Sept. 24. That was when Viacom Inc., the behemoth in radio, television and outdoor advertising, warned investors that revenue and profit for 2003 would fall short of estimates because of the uncertainty of spending plans by local media.
The belief that growth is slowing is supported by data being compiled by the Television Bureau of Advertising, the trade organization for local TV broadcasters. In a monthly report, which members are to receive today, Christopher J. Rohrs, president at the bureau, a national organization based in New York, wrote that it appears it will be "very tough to make our forecast range of 1 to 3 percent growth in 2003" because of a slowdown in gains since last month.
The primary culprit, Mr. Rohrs wrote, is the difficult comparisons with fall 2002, when spending for commercials on local TV stations surged compared with spending a year earlier. That year, of course, was 2001, when the terrorist attacks led to lower local TV spending in September through December. Another reason for the strength last fall, Mr. Rohrs noted, was the robust demand for commercial time for candidates in local, gubernatorial and Congressional elections.
There is still hope for 2003 to achieve the bureau's forecast range, Mr. Rohrs wrote, adding that "the key variables" are the demand for commercial time now among candidates for office and "how strong the holiday retail season is."
The retail spending picture was the focus of a report on Monday from Paul Ginocchio, the publishing analyst at Deutsche Bank, who reduced his estimate for retail ad growth for newspapers and questioned the prospects for ad revenue growth for radio.
The issue is not so much spending cutbacks by retailers, Mr. Ginocchio wrote, but the migration of ad spending by department stores to television from newspapers and also radio. For instance, the Macy's division of Federated Department Stores is planning a campaign with Lowe & Partners Worldwide in New York to run on TV that is meant to build the chain's brand image rather than sell specific merchandise.
"As the department stores become more willing to use other media," Mr. Ginocchio wrote, "newspapers will likely be forced to reduce ad rates to induce the retailers to remain in the fold."
Mr. Ginocchio wrote that he now expected retail spending in newspapers to increase 1.5 percent in the fourth quarter compared with spending in the period a year earlier, down from his previous forecast of a 3 percent gain. He also trimmed his estimate for 2004, predicting an increase of 2 percent rather than a previous estimate of 3 percent.
The report from Mr. Nabi of Merrill Lynch, also released Monday, focused on the outlook for radio.
"Companies did not have a definitive explanation as to why local business is weaker than national," Mr. Nabi wrote in summarizing meetings he had with managers from five major radio companies: Clear Channel Communications, Cox Radio, Cumulus Media, Emmis Communications and Radio One.
"The consensus was consistent with our theory," Mr. Nabi wrote, "that local businesses are hesitant to commit to advertising until proof of a recovery is evident in their pockets." That is particularly true for local businesses that are smaller than their national counterparts, he added.
Still, Mr. Nabi wrote, the radio station owners like Cox said they thought marketers "will have to return to advertising to help to attract demand as the economy improves."
The "glass is half-full" perception was also reflected by Gordon Hodge, analyst for Thomas Weisel Partners, who also issued a report Monday on the radio industry.
"We remain comfortable with our muted 2003 radio advertising growth forecast of 2.3 percent," Mr. Hodge wrote, with a slower growth rate of 1.7 percent in the second half.
For 2004, Mr. Hodge predicted, ad revenue for radio will increase 5.4 percent from 2003, with national sales outpacing local in gains by 7 percent to 5 percent.

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Rose 5.2%, Above Forecastfor August 

BYLINE:  Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 

 BODY:
Consumer debt rose 5.2 percent, or $8.2 billion, in August, the Federal Reserve said Tuesday.
 The gain exceeded expectations, with August being the fifth consecutive month consumer debt increased. 
The rise was led by a sharp increase in nonrevolving credit, which includes loans for cars, mobile homes, education expenses and vacations. 
 The July increase for overall credit was revised to $6.1 billion from the initially reported rise of $6 billion.
Wall Street analysts had expected a smaller August gain of $6.5 billion.
The report Tuesday was the first Fed release on consumer credit to include student loans held by the federal government and SLM Holding, the parent of Sallie Mae. The Fed revised its data to 1977, which shifted the growth rate of credit up four-tenths of a percentage point each year, it said.
Nonrevolving credit rose $7.0 billion after a $5.6 billion increase in July. Strong auto sales had been expected to give the category a lift, as terms continued to be easy for auto loans. Nonseasonally adjusted figures showed the average interest rate on a car loan from a finance company up slightly but still at a low 3.56 percent, while the length of the average loan extended further, to 63 months.
Revolving credit, capturing charge and credit cards, rose $1.2 billion in August after a $500 million increase in July.
The inclusion of the federal and SLM Holding student debt increased the overall level of consumer credit outstanding. The total stood at $1.956 trillion in August. The figure initially reported for July, before the change, was $1.774 trillion.

Data is revised to include student loans held by the federal government and Sallie Mae. (Source by Federal Reserve Board)

HEADLINE: Time and a Half in the Capitol 

 BODY:
In a rare Republican rebellion against pro-business priorities, the House has rejected a controversial plan to overhaul the rules covering overtime for millions of American workers. The House initially approved the plan last July, but several members of the G.O.P. majority, clearly sensing voters' concern about hard economic times, switched sides last week. 
That gave the second round to the Democrats, who were warning that many white-collar workers would be stripped of their overtime rights.
 The overtime proposals, already rejected by the Senate, attempt a double-edged change. The first part is commendable. It expands time-and-a-half rights for an estimated 1.3 million low-wage workers who are not covered by union contracts. They now lose eligibility once their earnings hit $8,060 a year; this would be raised to $22,100. More troublesome is the amorphous language that would allow employers greater leeway to designate a new class of white-collar professionals as managers and force them into unpaid overtime if they earn over $65,000 a year. Critics claim that as many as eight million workers, like nurses and computer specialists, could suffer pay cuts, but the administration insists that the changes would affect only 640,000 workers. 
 The White House is threatening to veto the annual spending bill for the labor and housing agencies if the overtime plan is not restored. The symbolic stakes are high as nervous Republicans seek to lace a touch of pro-worker appeal into voting records heavily weighted in favor of the administration's pro-business tax cuts. We urge the White House to accept a Senate proposal to raise overtime strictures on the underpaid, bottom-scale workers, but not tempt employers to save on well-earned overtime by handing out hollow managerial titles.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Dollar Weakens Again(No U.S. Tears Are Shed)

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar's fall accelerated yesterday, dropping below 110 yen, reaching an eight-year low against the Canadian dollar and slumping against the euro. But the decline is still small compared with previous episodes of weakness and, for now, is still a positive for the struggling American economy.
 But there seems to be confusion about what finance ministers in the Group of 7, who said after a meeting in Dubai last month that "exchange rates should reflect economic fundamentals," want to happen to the dollar. That confusion could add to the downward pressure on the currency. 
 Part of the confusion comes from the politics and economics surrounding the policies here and abroad on the dollar. The Bush administration has been pressing China and Japan since the beginning of September to let their currencies rise and the dollar fall because many of the industries hurt by a stronger dollar have lost thousands of jobs and are in states that could be critical in next year's presidential election.
In addition, Europeans do not want the euro to gain too much against the dollar or the yen because that would hurt their exports and the rebound of their economies, which are weaker than the United States' economy.
At the same time, economists generally agree that a weaker dollar is a good policy as long as it does not get out of hand. The dollar has to fall, they say, if the United States is going to be able to stop the growth of its record current account deficit, which is now $500 billion. If the growth is not curtailed, the dollar could fall even faster while interest rates rise, slowing the economic recovery.
The dollar was at its lowest in almost three years against the yen yesterday, trading at 109.79, down 1.1 percent from Monday. The euro was trading at $1.1774, up 0.6 percent. The dollar fell 0.7 percent, to 1.3308 Canadian dollars.
In September, Treasury Secretary John W. Snow began what many foreign exchange traders think is a campaign to weaken the dollar, and since then the dollar has fallen 6.7 percent against the euro and 6.1 percent against the yen.
But against a broad index of major and minor trading partners, the dollar is down just 3 percent, even though it is down 15.3 percent this year against the currency of Canada, the biggest trading partner of the United States.
In addition, the dollar's decline since its recent peak in the trade-weighted index, in February, is only 9.6 percent, less than a third of the run-up in the dollar from July 1995 to February. This is also a much smaller decline than the big dollar fall in the late 1980's, which was helped along by an agreement, known as the Plaza Accord, among America's allies to weaken the dollar. From its high in March 1985, the dollar plunged 33.9 percent until it began to bounce back in July 1995.
"It is not a problem," Michael Rosenberg, head of global foreign exchange research at Deutsche Bank, said of the dollar's decline. "I don't think it will fall too fast," he added, which is usually the main concern among government officials and economists during such a down cycle.
One positive sign is that the stock and bond markets have rallied as the dollar has fallen. Since the beginning of September, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is up 3.1 percent. Treasury prices are also higher, pushing the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note down to 4.26 percent from 4.47 percent during the same period.
And, in fact, there are a lot of positives to a weaker dollar, including making American exports more competitive abroad while blunting the competitive edge of imports.
The United States and its allies have not come close to any big accord on the dollar yet. But the communique issued by the Group of 7 finance ministers after their meeting in Dubai was taken as a signal for a weaker dollar by many currency traders and analysts.
Since that meeting, however, some finance ministers have said that interpretation is incorrect. The communique, they said, was aimed at China and Japan, urging them to allow their currencies to rise in value against both the euro and the dollar. The Chinese yuan is pegged to the dollar while the Japanese have spent more than 13 trillion yen this year buying dollars to prevent the yen from rising too far.
While there was no clear sign of Japanese government intervention yesterday after the dollar fell below 110 yen, it could come again if the yen gains much more. But David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics, said the Japanese might be realizing that "sustaining the kind of intervention we have seen to date is not practical and not looked kindly upon by Europe or the United States."
Ernst Welteke, a member of the governing council of the European Central Bank, said yesterday that "markets have interpreted Dubai in a way that was not intended," according to Reuters. It was not intended to drive down the dollar.
Mr. Welteke may be especially annoyed because while the dollar has fallen against the yen since the Dubai meeting, the yen has not budged against the euro. In trading yesterday the euro was worth 129.27 yen, off just 0.3 percent since Sept. 19. In the same period, the dollar has fallen 3.7 percent against the yen.
"The market has received some messages that were not intended," said Robert Sinche, global head of currency strategy at Citigroup. It is one thing, he said, for finance ministers, including Mr. Snow, to say it is acceptable for the dollar to weaken as a result of normal market conditions. "It is another to say I want the dollar to be weaker."

(Source by Federal Reserve)

HEADLINE: HOCKEY; 
Questions as N.H.L. Season Begins

BYLINE:  By JOE LAPOINTE

 BODY:
When he left the Anaheim Mighty Ducks for the Colorado Avalanche as a free agent last summer, Paul Kariya took a pay cut that reduced his salary to $1.2 million from $10 million. Because he wanted to play with a friend, Teemu Selanne, on a strong team, he did not try to maximize his value on the market.
 His contract is one of many startling numbers zooming around the National Hockey League like so many errant slap shots. The N.H.L.'s 30 teams, according to the commissioner's office, collectively lost about $300 million last season. 
 Television figures, a barometer of the business, show the N.H.L.'s ratings in decline and its national network exposure slipping. Rather than competing with the National Football League, Major League Baseball or the National Basketball Association, the N.H.L. on television is compared to bowling, arena football and other lesser attractions. And the low rating numbers may mean less revenue in the next network contract, expected next season. 
The N.H.L. Players Association said it doubted the owners' claims of financial problems in the last year of a collective bargaining agreement.
If negotiations between the owners and the players lead to a lockout next fall, the way they did for 15 weeks in 1994-95, a new version of the World Hockey Association, currently in the planning stages, hopes to capitalize with new teams in an alternate league next fall.
So, as the N.H.L. prepares to begin its 87th season tonight, a reasonable person may wonder: is hockey in a recession? And, if so, what needs to change?
"The hockey business, from a revenue and attendance and exposure standpoint, from a licensing standpoint and a sponsorship standpoint, has probably never been stronger," Commissioner Gary Bettman said last week in a conference call with reporters. "But we have disparities between revenues and expenses."
According to the N.H.L., the teams spent 76 percent of last season's $1.927 billion in revenue on players' salaries, which have increased to an average of $1.79 million a player. "Player salaries have increased at a rate even faster than our revenues, and this is at the core of the economic problems we are having," Bettman said.
This is disputed by the union. "The conclusions we come to are dramatically different than the N.H.L.'s current claims of financial distress," Ted Saskin, the union's senior director, said. Saskin said that the union was prepared to make compromises that favor the owners, but that the players would not agree to a salary cap or any "cost control" system that prohibits owners from paying players according to the market.
"The N.H.L.'s financial leaks to date have been very selective and completely distorted," Saskin said in a telephone interview from Toronto. "There is no way that their claims of financial distress could withstand any informal level of scrutiny."
Clearly, the bleak picture is what many analysts are seeing. One is Marc Ganis, president of Sportscorp, a consulting firm based in Chicago that works with arena and stadium development, and franchise acquisitions. Ganis said 5 to 10 N.H.L. franchises could be sold, if there were buyers.
One reason there are no buyers, he said, is that "numerous teams are losing significant percentages of their asset value" and "the ratings agencies very seriously question the health of the N.H.L."
Ganis said: "You can't get financing. It's very difficult." He said it would remain difficult until the N.H.L. aligned revenues with expenses and spread revenues more equally among the clubs. The way it is now, he said, hockey revenues are "very, very disproportionate" in favor of franchises like the Rangers, Boston, Toronto, Detroit, Colorado and Dallas.
But Ganis also said that Bettman must get concessions not only from players, but also from owners, who need to share money. "Some teams will absolutely not want to do this," he said. 
Teams like Buffalo and Ottawa are recovering from bankruptcy. But Pittsburgh, a few years after a bankruptcy filing, is making ominous sounds about leaving town if it does not get a new arena.
No team embodies the N.H.L.'s mixed signals more than the Devils. Although they are defending the Stanley Cup championship for the third time in nine seasons, they are an afterthought in the sports consciousness of their own major news media market. They sold out only 6 of 41 regular-season home games in 2002-3, according to Lou Lamoriello, the team's president and general manager. He said that they did not make a profit despite four rounds of playoffs.
The sport that best shares revenue is the N.F.L. Its system allows teams like the Green Bay Packers to compete with the Giants. The bulk of the revenue comes from national television contracts that pay the league $2.2 billion a year, split equally among the league's 32 franchises.
But hockey's television picture is not as big, bright or clear.
In the current package, ABC and ESPN, which are owned by the Walt Disney Company, pay the league $120 million a season. In the previous deal, from 1994 through 1999, Fox paid the N.H.L. $30 million a season and ESPN paid the league an additional $14.3 million for a different package of games.
According to figures provided by ESPN, the average audience for games on ESPN2, on which the league gets most of its exposure, was only 0.23 of a ratings point for 50 games last season, the same rating as in the previous season and down from 0.25 in 2000-1. On ESPN, the ratings dipped to 0.46 from 0.49 in 2001-2 and .59 in 2000-1. On ABC, which broadcasts five games in the regular season, ratings fell by 21 percent. At present, one rating point equals 1.08 million television households.
In addition, hockey's exposure has decreased in recent years. On ESPN2, the number of games shown dropped from 100 in 2000-1 to 75 in 2001-2 and to 50 in 2002-3. On ESPN, the number of games in the same period has been reduced from 27 in 2001-2 to 21 in 2002-3. It will dip to 20 this season on ESPN and remain at 50 on ESPN2.
When Kariya left the Ducks, Selanne joined him in Colorado and took $700,000 less than the $6.5 million he would have earned with the San Jose Sharks. Kariya's decision, according to his agent, Don Baizley, was based on a desire to play an offensive style with a good team. In addition, by accepting less than his market value, Kariya can become a free agent again before next season because he is a 10-year professional earning less than the league average.
Perhaps it is only a coincidence that his availability will coincide with the planned start of the new W.H.A., currently being organized in Niagara Falls, Ontario, with Bobby Hull as its commissioner. Hull was the key player who left the N.H.L. in 1972 when the old W.H.A. was founded, moving from the Chicago Blackhawks to the Winnipeg Jets. The W.H.A. was in business for seven seasons before it folded and the N.H.L. absorbed four teams (Winnipeg, Edmonton, New England and Quebec).
Al Howell, the co-founder of the new W.H.A., said that his group hoped to sell 8 to 12 franchises for $1.5 million each and that an N.H.L. shutdown next fall would be "a big bonus for us."
His prediction echoes the worst-case scenario in an industry that expanded from 21 teams in 1990-91 to 30 teams in 2000-1. In that period, the league left two Canadian cities, Winnipeg and Quebec, and colonized markets in the Sun Belt in the United States, like Tampa/St. Petersburg, Fla., and Phoenix. Two-thirds of N.H.L. teams are playing in new arenas. Bettman was asked the chances of the N.H.L. reducing the number of teams. "None," he said.
One of his top aides for the first seven years of his administration was Steve Solomon, now an independent sports consultant. When asked whether the hockey business, over all, was healthy, Solomon said yes and no. He added that it was obviously a "very difficult year for the yes part."
The talk of a shutdown next year "makes it difficult for the fans to embrace the sport," Solomon said. Nevertheless, Solomon said, hockey will grow and its investors will enjoy the benefits, eventually. "It will have its ups and downs, like the New York Stock Exchange," he said. "Over the long haul, investors in the sport will see it grow. At the core is the game, and it is a great team sport."

SECTION: Section C; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 571 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Court Lets U.S. Enforce Do-Not-Call Program
A federal appeals court let the Federal Trade Commission enforce its do-not-call program against telemarketers, while the agency appeals a judge's ruling that declared the rule unconstitutional.
 The ruling lets the commission fine telemarketers up to $11,000 for each violation as it appeals a decision by Judge Edward W. Nottingham of Federal District Court in Denver that struck down the list that has registered 51 million phone numbers. Page C6. 

PepsiCo Profits Up 13% in Quarter
Third-quarter earnings at PepsiCo rose 13 percent on the strength of new products at its Frito-Lay division and strong sales in its domestic beverage and international businesses. The results met analysts' expectations, but some analysts said the results, and Pepsi's performance in particular, had become predictable and lackluster. C4.

Coca-Cola reached a $540,000 settlement with Matthew Whitley, a former executive who filed a lawsuit against the company asserting that he was fired after he raised concerns about accounting fraud and a rigged marketing test in Burger King restaurants. C4.

The Bets Are In for Nobel Award
Professors and graduate students in the nation's top economics programs expect a man named Ed to win the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science this morning. They are just not sure if it will be Edmund S. Phelps of Columbia University or Edward C. Prescott of the University of Minnesota. C3.

U.S. Says Heating Costs Are Steady
The Energy Department predicted people who heat their homes with natural gas will have slight increases in their bills this winter, while those who use oil or propane will have slight reductions. C11.

Atlantic Monthly Ranks Colleges
The Atlantic Monthly has published its first ranking of the nation's 50 most selective colleges. The ranking of top colleges has become a multimillion-dollar industry for magazine and book publishers. B9.

Broker Requests a Separate Trial
Peter E. Bacanovic, the former Merrill Lynch broker indicted with Martha Stewart on charges of obstructing an investigation into insider trading, wants a separate trial. C2.

The Seattle Times Seeks a Review
The Seattle Times asked an appeals court to review a lower court's ruling that prevents the paper from dissolving its operating arrangement with The Seattle Post-Intelligencer. C7.

China Promises Asian Investments
The prime minister of China, Wen Jiabao, announced that his government would encourage greater investment in Southeast Asia by Chinese companies. This increased corporate presence and the marked surge in trade between China and the region, he said, show China's desire to bring benefits to Asian countries. World Business, Section W.

Third-quarter earnings at Alcoa rose 45 percent, beating Wall Street's expectations. C4.

Stocks Continue Winning Streak
Wall Street extended its October winning streak. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 59.63 points, to close at 9,654.61. The Nasdaq composite index rose 14.39 points, to 1,907.85. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.90 points, to 1,039.25. C11.

Consumer Debt Jumped in August
Consumer debt rose 5.2 percent, or $8.2 billion, in August, the Federal Reserve said. C4.

Job Shift Affects Office Market
The demand for office space is expected to drop by about 50 million square feet a year as jobs move overseas, according to Ernst & Young. Commercial Real Estate. C8.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Wall Street's October Winning Streak Goes to Fifth Day

BYLINE:  The Associated Press

 BODY:
Wall Street extended its October winning streak into a fifth day yesterday, although trading was erratic as investors shied away from big commitments in advance of third-quarter earnings reports.
 Analysts said investors were likely to remain cautious as economic news trickled in, and they warned that the market could become volatile if company results revealed many negative surprises. 
 "I think we're going to have a choppy market here for a while as the earnings come out," said Barry Berman, head trader for Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee. "But the tone of the market is still optimistic." 
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 59.63 points, or 0.6 percent, at 9,654.61, after recovering from midday losses.
 The broader market also reversed course to close higher. The Nasdaq composite index rose 14.39 points, or 0.8 percent, to close at 1,907.85. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.90 points, or 0.5 percent, to close at 1,039.25.
 Trading was quiet as many investors were waiting for third-quarter earnings reports. Companies were beginning to report results this week, starting with Alcoa after the close of markets and Yahoo today. Many analysts think earnings will have to not only meet, but exceed, estimates for stocks to move higher after six months of gains.
 After the close of trading, Alcoa, the nation's largest aluminum manufacturer, said its earnings had risen 45 percent, beating analyst expectations by 4 cents a share.
 Investors were pleased with the news. Alcoa rose 96 cents in after-hours trading, after losing 8 cents, to close at $28.19, in regular trading.
 Few companies have issued earnings warnings, which bodes well for the market in the next few weeks of third-quarter reports, said Neil Massa, an equity trader at John Hancock Funds. The lack of news has not exactly enticed investors, he said, but low trading volume is normal for a time like this.
 "I don't think there's any worry here," Mr. Massa said. "People are just taking some money off the table, and that's a natural progression, not a fundamental shift in sentiment."
 Arnie Holzer, senior investment strategist at Deutsche Asset Management Americas, said investors were wary, but it was not because they did not think there was a recovery under way. 
 Stocks appeared to be getting some support from the dollar, which weakened slightly against the Japanese yen, trading at 109.79, down from 111.03 Monday. Analysts said this could be good news for large-cap companies, technology concerns and industrial goods producers that rely heavily on exports that are cheaper to buy when the dollar is down.
 McDonald's gained 62 cents, to close at $24.72, after the Smith Barney unit of Citigroup upgraded its rating to buy from hold, citing good sales prospects.
 PepsiCo was down 10 cents, to close at $47.40, in spite of its reported 13percent rise in profits, which met analysts' expectations.
 El Paso fell 20 cents, to close at $7.65, after the Securities and Exchange Commission notified the company that it was investigating some of its filings.
 Terayon Communication Systems closed up $1.50, or 24.2 percent, at $7.71, after the broadband equipment provider said its third-quarter revenues would beat estimates.
 LookSmart slid $1.58, or 52.3 percent, to close at $1.44, after Microsoft said it would end a licensing agreement with the company in January 2004.

	 	 		--------------------	 	

Treasury Prices Fall
(Reuters)
 Treasury bond prices veered lower yesterday as a flood of new supply and a fresh slide in the dollar diminished the allure of government debt.
 A slew of corporate issues were brought to market this week, including a highly rated 10-year offering from Goldman Sachs that was met with such great demand that its size was nearly doubled.
 Traders were also worried that the market might have a tough time absorbing the $16 billion auction of new five-year Treasury notes today, after last week's rise in payrolls prompted a sell-off in bonds.
 By late in the day, the 10-year note fell 23/32, to a price of 99 29/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.26 percent from 4.17 percent. And the 30-year bond fell 1 10/32, to 103 6/32; its yield climbed to 5.16 percent from 5.07 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES; 
U.S. Sees Gas Heating Costs Roughly at Last Year's Levels

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 

 BODY:
The natural gas price spikes of last winter will not be repeated in the coming months if temperatures are normal, the Energy Department predicted on Tuesday. 
 Even so, people who heat their homes with natural gas will have slight increases in their bills, the department predicted, while those who use oil or propane will have slight reductions. 
 In an annual report, the Winter Fuels Outlook, the department predicted an average cost for residential customers of $9.17 for each 1,000 cubic feet, up from $8.39 last year, but said they will use less. Last year was about 3 percent colder than average, and 8 percent colder in the Northeast; the Energy Department is assuming an average winter this year and lower fuel consumption as a result. 
 Heating oil will sell for an average price of $1.33 a gallon, the same as last year, the department said, and propane for $1.21 a gallon, up a penny from last winter.
"On average, the U.S. consumer will be paying less," said Guy Caruso, the administrator of the Energy Information Administration. 
 He called the prediction for this year "basically a neutral outlook."
 That is considerably improved from earlier in 2003, when inventories of oil and natural gas were extremely low. Natural gas supplies are now in the normal range, and Mr. Caruso said he was surprised at how fast they had been rebuilt. High natural gas prices last winter stimulated drilling and resulted in a 2 percent increase in domestic production this year, he said. In addition, a wet, cool summer held down demand for electricity made from natural gas, and an economic slowdown depressed industrial demand for gas.
 But some of last winter's run-up in gas prices will be reflected in the prices charged by distributors this winter, he said.
 Oil inventories, which were lower because of reduced production from Venezuela during political unrest there, have also recovered.
 Residential consumers may still find this an expensive winter by recent standards, he said. "Eight of the 10 years in the 90's were warmer than normal," Mr. Caruso said. "Consumers tended to get used to those." 
 The department projected that the commodity price of oil would stay near $30 a barrel for the American benchmark, West Texas intermediate crude oil, slightly lower than last winter. Natural gas at the wellhead will average around for 1,000 cubic feet, about 30 cents less than last year, it forecast. For all of 2003, the average wellhead price will be about $4.90, Mr. Caruso said, up from $3 in 2002, and will be about $4 for all of 2004.
 Prices briefly rose to $7 last winter.
 The predictions exclude extraordinary events, like extreme weather conditions or turbulence in oil-exporting countries. Mr. Caruso said Iraq, Nigeria and Venezuela could each experience events that would reduce overall oil production.
 He said that oil supplies were still low in this country. Shortages in heating oil can be made up by shipments from Rotterdam, he said. But new rules on gasoline taking effect in New York and Connecticut on Jan 1. will reduce the ability of European refiners to supply markets in those states, he said. The two states will ban the gasoline additive MTBE, and refiners there will have to use ethanol instead to meet a requirement for an oxygenate in gasoline. But ethanol evaporates easily, leading to air pollution, so gasoline that is to be blended with ethanol has to be refined differently, in a way that is not commonly done in Europe.

HEADLINE: China Promises More Investment in Southeast Asia 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: NUSA DUA, Indonesia, Oct. 7 

 BODY:
The prime minister of China, Wen Jiabao, making his first appearance before Southeast Asian leaders Tuesday, announced that his government would encourage greater investment in the region by Chinese companies.
 This increased corporate presence, combined with the marked surge in trade between China and the region, shows China's desire to "bring tremendous immediate and long-term benefits to Asian countries," he said. 
 Sounding more like a champion salesman than the number-crunching manager of the world's fastest-growing economy, Mr. Wen suggested that in two years China's trade with the 10 Southeast Asian nations could come very close to or even surpass that between the United States and Southeast Asia. The prime minister entered the meeting of business leaders of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, known as Asean, with his hands clasped above his head. 
 To a region battered by a financial crisis six years ago, and still recovering, his message was: don't fear us, love us. China represents a big market, and is a big investor, and its very size will help lift all boats, he suggested. At the end of his spirited address, he received robust applause from the gathering here on the island of Bali.
 China, Japan and South Korea participate in the Asean summit meeting, although they are not members of the regional group. Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan spoke immediately after the Chinese leader, and in contrast, delivered an address in a more subdued tone about Japanese development aid to the region.
 At the opening of the meeting Tuesday, the leaders signed a document to establish an Asean economic community, a move that has been largely forced upon them by the sudden competition from China.
 Two of the Asean leaders, Goh Chok Tong of Singapore and Thaksin Shinawatra of Thailand, say they urgently want a common market in Southeast Asia so that the region can face China from a position of strength.
 But in closed-door negotiations Tuesday, Singapore and Thailand were unable to persuade the other countries to move closer the current 2020 deadline for completely forming a common market.
 Timelines were set out for completing liberalization in 11 priority sectors including auto parts, agricultural commodities and tourism by 2010. Still, there were no steps for completing entire market integration of any one sector before 2010.
 The document pledged to "streamline" decision making and to strengthen institutions for enforcing the economic liberalization.
 But in deference to Asean's basic principle of noninterference with each member's affairs, the document said that "consensus" would govern the decision-making by the economic bodies.
 In another indication of China's dominance at this year's summit, on Wednesday the Chinese leader is scheduled to sign three documents with the Asean group. These include a treaty of amity that pledges China and the Asean countries to promote stability and cooperation in the region. 
 Mr. Wen will also sign an "early harvest" agreement that will allow some Asean countries to receive beneficial treatment from China on some products, primarily in agriculture. A third document, called the China-Asean strategic partnership, is similar to agreements Asean has with Russia and the United States.
 Among those in the audience for Mr. Wen's speech were some of the nearly 50 executives from China's banking, auto, telecommunications and advertising industries who came to the meeting. 
 Mr. Wen was not specific about which Chinese corporations would be encouraged to come to the region. Chinese energy companies have already started investing in Indonesia's oil and gas fields, and have announced intentions to buy even bigger interests.
 The prime minister said that direct investment from China to Asian countries was growing at more than 20 percent annually, and in some countries even more than 40 percent.
 "With the further expansion of China's economy, an increasing number of competitive Chinese companies will go to Asian countries and be directly involved in local economic development," he said.
 An American business executive in the audience said the prime minister's statement about Chinese investment in the region amounted to a government directive.
 "When Wen says: 'We're telling Chinese business to come down here,' in the Chinese system that's a mandate," said Ernest Z. Bower, the president of the US-ASEAN Business Council.
 In stressing the fast-growing trade between China and the Southeast Asian region, Mr. Wen said that he believed that a China-Asean free trade area would be completed by 2010. The initiative for the free trade area came from China last year and "positive headway" has been made in negotiations, the prime minister said.
 Trade between China and Southeast Asia had grown by 55.5 percent in the first six months of this year, he said.
 "If it grows at the current speed, bilateral trade volume is expected to surpass $100 billion in 2005," he said.
 Trade between the United States and the Asean countries was $120 billion last year, Mr. Bower said.
 "I got the feeling that China is looking very closely at that U.S. number," he added.

HEADLINE: Grass Is Green for Amazon Farmers 

BYLINE:  ByTONY SMITH 

DATELINE: CAMPO LIMPO, Brazil 

 BODY:
Jose Mateus has placed his hopes for the future in the sweet-scented grass now reaching shoulder height in the fields he farms not far from where he lives with his family of four sons and over a dozen grandchildren in this poor dusty community on the Amazon delta. 
 The grass, known as priprioca, should fetch twice the price of the watermelons and manioc that Mr. Mateus, 52, has traditionally grown in this area, which is a two-hour drive southwest of Belem. If the new crop succeeds, he says, it "will change everything in our lives --better houses for us, better food for our kids." 
 That Mr. Mateus and his equally poor neighbors nurture such hopes at all is thanks largely to Natura, a Brazilian cosmetics company that has helped pay for the planting of the grass and has promised to buy it all to make a new perfume it hopes to sell to environmentally conscious consumers. Natura plans to go global with a range of body care products made from exotic fruits, roots and nuts, all harvested in sustainable forest reservations or on small, traditional plantations like Mr. Mateus's. 
 Executives at Natura, which is based in Sao Paulo, argue that by buying produce from the forest dwellers and also from farmers like Mr. Mateus, they can help preserve the Amazon's rich biodiversity and its intricate ecological balance while still earning a profit for their company. But can they succeed where bigger corporations with deeper pockets, firmly established in the developed world, have failed?
 The Body Shop and Ben & Jerry's, for example, scored runaway commercial successes in the 1990's with eco-friendly products from the Amazon, but then found that they had badly damaged their reputations when they were unable to keep up with demand and were forced to turn to more conventional sources to supply the market.
 Such a test now looms for Natura as it prepares to roll out its Ekos brand of shampoos, soaps, massage oils and perfumes next year in Europe. Sales to the United States should follow in 2005, according to Pedro Passos, the chief executive of Natura. 
 Natura hopes to capture a relatively modest $200 million slice of the estimated $6 billion worldwide market for natural or organic cosmetics, which would lift its current sales of about $500 million within Brazil by about 40 percent. But to do so Natura will have to compete directly with well-known international brands like Yves Rocher, L'Occitane, Bodyworks, Origins and Aveda.
 While eager to repeat the commercial success of the Body Shop and Ben & Jerry's, Natura executives are equally eager to avoid the problems faced by both those companies. Ben & Jerry's Rainforest Crunch ice cream and the Body Shop's creamy Brazil nut shampoos and conditioners were once hailed -- by their producers and consumers -- as products that could help save the Amazon by offering local farmers an alternative to the illegal, and highly profitable, logging of tropical timber and forest clearing for mining, cattle raising or intensive farming of soybeans and other cash crops.
 But as demand exploded, the Amazon cooperative that harvested Brazil nuts for the ice cream could not meet demand and Ben & Jerry's had to buy nuts on the open market supplied by large-scale producers, some notorious for their antilabor practices. Rainforest Crunch was discontinued in 1997.
 The Body Shop ran into trouble when aid groups and its Brazilian representative sharply criticized statements by the company's founder, Anita Roddick, that the Amazon natives were being paid first-world wages for growing Brazil nuts. To add to the Body Shop's troubles, a chief of the Kayapo tribe, a main supplier and symbol of the company's "Trade Not Aid" initiatives, filed suit over the use of his image in Body Shop promotions. The Body Shop now buys Brazil nuts from a larger-scale Amazonian cooperative and also from Peru.
 "It wasn't that the intentions of Ben & Jerry's or the Body Shop were not good," said Jon Entine, a expert on business ethics. "It's just that when they found out just how difficult it was, they took the easy way out and began behaving like any other big corporation."
 The Amazon is still shrinking fast. Last year, another 10,000 square miles of rainforest -- an area roughly the size of Belgium -- were lost mainly to pasture land, soybean plantations and illegal logging, representing a 40 percent increase in deforestation compared with the previous year. 
 So, is Mr. Mateus right in pinning his hopes on priprioca? Certainly, according to Eduardo Luppi, Natura's director of innovation.
 Priprioca, which has long been grown in small quantities in the region, was first spotted by a member of Mr. Luppi's research team hanging on a herb stall at the dockside Ver-o-peso market in the bustling Amazon port of Belem. 
 The researchers were charmed by the plant's scent, but dismayed when they found out the market was supplied by only one tiny farming community that grew just four tons of the grass a year. For an annual run of perfume, Natura needed at least 40 tons.
 Mr. Luppi's team persuaded the farming community to share its expertise with two others, including Campo Limpo. Natura bought bulbs from the original community to plant and promised to buy crops from all three groups.
 "We don't want this model to be valid for just two or three families," Mr. Luppi said. "It has to be more than emblematic, more than a niche. And we have to make money."
 Mr. Luppi is also working on switching all Natura's Ekos soaps from tallow to a vegetable oil base, meaning a potential extra $3,000 a year income -- a small fortune by local standards -- for another 1,000 families in the region.
 As many farming communities already sell fruit and vegetables or milk to regional cooperatives, Mr. Luppi is simply asking those cooperatives to start handling oil pressed from Brazil nuts, andiroba and passion fruit seeds, too. 
 Using a cooperative, however, did not work for Ben & Jerry's. And the Body Shop found it difficult to coordinate supplies from isolated pockets of the Amazon jungle. So why should Natura have more success? 
 "We do have the advantage that we are Brazilian and we are in Brazil," Mr. Luppi said. "If you are in England or America and want to manage something like this in the Amazon by remote control, you can forget it."
 While skeptical that the market for Amazon products can produce another boom like that of the 1990's, experts here say the global niche is still big enough to make it worth Natura's while. 
 "If they learn from others mistakes in the past, they could do it," said Saulo Petean, a former representative for the Body Shop in Brazil. "As long as the social responsibility thing doesn't become just another marketing tool, it is possible to do both things -- be responsible and turn a profit."

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET --Stamford; 
An Empire Of Offices Fades Out

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 3 

 BODY:
High Ridge Park, a 38-acre harbinger of the suburban office campus boom of the 1970's and 1980's was sold this week to the George Comfort & Sons Real Estate Company in Manhattan for $86 million. It was the last remaining piece of a 4.4-million-square-foot real estate empire created in Stamford from the mid-1960's to the mid-1980's by the F.D. Rich Company. Much of the rest was lost during the real estate debacle of the late 1980's and early 1990's.
 The High Ridge Park property had been marketed sporadically for the last four years by F.D. Rich and its partners, Hoffman Investment Partners of Stamford, the Samuel Miller family of Stamford, and the Calmon Ginsberg family of New York. 
 Built in the mid-1960's to attract corporations seeking to escape costs, crime and congestion in New York, the park's 500,000 square feet of office space was dispersed among six buildings designed for individual tenants.
 "We were listening when Pepsico, American Can, Olin, and the New York Stock Exchange were talking about leaving Manhattan," said Robert N. Rich, the company's vice chairman. "We built the park for $30 million, including $446,796 for the land. 
 "There was no office market then," he added. "We were the only ones with space. General Time and CBS Laboratories moved in, followed by Contintental Oil, Texas-Gulf, General Signal, Xerox, Citizens Utilities and the American Thread Company." Rents were $5.75 a square foot annually and leases stretched to 20 years. Current rents range from the $20's to the low $30's and leases are generally 10 years. 
 The F.D. Rich Company, founded in 1920 by Frank D. Rich Sr. put the park three and a half miles from downtown, where, as Stamford's designated urban renewal developers, it was supervising a huge demolition project to make way for the rebuilt central business district. 
 While some companies wanted a campus, others wanted to be downtown. Robert Rich and his brother, Frank D. Rich Jr., put up buildings along a mile-long stretch of Interstate 95 and on Atlantic Street and Tresser Boulevard. Among them were the Landmark Building office tower; Stamford Town Center; the GTE Building; Champion International; the Marriott Hotel; Nos. 4, 6, 8, and 10 Stamford Forum; 300 Atlantic Street; and 177 Broad Street. 
 Almost all passed from the Rich Company's control during the 1980's and 1990's. The company recently sold the remaining three acres of the old urban renewal site to Target. Once dominant in Stamford, the Rich company now retains only a 15 percent interest in the Stamford Town Center. 
 High Ridge Park and its futuristic buildings designed by Victor Bisharat were ridiculed by architecture critics. The General Time Building was likened to a space ship, a flying saucer or a hamburger, and the park itself was deemed the equivalent of a nouveau riche housing project.
 "That didn't stop the public from lining up to get into the General Time Building," Mr. Rich said. "It was open for tours on Sundays." Nor did it inhibit rentals that kept the park going in good times and bad. 
 Some buildings now have multiple tenants and the vacancy rate within the park is the same as Stamford's overall office vacancy rate: 14 percent. Among the longtime single-occupancy tenants are Cadbury Beverages, Citizens Communications and Mead/Westvaco. 
 Marketing of the park was taken over in February by Jeffrey R. Dunne, senior vice president for investments, and his team at CB Richard Ellis, producing seven bids, mostly from New York and Chicago. The offer from George Comfort & Sons' offer was the one accepted.
 "We didn't hit their dream price, but it was pretty good," Mr. Dunne said. The park's location off High Ridge Road and Exit 35 of the Merritt Parkway, its condition and landscaping were cited with its history of high-quality tenants as selling points, Mr. Dunne said.
 F.D. Rich's share of the proceeds will be deployed among new ventures created by the family's third generation, Thomas L. Rich, Robert's son. "There will be no over-leveraging, no repeat of the '80's and early '90's," he said. "We contemplate being active regionally, acquiring and developing primarily commercial properties along the Boston- to-Washington corridor."
 High Ridge Park's new owner, which traces its existence to a small residential firm in 1919, became a strictly commercial owner and manager after World War II.
 "We had been looking for opportunities in the tristate and East Coast regions," said Peter Duncan, Comfort's president, "and we saw High Ridge Park in 1999, but it was taken off the market. When it became available again we returned. 
 "It is our first acquisition in Connecticut," Mr. Duncan said. "We have lots of plans for updating the systems, redecorating and making sure the properties are as current technologically as they should be."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
JETBLUE AIRWAYS ANNOUNCES 3-FOR-2 STOCK SPLIT

BYLINE:  By Edward Wong (NYT)

 BODY:
 JetBlue Airways said yesterday that it would issue a 3-for-2 split of its common stock. 
The split will be given out on Nov. 20 to people and institutions holding shares at the end of business on Nov. 10. After the split, the company, based in Queens, will have about 101 million outstanding shares of common stock, an increase of 50 percent. The company has remained profitable since its start, even as larger, more traditional airlines have suffered huge losses during the economic downswing and in the aftermath of the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. JetBlue closed at $67.70 a share yesterday, up from $27 when the stock was first offered to the public, a year-and-a-half ago. Edward Wong (NYT)
